Name: Alpha Phi Omega
Description:
Sigma Chapter at Northwestern is comprised of over 40 active members who focus on leadership, friendship and service.

The major focus of our operations is service opportunities. Members help out on campus and in the local community. We have a variety of involvements including Campus Kitchens, Challah for Hunger, Center for Independent Futures, and Housing Opportunities for Women.

We also have fellowship activities like dinners, a formal, and trips downtown. Members get to know each other and have fun hanging out and doing service with their friends.

There are also plenty of leadership opportunities ranging from leading members for a service opportunity to committee chairs and the exec board. We focus on leadership development and work to create opportunities for members.

Finally, we are a national Greek organization so we have long-standing traditions as well as a national network of members. We recently hosted a conference and attend conferences every year to meet other members, participate in leadership training, and shape the future of the fraternity.

Please check out our website or email us at alpha-phi-omega@u.northwestern.edu if you have any questions!

Due to COVID-19, we will shift mainly to online service opportunities and fellowship activities, although there will also be opportunities to meet on campus for those living in the Evanston/Chicago area! We hope to return to fully in-person events when it becomes possible.
Summary: APO is a gender-inclusive national service fraternity with open recruitment at the beginning of every quarter. Members focus on planning and participating in a variety of community service activities as well as fellowship activities.

Name: Alpha Psi Lambda National, Inc.
Description:
Alpha Psi Lambda National, Inc. is a Co-educational Fraternity geared towards the goals of Latino students on university campuses. As the fastest-growing minority in this country, it is becoming more important that the Latino community continues their education. This trend has also brought with it a need for cultural awareness, cultural identity, and cross-cultural understanding. As a result, there is an increased need for Alpha Psi Lambda for which we try to assist in the identity of our culture. This trend has been demonstrated by the growth of our Fraternity. 

While we are a Latino interest Fraternity, Alpha Psi Lambda has welcomed people from a broad spectrum of cultures across the globe. Alpha Psi Lambda stands as one family united. Our strength lies in our ability to focus on our culture while appreciating the diversity of others. 

The Latino culture is very strongly rooted in family and support, which allows Alpha Psi Lambda to provide those same roots to our Fraternity. Alpha Psi Lambda, to its members, is more than just a Fraternity. It creates that true family support, brotherhood, and sisterhood, at a time in a student's life when it is most important. Our membership prides itself on the values of Familia, Culture, Academics, Service, and Leadership.
Summary: Alpha Psi Lambda was established on February 11, 1985, at The Ohio State University.  We believe in the concept of Familia to create a support network for our members while creating the real-world experience of working with anyone.

Name: Alternative Student Breaks
Description:
Alternative Student Breaks seeks to educate Northwestern students of all majors and backgrounds by sponsoring service-learning trips during academic breaks in fall, winter, and spring. Service-learning is the heart of ASB, which promotes a critical approach to social justice and service that centers the communities affected by a social issue. 

 

ASB trips take place during the first week of winter break and over the course of spring break. Groups of up to twelve students engage with community partners and social issues across the country to deep dive into the social issue and the work people are doing to address it.

 

ASB also offers class trips! Students participating in class trips take a peer-led, for-credit course taught by seasoned ASB veterans before heading out to work with the social issue they just spent the previous quarter learning about. These classes are a great way to deepen your learning about a social issue near to your heart, and also meet wonderful, passionate peers. For winter break class trips, the class takes place during the fall quarter. For spring break class trips, the classes take place during winter quarter. All these fantastic classes are also pass/fail!

 

You can get involved with ASB in several ways. Join our listserv to receive applications for upcoming trips by sending a request to asb@u.northwestern.edu. If you would like to really get hands-on with what ASB does, look for applications to be a trip leader or an exec member. Details for these positions will be sent out over the listserv and posted on our main website at www.northwesternasb.com
Summary: Alternative Student Breaks sends students to volunteer sites across the nation during academic breaks.

Name: American Medical Women's Association
Description:
The American Medical Women’s Association Northwestern University chapter aims to foster an enriching environment for women in science and the medical profession. We hope to give back to the community through a variety of events spreading awareness about women’s health issues. 

Our Objectives:  

…to provide peer mentorship to undergraduate students pursuing careers in science and medicine

…to spread awareness about women’s health issues on campus and the community at large

…to create a positive space for women pursuing careers in science and medicine
Summary: The American Medical Women\u2019s Association Northwestern University chapter aims to foster an enriching environment for women in science and the medical profession.\u00a0

Name: American Society of Civil Engineers
Summary: We are the Northwestern student chapter of the American Society of Civil Engineers, a professional society dedicated to advancing members' goals and passions in civil engineering.

Name: American Statistical Association - Northwestern Chapter
Description: tba
Summary: tba

Name: AMPED
Description: AMPED is a weekend music mentorship program that connects Northwestern students with incarcerated young men at the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center. The “Saturday practice sessions” are offered for 2 hours every Saturday in the CCJTDC music lab to young men who show interest, talent, and desire to hone the skills they learn in their once a week classes. The sessions are facilitated by undergraduate & graduate mentors from Northwestern University, who provide musical assistance and support for the students. AMPED aims to help develop the students’ music composition skills through the use of GarageBand software while offering structured and trusting mentorships between the NU students and CCJTDC students.
Summary: We are a group of students that go down to the Juvenile Temporary Detention Center (JTDC) in Chicago to mentor residents through creating hip-hop music through Garage Band.

Name: APIDA Town Halls
Description: Please add.
Summary: TBA

Name: Applause for a Cause
Description:
Applause for a Cause is a philanthropic, student-run film production company. Our members annually write, produce, direct, and edit a feature length film (~90 minutes) to premiere in May and to raise donations for the chosen beneficiary of that year. In the past we have worked with local and national organizations including the Make-A-Wish foundation, the Howard Area Community Center, and Connections for the Homeless.

Our production timeline starts in the summer with screenplay submissions. Then once a script is chosen, we hold crew petitions and casting auditions when the school year starts in fall. Production occurs during the winter, and finally we edit and roll out the red carpet in the spring.

We are completely student run, and encourage students of all studies and film backgrounds (even if you have none at all) to join our organization so that you can experience college film-making and meet some great people along the way.

Not a student? We accept year-long support, advice, and donations and if you are in town, we invite you to attend the premiere.

It takes a village to make a feature, so we encourage you to participate in any way you can!
Summary: Applause for a Cause annually produces and premieres an original feature-length film, in support of an annually-selected philanthropic organization.

Name: Arch Society
Description:
The Arch Society is a group of student ambassadors sponsored by the Northwestern Alumni Association (NAA). Members will support and develop university-related programs and community-wide events to strengthen the relationships between alumni, students, faculty, and staff and to foster a sense of pride and community. Meetings occur once a month during the academic year with additional meetings or program support occurring as needed.

Candidates are chosen and serve as representatives throughout their time at Northwestern. Each member of the Arch Society will serve on one of the four committees:

(1) Class Programming Committee shall be responsible for class-specific programming to increase NAA touch points with current students between Wildcat Welcome and Senior Week (i.e., Sophomore Welcome Back, Senior Class Picnic)
(2) Marketing & Outreach Committee shall be responsible for social media presence/content creation and outreach to student groups on campus (i.e., supporting social justice and mental health initiatives)
(3) Traditions Committee shall be responsible for promoting current traditions and initiating new traditions (i.e., NU Day @ Wrigley, Northwestern Night at the Art Institute)
(4) Homecoming Committee shall support Homecoming programs, recruitment, and student-alumni engagement initiatives (i.e., Homecoming Social)
Summary: Arch Society members act as student ambassadors of the Northwestern Alumni Association. We support and develop university-related programs and community-wide events to strengthen the relationships between alumni, students, faculty, and staff.

Name: Archery Club
Description: We're a co-ed sports club practicing recreational and competitive archery for educational fun. People of all experience levels are welcome. We provide training for beginners, 1-on-1 coaching for serious competitors, and equipment & an archery range for all university-affiliated members!
Summary: We're a co-ed sports club practicing recreational and competitive archery. People of all experience levels are welcome. We provide training for beginners, 1-on-1 coaching for serious competitors, and equipment & an archery range for all!

Name: Area Councils
Description: Area Councils are student-led organizations that serve as the hall-governance for Northwestern’s residential communities. If you are craving an opportunity to be a leader on campus and play a pivotal role in organizing in-person social programs and initiatives for the next academic year, we encourage you to come to learn more about Area Council.
Summary: Area Councils are student-led organizations that serve as the hall-governance for Northwestern\u2019s residential communities.

Name: Aroma Tea Club
Description:
Tea has always been a significant part of many cultures around the world, and tea can also be a bridge between people from different countries and races. Usually accompanied by art, cuisine, and literature, tea helps us understand the culture of a country from the everyday life of its people. Our aim is to create an open and friendly environment for people to learn about tea and tea culture in the world and to provide an opportunity for students to talk and learn about different cultures.

During our weekly meetings our we will introduce different kinds of tea from a variety of countries. Basic techniques and knowledge of tea ceremony will be taught through practice and appreciation. Students can learn about the cultures and histories of different countries while enjoying the aroma and the taste of exquisite tea.
Summary: Aroma Tea Club is a multicultural organization that aims to provide an open and friendly environment for the Northwestern community to learn about tea and tea culture.

Name: Art Union
Description:
Art Union is Northwestern’s premier art club.

We aspire to promote and develop a community of Northwestern artists, helping to nurture relationships, artistic skills, and various talents from a diverse network of students, through intentional art-making and sharing of the love of art practice. AU seeks to emphasize the art practice of artists at Northwestern, using their passion and skills for art to create a strong community within NU. From sketching and drawing nights, painting sessions, trips to the museums, and chill hangouts at local areas to simply get together and make art, we want AU to nurture the general public’s love for art practice, creating an art-loving family for all.
Summary:
Art Union is Northwestern\u2019s premier art club.
We aspire to promote and develop a community of Northwestern artists, helping to nurture relationships, artistic skills, and various talents from a diverse network of students, through intentional art-making.

Name: ARTivate
Description:
ARTivate is a community arts engagement initiative that aims to use art to create a more diverse and interconnected community, provide safe spaces, and improve the overall well-being of individuals. We plan to host on and off-campus art workshops and guest speakers to reach this goal and to create a centralized digital platform to ensure accessibility and transparency of our program. We believe that art empowers and heals. We hope to share our love for the arts with both our NU and Chicagoland communities, while striving to create positive change through the arts. 

Our social justice arts initiative hopes to implement an art engagement program that would allow students and faculty to branch out and engage students at NU and neighboring schools in the performing and visual arts. This effort can be an effective way for the many NU students who are passionate about art to relieve stress while giving back to and learning about their local communities. Our program focuses strongly on providing a space for students to escape the rapid lifestyle that we constantly embody and extend the passions of students to the larger Evanston community. Through our efforts, we hope to highlight the importance of acknowledging and respecting the arts in our daily lives. We will provide students with the opportunity to embrace their passion or find a new passion for the arts.
Summary: ARTivate is a community arts engagement initiative that aims to use art to create a more diverse and interconnected community, provide safe spaces, and empower individuals to express and use their voices through art.

Name: Arts Alliance
Description:
Arts Alliance is the oldest and largest student arts group at Northwestern University. Founded in 1974 by a collection of arts groups looking to share space, Arts Alliance has grown to become one of the largest student arts organizations in the country. Its annual season consists of three mainstage shows and two Mee-Ow Improv & Sketch Comedy shows. Arts Alliance Executive Board consists of seventeen members committed to bringing accessible, exciting, and entertaining theatrical experiences to the Northwestern and Evanston communities.

All Arts Alliance programming revolves around the three pillars of our mission statement: art that is easy to relate to, art that is easy to speak with, and art that is easy to reach. We tell stories that resonate with our community members by delivering theatre that they want to see without physical or financial barriers. 

Arts Alliance is a non-profit student arts organization committed to providing diverse, accessible, and fulfilling artistic experiences to enrich the Northwestern University community. Arts Alliance is rooted in its long-standing traditions and continues to seek out new artistic opportunities. It provides a positive atmosphere in which students can learn and work alongside a committed and supportive board to create professional-quality productions.
Summary: Arts Alliance creates art that reflects, deepens, and challenges the Northwestern community. We provide a positive atmosphere in which students can learn and work alongside a committed and supportive board to create professional-quality productions.

Name: Asian American Intervarsity Christian Fellowship
Description: Asian American InterVarsity is a group of students on campus who grow together to love God, His Word, His people and His purpose in the world. Students work together to find genuine friendship and a real community through small groups, one-on-one discipleships, and large group gatherings.
Summary: Asian American InterVarsity is a group of students and staff who strive together to grow in love for God, his Word, his people, and his purposes in the world. We seek to be a witnessing community to the Asian and Asian American community at NU.

Name: Asian Pacific American Coalition
Description:
In recognition of the heterogeneity of Asian America, the Asian Pacific American Coalition is a sociopolitical group that provides a space for students who share an identity shaped around their politics to connect, learn, organize, and ultimately resist systems of domination. From our unique position as similarly racialized peoples, we build community and raise awareness of historical, social, and political issues that affect marginalized communities at large due to the interconnected nature of oppressive power structures through the following:
  • Collective learning
  • Support systems
  • Programming, both educational and advocacy-based
  • Coalition-building
APAC’s history began in 1991, under the name of Asian American Advisory Board (AAAB). It started out as an umbrella organization for all of the Asian/Asian American student groups to coordinate and guide their different activities. In 1992, the AAAB gained A-status from the Northwestern’s Associated Student Government. The organization began to make headlines in 1995 when APAC organized a successful hunger strike fighting for the creation of an Asian American Studies Program. The incident garnered public support from universities all over the country and has served to inspire a new generation of young Asian Americans. In 2003, AAAB officially changed its name to The Asian Pacific American Coalition (APAC). The new name was intended to be more inclusive and reflective of the diverse and heterogeneous mix of Asian America. Along with the name change, APAC remade its constitution and redefined its mission statement towards a more holistic outlook, making commitments to community building by addressing political, cultural, and social issues of Asian America both within our own community and with the rest of NU’s population through various programs and events. In the past, APAC has hosted events such as Asian American History Month, a screening of Better Luck Tomorrow with cast and director Justin Lin, the annual Mr. PanAsia, Powderpuff football, Espresso Expressions, and speakers such as actor George Takei, comedian Margaret Cho, music video director Joseph Kahn, SuChin Pak of MTV, Japanese Breakfast, and Alok Vaid-Menon.
 
APAC strives to achieve the following:
  • Commit to accessibility and inclusion, especially with regard to non-East Asian communities
  • Recognize differences in experience within the umbrella of Asian, Asian American, and Pacific Islander peoples, as well as the experiences of multiracial peoples
  • Engage and mobilize the student community through activism and advocacy
  • Undertake intersectional grassroots activism and advocacy in the larger Northwestern community, Evanston, and Chicago
  • Foster collective healing from historical, intergenerational, and individual trauma
  • Empower individuals with marginalized identities

If you are interested in joining APAC, interest forms are open near the beginning of every quarter -- keep an eye out on the FB page or send us an email at apac@u.northwestern.edu for updates!
Summary: From our unique position as similarly racialized peoples, Asian Pacific American Coalition builds community and power, in addition to raising awareness of historical, social, and political issues that affect marginalized communities at large.

Name: Associated Student Government
Description: ASG is the Associated Student Government of Northwestern, a group of undergraduate students devoted to working on behalf of the Northwestern community. ASG discusses and acts on ways to make Northwestern an overall better experience for students. We work with Northwestern administrators to bring change to the university, but we also provide services directly to students. ASG is comprised of a student Senate – broadly representative of the varied student interests at Northwestern – an executive board, and 14 working committees that address issues affecting student life, academics, relations with Evanston, student groups, and more. ASG believes in building a better Northwestern.
Summary: ASG is the Associated Student Government of Northwestern, a group of undergraduate students devoted to working on behalf of the Northwestern community.

Name: Association for Women in Sports Media
Description: The Northwestern Chapter of the Association for Women in Sports Media is a network and advocacy group for women in the sports industry. Open to both male and females, AWSM at Northwestern aims to prepare its members for their professional careers through group meetings, guest-speaker insight, industry connections, and other unique opportunities.
Summary: Network and Advocacy Group for Women in the Sports Industry

Name: Association of Latino Professionals for America
Description:
ALPFA (Association of Latino Professionals For America) was the first national Latino professional association in the United States, established in Los Angeles in 1972. Throughout our 47-year history we have experienced steady growth and demonstrated consistent value. ALPFA continues to build upon its proud legacy with a mission: To empower and develop Latino men and women as leaders of character for the nation, in every sector of the global economy.

More than 92,000+ professional and student members across the country – a number we plan to grow aggressively to 100,000 within the next two years. In addition to networking and professional leadership development opportunities, our members have access to 50,000 paid summer internships through hundreds of Fortune 1000 corporate partners. We aspire to be the business partner of choice for companies seeking to hire and develop Latino talent.
Summary: ALPFA (Association of Latino Professionals For America) is the first national Latino professional association in the United States, established in Los Angeles in 1972. =

Name: Association of Undergraduate Women in Science
Description:
The purpose of our organization is to provide a space for students identifying as women and other underrepresented genders who are pursuing studies in the sciences at Northwestern. Meetings will involve discussion of the unique challenges faced by women in science, as well as discussions with female faculty or graduate students who are also studying science. There will be opportunities for volunteerism, professional development, and academic support throughout the year.

If you missed us at the club fair and/or want to get added to our listserv, just fill out this google form! https://tinyurl.com/auws2020

We hope to see you soon!
Summary:
The purpose of our organization is to provide a space for woman-identifying and nonbinary
students who are pursuing studies in the sciences at Northwestern.

Name: Asterik A cappella
Description: Asterik is Northwestern's premier all male range voices a cappella group, founded in 1994.
Summary: Asterik is Northwestern's premier all male range voices a cappella group, founded in 1994.

Name: Athletes in Action
Description:
Athletes in Action is a interdenominational Christian ministry. We desire to provide every athlete at Northwestern an opportunity to hear how they can know God through Jesus Christ. We are committed to do this as a community of believers laboring together in unity.

If you are curious about this relationship with God, or want to learn more about Christianity a great resource is Knowing God Personally. Also check out EveryAthlete.com
Summary: Athletes in Action is a interdenominational Christian ministry. We desire to provide every athlete at Northwestern an opportunity to hear how they can know God through Jesus Christ. We are committed to do this as a community.

Name: Athletics & Recreation
Description: The Department of Athletics and Recreation: Fitness, Aquatics and Recreational Sports oversees the sport clubs on campus.
Summary: The Department of Athletics and Recreation: Fitness, Aquatics and Recreational Sports oversees the sport clubs on campus.

Name: Athletics Sustainability Committee
Summary: ASC has a mission to decrease the environmental footprint of the Northwestern Department of Athletics and Recreation by increasing awareness among  students, athletes, staff, and fans and reducing waste within practices, games, and facilities.

Name: Aviation Club
Description: Aviation Club helps aviation enthusiasts at Northwestern explore their interest in and expand their knowledge of aviation, including, but not limited to, general, commercial, and military aviation. It fosters interests in students new to aviation by offering a place to explore it in a supportive, knowledgeable, and connected environment. We help Northwestern students connect with fellow aviators to expand their network of colleagues on campus, providing more opportunities to share and participate in their passion with others. We also help Northwestern students interested in a career in aviation connect with advisors and opportunities to pursue their goals during and after college. Aviation is a very cost-prohibitive activity. We want to make it available to all Northwestern students in as many ways as possible. This can be achieved in many forms, and we are excited to build on our current plans to bring it to Northwestern students as best as possible.
Summary: Aviation Club is Northwestern's only student organization dedicated to the social aspects of aviation. Dedicated to helping people expand their knowledge of and interest in aviation, we host a variety of meetings, events and trips each quarter.

Name: Ayers Residential College of Commerce and Industry
Description:
Thomas G. Ayers Hall is on north campus and houses 170 students in mostly double-
occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
Summary: Thomas G. Ayers Hall is on north campus and houses 170 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This building

Name: B Burlesque
Description: B. Burlesque is a dance interest group that serves to teach burlesque dance to students of color and showcase their performances in the annual burlesque show during winter quarter. Promoting body and sex positivity, B. Burlesque offers workshops led by professional burlesque dancers and trips to burlesque shows to get a better understanding of the art. Through 2 months of rehearsals, students will prepare for the annual show to showcase their unique routines.
Summary: A dance interest group for students of color to learn and perform burlesque dances!

Name: Badminton Club
Description:
To allow everyone a chance to play, matches are two games to 21 (rally scoring) with a brief warm-up period. Rackets are not readily available to borrow, so do plan on bringing your own. Due to space restrictions, doubles is usually played. Birdie tubes can be bought at $18 a tube. Please email in advance if you are interested in purchasing a tube. To receive notifications about Club Badminton, send an email to listserv@listserv.it.northwestern.edu with no subject and with “SUBSCRIBE Badminton” in the body of the email. 

**DUE TO COVID-19, WE WILL NOT BE HOSTING PRACTICE IN WINTER QUARTER 2020
Summary: Club Badminton provides court space for undergraduates, graduate students, professors, and the general public of all skill levels to play badminton. We also have an annual tournament with the University of Chicago.

Name: Baha'i Club
Description: Once a month, NU students of all backgrounds come together to discuss some of life's deeper questions, share their unique perspectives, eat home-cooked Persian food, play competitive games, and have a good time!
Summary: Once a month, NU students of all backgrounds come together to discuss some of life's deeper questions, share their unique perspectives, eat home-cooked Persian food, play competitive games, and have a good time!

Name: Baja SAE
Description: The Baja SAE team's goal is to enrich the Northwestern experience through the production of a competitive off-road racing vehicle by inspiring creative automotive design, forging marketable leadership and technical skills, and building a close-knit engineering community. The one-man, dune buggy type car must be prepared to face the most rugged terrain—rocks, creeks, snow, jumps, and mud—and keep their driver safe through all driving conditions including a roll over. The team consists of students, mostly from McCormick, who simply like to build cars and play in the mud.
Summary: The Baja SAE team is a team of undergraduate students who design, build and race an all-terrain vehicle each year. Students are challenged to pull all their engineering knowledge and skills together to engineer a safe, functional racing machine.

Name: Balkan Student Association
Summary: The goal of BSA is to promote the cultures and languages of the Balkan countries by creating a space where individuals who originate from the Balkan Peninsula and individuals who are interested in our region can connect easily and build a community.

Name: Ballet Folkl\u00f3rico Mexicano: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros
Description: Ballet Folklórico Mexicano: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros was established in 2012 by 6 freshmen Chicanas to create a space at Northwestern that made them feel comfortable enough to share and embrace their artistic side, their culture, and their roots. We strive to critically preserve our Mexican culture by showcasing folklórico at Northwestern and the surrounding communities and to increase awareness of Mexican ancestry and to serve as a catalyst for others to take pride in their own backgrounds.
Summary: Ballet Folkl\u00f3rico Mexicano de Northwestern: Ritmo de Mis Ancestros (Rhythm of My Ancestors) is a traditional Mexican dance group dedicated to spreading folklore music and dance on Northwestern's campus and the surrounding community.

Name: Ballroom Latin and Swing Team
Description:
BLAST (Ballroom, Latin, and Swing Team) is an undergraduate partner dancing community. Our club is split into two main seasons - a competition season (fall - mid-winter) and a show season (mid-winter - spring), interspersed with social dance classes and workshops. New members are welcome to join at any point of the year, with no prior experience necessary to participate in either season. The dancesport dance classes are open to anyone and begin in the fall shortly after new student week. Auditions for the show occur early in Winter quarter and then subsequent rehearsals will occur throughout the year until showtime in Spring.  Classes, workshops, and social dance opportunities range in style from social dances like swing or salsa, to more formal ballroom dances like waltz and tango.

Our goal as an organization is to create a partner dancing community here at Northwestern. All dancers are welcome to attend our classes, workshops, and social events.

If you want to get more involved, the best ways to become a formal member of BLAST is to regularly show up to dancesport classes and actively participate in either the competitive or performance seasons.
Summary: BLAST, short for \u201cBallroom, Latin, and Swing Team\u201d, is a partner dance organization committed to creating a community for all levels of dancers. We provide quality instruction alongside competitive, social and performance dance opportunities

Name: Be the Match
Description:
The Northwestern University chapter of Be The Match On Campus aims to increase awareness of the need for more young registry members, educate others about the under representation of ethnic minorities in the registry, and hold campus-wide marrow donor registry drives to give the entire student body the opportunity to join in this global effort. 

We welcome any student to join! In Be the Match, we partner with other groups to host events, have fundraising activities, hold registry drives, host speakers, and more. Members will be involved in planning and holding events. For more information, feel free to contact us or check out our facebook page!
Summary: Be the Match aims to register students and faculty for the national marrow donor program, and raise awareness of the minority ethnic groups that are underrepresented within the registry.

Name: Best Buddies
Description: Best Buddies is an international nonprofit organization dedicated to enhancing the lives of those with intellectual and/or physical disabilities by providing opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, and leadership.  It was founded in 1989 by Anthony Kennedy Shriver. Each member of Northwestern's Best Buddies chapter is matched with an adult with disabilities. The buddy pair maintains regular contact throughout the year and meets several times a quarter for fun activities and themed outings. The chapter also promotes disability awareness on campus and throughout the community.
Summary: Best Buddies is an international nonprofit organization dedicated to enhancing the lives of those with intellectual and/or physical disabilities by providing opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, and leadership.

Name: Bhakti Yoga Society
Description: Bhakti Yoga Society provides students the opportunity to experience yoga and spiritual culture from ancient India through a blend of yoga classes, small group discussions, meditation sessions, vegetarian cooking classes and speaker events that provide ancient prescriptions for modern maladies. Bhakti Yoga is the Vedic Science of connecting with the Higher Consciousness through devotion, bringing about genuine care for all people and things. People of all backgrounds are welcome! We meet on Fridays at 6:00 p.m. for yoga, guided meditation, discussions and dinner.
Summary: Bhakti Yoga Society provides students the opportunity to experience yoga and spiritual culture from ancient India through a blend of yoga classes, small group discussions, guided meditation sessions and more!

Name: Bienen Student Advisory Board
Summary: An organization that helps connect the student body of Bienen to the faculty!

Name: Biology Students Association
Summary: Biology Students Association (BSA) at Northwestern seeks to connect students with a common interest in biology, provide a forum for discussion, and bridge the gap between textbook knowledge and real-world science.

Name: Biomedical Engineering Society
Description: The Biomedimedical Engineering Society (BMES) at Northwestern University offers the chance to establish leadership skills, networking, and career development opportunities. BMES also facilitates community among biomedical engineering undergrads through social events and opportunities to interact with faculty in a casual setting.
Summary: The Biomedical Engineering Society at Northwestern University brings together biomedical engineering students and faculty members to promote academic, professional, and social collaborations.

Name: Biomedical Informatics and Data Science
Description:
The purpose of the Biomedical Informatics and Data Science (BIDS) Student Group is to create a community for biomedical informatics and data science students across Northwestern University’s Evanston and Chicago campuses. The main goals of the group are as follows:

  • Develop an internal and external network for BIDS students and alumni.
  • Foster an environment for discussion related to BIDS work at Northwestern University and beyond.
  • Increase awareness of current BIDS research and promote cross-program collaborations between the domains of informatics, data science, medicine, health and biology.
  • Create an avenue for inter-institutional collaborations with other BIDS student groups across Chicago.
  • Promote additional opportunities for BIDS students through lectures and workshops.
  • Serve as an informal advisory board to BIDS Faculty in curriculum planning and program development.

The main benefits of joining the BIDS student group are to:

  • Develop professional and leadership skills.
  • Network with other BIDS students, alumni, and faculty.
  • Gain a deeper knowledge and understanding of BIDS research, educational programs, and outside projects.
  • Have fun with other BIDS students at Northwestern University!
Summary: The purpose of the Biomedical Informatics and Data Science (BIDS) Student Group is to create a community for biomedical informatics and data science students across Northwestern University\u2019s Evanston and Chicago campuses.

Name: Black Formal
Description: A collective of students, representative of members that both do and do not hold formal leadership positions in Black student organizations, pulled together to identify an event based on a community need. This event was intended to mirror other Northwestern-funded student formal affairs- with students dressing up and going to an off-campus venue for an evening of entertainment, food, and fun. The Black community has not had an event like this in recent years. Most formals or balls that occur within the Black community are hosted by Black Greek-letter organizations. This formal is unique because it is not affiliated with any student organization in the community and aims to create an inclusive space. This formal is in celebration of the Black community, and seeks to fulfill the needs expressed in the Black Student Experience Report.
Summary: Black formal organizes a yearly formal in celebration of the Black community, and seeks to fulfill the needs expressed in the Black Student Experience Report.

Name: Black Graduate Student Association
Summary: Founded in 1996, the Black Graduate Student Association (BGSA), a graduate student organization within The Graduate School (TGS), aims to support the academic, professional, and social growth of graduate students of color from underrepresented groups.

Name: Black Mentorship Program
Description: The Black Mentorship Program (BMP) is a mentorship program for Black identifying undergraduate students at Northwestern. We believe our mission is to improve the undergraduate experience of Black students at Northwestern through mentorship, community building, racial identity development, and engagement with community resources. During its pilot and subsequent years, the program will hold regular meetings throughout the school year with topics ranging from study skills and getting acclimated to college life to what it means to be Black at Northwestern. We are student led and hope to be an asset to the broader Northwestern community by creating a strong Black community and producing confident Black student leaders. Our mission is to improve the undergraduate experience of Black students at Northwestern through mentorship, community building, racial identity development, and engagement with community resources.
Summary: The Black Mentorship Program (BMP) is a mentorship program for Black identifying undergraduate students at Northwestern.

Name: Blackboard Magazine
Description: This student-led publication aims at reporting on issues concerning the Black community both on Northwestern's campus and in the United States, more broadly.
Summary: BlackBoard Magazine is Northwestern University\u2019s historically Black student publication.

Name: Block Student Advisory Board
Description: The Block Student Advisory Board (BSAB) is a crossroads between the Block Museum and the campus community: we are a group of students with diverse backgrounds of study (art history to engineering) who share a love of art and interest in connecting art to our lives on and off campus. The BSAB seeks to bring a multifaceted range of students into the museum to develop new ways to engage the student body and the local arts community through planning and marketing creative events inspired by the museum's exhibitions and collection.
Summary: The BSAB seeks to bring a multifaceted range of students into the museum to develop new ways to engage the student body and the local arts community through planning and marketing creative events inspired by the museum's exhibitions and collection.

Name: Blockchain Group
Description:
Founded in 2017, Blockchain Group aims to foster a healthy and active ecosystem in Northwestern/Chicago and solidify our community on the map as a strong hub for blockchain technology. We work towards this vision by doing the following:

  • provide a gateway for interested students to learn about blockchain technology
  • organize speaker events that feature leaders in the industry
  • work on portfolio-worthy technical and non-technical blockchain projects 
  • collaborate with enterprises to empower our ecosystem
Summary: NU Blockchain Group is an undergraduate group aiming to foster a healthy ecosystem surrounding Blockchain technology on campus through a series of workshops, speaker events, and development projects.

Name: Bobb/McCulloch/Goodrich Residential Community
Summary: North Campus Residential Living Facility

Name: Boomshaka
Description: Boomshaka is Northwestern University's premier drum, dance, and rhythm ensemble. Entirely student written, directed, and produced, Boomshaka has established a reputation for consistently delivering energetic and inspiring performances. We combine dance styles such as hip-hop and contemporary with various forms of percussion, using everything from sticks, poles, and buckets to our hands and feet. Our performers come from a variety of backgrounds and have a number of areas of artistic expertise, ranging from classical music composition and formal dance training to free style rapping and break dancing. We blend our unique talents and experiment with new mediums of expression to create a performance like none other!  Check us out on Youtube, Facebook, Instagram, or on our website.
Summary: Boomshaka is Northwestern's premier drum, dance, and rhythm ensemble. Entirely student written, directed, and produced, Boomshaka has established a reputation for consistently delivering energetic and inspiring performances.

Name: Botany and Bees
Description: Our organization aims to educate the student body on the importance of bee conservation as well as provide a space in which students can collaborate and communicate to achieve a greater goal. We hope to be able to spread awareness about the decline in bee populations over the past decade and educate students at Northwestern on ways in which they can help the environment. We also hope to fundraise for bee conservation efforts.
Summary: Our organization aims to educate the student body on the importance of bee conservation as well as provide a space in which students can collaborate and communicate to achieve a greater goal.

Name: Brain Awareness Outreach
Description:
The NU Brain Awareness Outreach (NUBAO) organization is a graduate student-led public outreach initiative dedicated to educating, exciting, and inspiring Chicago area youths about the brain and the progress and benefits of neuroscience research. Founded in 2010 as part of the Northwestern University Interdepartmental Neuroscience PhD Program, NUBAO consists of a diverse group of mostly graduate students, in addition to several undergraduate students, post-doctorate fellows, faculty, and research staff from various departments and scientific disciplines at Northwestern University. Through close collaboration with public schools and science education programs in the Chicago area, NUBAO organizes hands-on lectures, workshops, and open-house style events regarding a variety of neuroscience topics for students of all ages.

We are an all inclusive organization. Anyone is welcome to join. 
 
Visit us at http://www.nubrainawareness.com
Summary: The NU Brain Awareness Outreach (NUBAO) organization is a graduate student-led public outreach initiative dedicated to educating, exciting, and inspiring Chicago area youths about the brain and the progress and benefits of neuroscience research.

Name: Brain Exercise Initiative
Description: It has been suggested in scientific literature that brain exercises could help slow down Alzheimer's. One article from 2005(1) indicates that exercising the brain through reading and completing math questions while speaking out loud could slow down Alzheimer's. The Brain Exercise Initiative Club intends to help Alzheimer's patients combat the illness by recruiting volunteers that help the patients at retirement homes complete basic mathematics questions or read books aloud. Therefore, the main goals of this club are to help patients with Alzheimer's combat the illness, improve the communication skills of participating students in a volunteering/healthcare setting, and allow students to participate in a sustainable, long-term volunteering project.
Summary: BEI is a volunteering organization that helps patients with Alzheimer's by using simple math, writing, and reading exercises to decrease the rate of disease progression and improve that cognitive function.

Name: Brazilian Student Association
Description:
The Brazilian Student Association (BRASA) aims to establish prolific and long-lasting relationships between American universities and Brazil, thereby creating a platform through which Brazilian students in the United States – and non-Brazilian students willing to be involved – can act to improve Brazil. In addition, BRASA aims to promote the understanding of Brazilian culture, professional opportunities, and the Portuguese language.

A Associação Brasileira de Estudantes (BRASA) visa estabelecer relações prolíficas e duradouras entre universidades americanas e o Brasil, assim criando uma plataforma através da qual estudantes brasileiros nos Estados Unidos, e estudantes não brasileiros que desejam se envolver, podem atuar para melhorar o Brasil. Adicionalmente, a BRASA tem como objetivo promover o entendimento da cultura brasileira, oportunidades profissionais e da língua portuguesa.
Summary: BRASA strives to engage the Brazilian community at Northwestern, integrate it with the community of Brazilians studying abroad, as well as to promote Brazilian culture, social life and pre-professional opportunities on campus.

Name: Bridge Club
Description:
Welcome to the world of Bridge! Bridge is a game of practically infinite possibilities and one of the world’s greatest card games. You’ll love Bridge if you enjoy puzzles or cards or if you’re just looking for a fun social game to participate in. Players of any experience level are welcome to join us at our weekly meetings at the Norris Student Center -  whether you’re a bridge master or have never touched a playing card in your life, we hope to see you there! Participation is open to all members of the Northwestern and Evanston community.

 

For new players there will be mentors available to teach and offer tips about the game. The atmosphere is always very casual and geared towards learning. For experienced players, it’s a great place to meet other bridge enthusiasts, forge partnerships, and get in some good practice. Chances are you’ll meet someone to partner with at local bridge games both down in Chicago and nearby in Evanston.

 

Looking for some serious bridge competition? We also participate in the ACBL Collegiate Bridge Bowl qualifiers each winter and spring. We have a strong history in this event and have qualified for nationals several times in recent years, which typically means a travel package to the NABC in the summer!

 

For more information, stop by our booth at the activity fair this Fall or email Ben at benfisk2023@u.northwestern.edu.
Summary: Northwestern's Bridge Club. Come play with us! All levels welcome!

Name: Bridge Out
Description: Bridge Out’s purpose is to serve as a bridge from the Northwestern campus to non-profit organizations in the Chicago area. Northwestern has an abundance of ambitious students willing to volunteer time as well as an incredible amount of intellectual talent and performance talent that could aide non-profit organizations. In the current Northwestern community, producers of individual student groups, or individuals, are often tasked with forming partnerships and creating opportunities for Northwestern students to volunteer outside the community. We feel this results in many excellent partnerships being unexplored and hope to simplify the process.
Summary: Bridge Out\u2019s purpose is to serve as a bridge from the Northwestern campus to non-profit organizations in the Chicago area.

Name: Brown Sugar
Description: Brown Sugar is the nation's premiere South Asian-interest co-ed a cappella group. Founded in 1999 by two Northwestern students looking to embrace their South Asian roots, Brown Sugar performs a refreshing mix of South Asian and Western music, ranging everywhere from Bollywood classics and Punjabi pop to American rock and R&B. The group performs around the Chicagoland area and around the country. We are currently recording and producing our fifth studio album! Check out our website and listen to us on iTunes.
Summary: Brown Sugar is the nation's premiere South Asian-interest co-ed a cappella group.

Name: Cambodian Cultural Awareness
Description: CCAC aims to recognize and share the Cambodian student experience at Northwestern by fostering an appreciation of this culture. Introducing different parts of Cambodian cultures and traditions to all students at NU through means of different community activities such as trips to museums, cooking lessons, and movie nights. All students are welcome!
Summary: CCAC aims to share and celebrate Cambodia's rich culture, history, and cuisine through fun activities such as field trips to museums and cooking sessions. Hence, if you (all students) are interested to learn more, we're very excited to have you join us!

Name: Camp Kesem Northwestern
Description:
Camp Kesem at Northwestern University is a local chapter of a national organization (Camp Kesem National) that supports children through and beyond their parent's cancer. CKNU hosts two weeks of free summer camp for over 150 children from the Chicagoland area who have been affected by a parent's cancer.

Although our camps take place during the summer, throughout the year, our counselors fundraise, outreach to find campers, and get trained in order to prepare for the summer! Camp Kesem is a great organization for any students interested in children or summer camp, or are interested in making a meaningful impact through service!

Watch this video to learn what we do here

Check out our Facebook page to learn more!
Summary:
Camp Kesem is a nonprofit that organizes a free summer camp for children who have been affected by a parent's cancer.  

Fill out this form if you're interested in joining: https://forms.gle/X5mQTa3EL9vQ64cA6

Name: Campus Curlz at Northwestern
Description:
Campus Curlz will provide education by giving  free lectures and powerpoints titled ‘Natural Hair Inside and Out’ on our campus, schools and other public avenues as well as utilizing social media channels and the corporation website to provide facts, statistics and related data to raise awareness on healthy hair to eradicate the majority's lack of knowledge on the topic.

We will also provide  events and programs including but not limited style parties where we demonstrate how to style hair, tabling events at an activity hour on campus, and dorm chats touching on topics including healthy hair, beauty, networking and navigating through college. 

To maximize our impact, Campus Curlz will provide service by partnering with local non-profit organizations and participating in community events including but not limited to volunteering at local soup kitchens, elderly residential facilities, domestic abuse survivor centers, mentoring and tutoring  at local schools.
Summary: Campus Curlz is a natural hair and service-based organization whose goals are to enhance, educate, and uplift those on campus and in the community through educational support and service.

Name: Campus Inclusion and Community
Summary: DCIC is dedicated to collaborating with students, faculty, and staff with the aim of making Northwestern University an inclusive community for all Wildcats. DCIC's primary goal is to cultivate a community of respect at NU.

Name: campusCatalyst
Description: Each quarter campusCATALYST recruits undergraduate students to provide consulting services for local nonprofits. Students take a cC designed for-credit seminar where they learn about consulting, nonprofit management and the social sector. Teams of 5 students are paired with a local nonprofit that needs assistance with strategic challenges. Each team is also mentored by a Kellogg MBA student for the quarter, who offers advice and guidance in the consulting process.
Summary: campusCatalyst is a student group and Kapnick Business Institutions Program class at Northwestern University that engages college students, supported by business school mentors, in high-impact pro-bono consulting for nonprofit organizations.

Name: Canterbury Northwestern
Description:
We're the Episcopal campus ministry. Through communion and community, we offer students a place to explore issues of vocation, social justice and spirituality -- where the life of the mind meets the concerns of the soul and the needs of the world. We meet weekly to worship God and enjoy each other's company, and we also participate in Diocesan Conventions and weekend retreats. Using the traditions of the Christian faith in contemporary language, we seek to support each other to meet the challenges of campus and society. We invite all seekers -- Episcopal, Anglican, or of any faith -- to join us in these conversations and fellowship.

 

Weekly services during the academic quarters: Sundays at 5:00 p.m. on Zoom! We also host book studies and social events throughout the quarter. Contact us to get on our listserv.
Summary: We're the Episcopal campus ministry. Through communion and community, we offer students a place to explore issues of vocation, social justice and spirituality -- where the life of the mind meets the concerns of the soul and the needs of the world.

Name: Card Fiends Poker Club
Summary: TBA

Name: CaribNation
Description: Northwestern's Caribbean Student Alliance is an organization for students of Caribbean descent, as well as all members of the NU community who are interested in the dynamic culture. It seeks to explore and preserve the culture through many types of on-campus programming.
Summary: Northwestern's Caribbean Student Alliance is an organization for students of Caribbean descent, as well as all members of the NU community who are interested in the dynamic culture. It seeks to explore and preserve the culture through programming.

Name: Carnaval
Summary: Are you interested in practicing Portuguese and learning about lusophone cultures? Carnaval is a space for language learners to have conversations and build on their knowledge. We put on fun and informative cultural events.

Name: Center for Awareness, Response & Education
Description:
CARE provides services for survivors of past or recent trauma, and friends of survivors, including confidential support and advocacy services, education programming, and referrals.

Please note that this page is not kept active.  If you wish to know more about CARE, feel free to email care@northwestern.edu, follow us on Facebook, or stop by our office in Searle Hall.
Summary: The mission of CARE is to create a culture of healthy sexuality at Northwestern University where sexual violence, relationship violence, and stalking are not tolerated

Name: Center for Civic Engagement
Description:
Northwestern University's Center for Civic Engagement promotes a lifelong commitment to active citizenship and social responsibility among all students. Through an integration of academics with meaningful volunteer service, research and community partnerships, the Center supports students, faculty, staff and alumni as they enhance their own academic experiences while contributing to stronger communities and a more engaged university.

The Center for Civic Engagement utilizes a variety of strategies to meet this mission, building in part on the successful programs that are already underway in various halls of the institution. The Center for Civic Engagement:

    • Promotes meaningful community involvement and a culture of active civic engagement among all members of the university community (pre-college students, undergraduates, graduates, alumni, faculty and staff)
    • Develops and promotes cohesive curricular strategies that integrate service and hands-on experience with academic learning in a variety of disciplines
    • Connects and coordinates related efforts among individual faculty and staff as well as programs and departments throughout the university
    • Serves as a clearinghouse to collect and disseminate information on civic learning opportunities
    • Facilitates mutually-beneficial partnerships with community organizations locally and across the globe
    • Provides training and technical assistance to faculty, staff, and student leaders who facilitate service-learning projects and community partnerships
    • Conducts and publishes research on civic engagement and service-learning
    • Evaluates programs and disseminates information on best practices for academically based centers on civic education
Summary: Northwestern University's Center for Civic Engagement promotes a lifelong commitment to active citizenship & social responsibility. CCE integrates academics with meaningful service, research and community partnerships to promote a more engaged university

Name: Center for Health Equity Transformation
Description: tba
Summary: tba

Name: Chair-ity
Description:
Welcome to Chair-ity! We, members of the Class of 2024, began this organization in the summer of 2020 in an effort to crowdfund "the Captain’s Chair" from the Northwestern Bookstore, but have since shifted our funding focus to raising money and awareness for topical issues worldwide. Our current goal is to bring together the University’s student populace (especially first-years) by promoting charitable efforts and creating bonding traditions for future first-year classes, especially as we deal with and prepare to come out of a global pandemic.  

As a fledgling organization, we have many plans to get off the ground–events, fundraisers, and smaller experiences.  Chair-ity is all about welcoming every first-year and every other student that would like to be involved for the sake of both purpose and tradition.
Summary: Welcome to Chair-ity! We're a fledgling group dedicated to connecting topical, charitable causes to traditions and lasting experiences for any first-year (or upperclassmen) students that wish to take part\u2013with a unique focus on "the Chair."

Name: Challah for Hunger
Description:
If you like to bake, eat, or volunteer, Challah for Hunger is for you!! Challah for Hunger (CfH) raises awareness of and money for hunger and disaster relief through the production and sale of challah bread. Volunteers gather weekly on Wednesday (4-5) and Thursday (4-6) afternoons at Hillel to make challah, which we sell to the Northwestern community. Challot come in a variety of flavors: plain, chocolate chip,  cinnamon sugar, and flavor of the week! Fifty percent of each CfH chapter's profits are donated to the national CfH cause-- Swipe Out Hunger. The remaining 50% goes to The Ark, an organization that supports Jews in the Chicago area.

Although we are a Hillel student group, Challah for Hunger is open to all students!! 

 

Contact Avram Kordon at avramkordon2022@u.northwestern.edu for more information!
Summary: If you like to bake, eat, or volunteer, Challah for Hunger is for you!! Challah for Hunger (CfH) raises awareness of and money for hunger and disaster relief through the production and sale of challah bread.

Name: Chapin Hall
Description: Chapin Hall is the Humanities Residential College. It houses 65 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live on separate floors. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
Summary: The Humanities Residential College.

Name: Chi Alpha Campus Ministries
Description:
XA's focus is in three parts: 
 
God • Bringing you to a place where you can grow closer to God
Community • Building a community of people you can rely on, spend time with, and grow with
Mission • Pursuing the mission of helping others find the joy of experiencing God and community
 
Everyone of all backgrounds and identities are welcome in XA!
Summary: Chi Alpha (or XA) is a Christian campus ministry focused on allowing students to grow together in their experience with God, community, and mission.

Name: Chi Omega
Description:
Xi Chapter, Northwestern University
1870 Orrington Ave

Installed: 1901

Chapter President: Emma Brick

You may visit the Xi Chapter's website at www.chiomegaxi.com

Organization Facts

To learn more about Chi Omega you may visit their headquarters' website at http://www.chiomega.com/.

Awards
