Name: Chi Sigma Iota-Nu Upsilon
Description: CSI is an international honor society that values academic and professional excellence in counseling. We promote a strong professional identity through members (professional counselors, counselor educators, and students) who contribute to the realization of a healthy society by fostering wellness and human dignity.
Summary: Our mission is to promote scholarship, research, professionalism, leadership, advocacy, and excellence in counseling, and to recognize high attainment in the pursuit of academic and clinical excellence in the profession of counseling.

Name: Chicago Graduate Student Association
Description:
For more information check out our website: http://sites.northwestern.edu/cgsa/

 

The Chicago Graduate Student Association (CGSA) is a student organization composed of graduate students from programs on Northwestern University’s Chicago Campus, including, but not limited to,  the Driskill Graduate Training Program in Life Sciences (DGP), Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP), Northwestern University Interdepartmental Neuroscience (NUIN), Biomedical Engineering (BME), Clinical Psychology, Genetic Counselling and Physical Therapy.  The CGSA aims to serve in the best interest of all graduate students on the Chicago campus. We work to achieve this goal by advocating for and promoting students’ rights, academic and professional development, social interaction and community outreach. We also strive to bring together students from both the Chicago and Evanston campuses, whether through academic or social events. Our mission is to represent the diverse interests of Chicago graduate students and facilitate The Graduate School’s objective of funding and supporting graduate students’ academic and career goals.
Summary: For more information check out our website: http://sites.northwestern.edu/cgsa/

Name: Chicago Urban Program
Description: The Chicago Urban Program is a Program for incoming students of Northwestern University. CUP is an introduction to the neighborhoods in Chicago through service, arts and culture. The program examines the issues that face these communities, the organizations that serve them and the means by which Northwestern students can effect change. CUP employs the theory of Asset-Based Community Development in teaching participants about issues as varied as housing, education, health care, politics, gentrification and community organizing. During this program, participants will stay in a youth hostel in Chicago's Loop area. From there they will be dispatched to volunteer at community centers, urban schools, homeless shelters and advocacy organizations throughout the city. Northwestern faculty and various community leaders will lead discussions on a variety of issues facing urban communities.
Summary: The Chicago Urban Program is a Pre-Orientation Program for first year students the week before Wildcat Welcome. CUP is an introduction to the neighborhoods in Chicago through service, arts, and culture.

Name: China Care
Description: China Care is a cultural philanthropy group who helps to fund surgeries for Chinese orphans with disabilities and provides programming for adopted Chinese children who live in the Chicagoland area. Please check out the NU China Care website here!
Summary: China Care is a cultural philanthropy group who helps to fund surgeries and education for Chinese orphans with disabilities and provides programming for adopted Chinese children who live in the Chicagoland area.

Name: Chinatown Health Initiative
Description:
What we do:

  1. Volunteer - You will work with medical students and health professionals to provide free primary healthcare to the indigent public at health fairs and clinics. Interpreting is a further way get more involved clinical experience (conversational proficiency in Mandarin or Cantonese required as translator).
  2. Education - CTHI hopes to foster greater education of health-related issues on campus and in Chinatown. On campus, we have held speaker events and discussions. In Chinatown, we are starting outreach initiatives to connect to the public.
  3. Fundraising - In the past we hand-made and sold Chinese spring rolls and pastries to raise funds to buy medicine, equipment, and other medical supplies. New initiatives always welcome! No cooking or language experience needed
  4. Socials - We hold all types of socials, including dim sum outings, movie nights, game nights, etc! Come meet fellow CTHI members and have a good time.
  5. Apply to join the student board as a Junior Executive (Fall) and Executive Member (Spring). Our executive board coordinates volunteering activities and fundraisers. This is a great way to gain event planning experience and build communication and leadership skills!

If you're interested, please contact chinatown@u.northwestern.edu. We will reply within 1-2 days!
Summary: Welcome! We are a student group that supports health initiatives in Cermak Chinatown. Get involved by volunteering as an interpreter or joining the student board.

Name: Chinese International Student Association
Description: Formed in 2009, Chinese International Student Association is a cultural club that welcomes international chinese students and all friends who are interested in Chinese. It aims to promote the authentic Chinese culture on campus, while providing a sense of belonging for the international Chinese students, helping them in transition to college life in US. CISA also tries to connect the Northwestern students with the scholars/ visitors from China in order to gain understanding of Chinese society from a local perspective. Moreover, CISA is also promoting the brand of Northwestern University in China, helping to match Northwestern students to career opportunities in China.
Summary: Formed in 2009, the Chinese International Student Association is a cultural club that welcomes international Chinese students and all friends who are interested in Chinese. It aims to promote the authentic Chinese culture on campus.

Name: Chinese Student and Scholar Association
Description: Northwestern University Chinese Students and Scholars Association (NUCSSA) is a student organization dedicated to promoting social, intellectual and cultural activities for Chinese students and scholars. We strive to provide benefits for Chinese students and scholars at Northwestern University by organizing big festival activites, providing information for jobs and so on. We encourages all, especially incoming, Chinese students and scholars to join our organization and participate in our activities
Summary: Northwestern University Chinese Students and Scholars Association (NUCSSA) is a student organization dedicated to promoting social, intellectual and cultural activities for Chinese students and scholars.

Name: Chinese Students Association
Description: The Chinese Students Association is one of the first established Asian-American student groups at Northwestern. We aim to promote the awareness of Chinese culture on campus and elsewhere while encouraging a social environment for students of all backgrounds. Furthermore, we strive to bring service to our community. Our events are geared towards bringing together the Asian community while sharing our culture with others. Some annual events include: Celebrasia, bowling nights, dances, dinner parties, and hosting famous guest speakers.
Summary: The Chinese Students Association is one of the first established Asian-American student groups at Northwestern. We aim to promote the awareness of Chinese culture on campus and elsewhere while encouraging a social environment for students of all

Name: Christian Science Organization NU
Description: Christian Science is a protestant denomination founded by Mary Baker Eddy in 1879. The church's mission is to "reinstate primitive Christianity and its lost element of healing." We believe that everybody can heal the way Jesus healed, because God's universal laws can be applied with scientific certainty to any situation. For this reason, we refer to ourselves as Christian Scientists. Christian Science is wholly based on the Bible and the teachings of Christ Jesus, who declared that "He that believeth on me, the works that I do shall he do also." Jesus' bold declaration was a call to action that we answer every day through our practice of Christian Science. While people are occasionally confused about what Christian Science is, Christian Science is not a cult, not an eastern religion, a new age practice, faith healing, or Scientology. Instead, Christian Science is a thoroughly Christian faith that seeks to uplift all of humanity by unlocking the healing power of the Christ- which is as present and powerful now as it was 2,000 years ago.
Summary: The Christian Science Organization has supported practical, healing spirituality at NU since 1926. The CSO welcomes both active students of Christian Science and the broader community as we explore campus and global issues through a spiritual lens.

Name: Christians on Campus
Description:
Christians on Campus is a campus group comprising of believers in Christ from various backgrounds. We warmly welcome all Christians in Christ, and reach out to the greater Northwestern community.

Our Faith:

We hold the faith which is common to all believers (Jude 3):

  • The Bible is the complete divine revelation inspired word-by-word by God through the Holy Spirit (2 Peter 1:21, 2 Timothy 3:16)

  • God is uniquely one, yet triune - the Father, the Son, and the Spirit (1 Timothy 2:5a, Matthew 28:19)

  • God became a man, the man of Jesus Christ (John 1:1, John 1:14)

  • Christ died on the cross for our sins, shedding His blood for our redemption (1 Peter 2:24, Ephesians 1:7a)

  • Christ resurrected from among the dead on the third day (1 Corinthians 15:4) and ascended to the right hand of God to be Lord of all (Acts 1:9, Acts 2:33)

  • When a person repents to God and believes in the Lord Jesus Christ, he is regenerated (born again) and becomes a living member of the one Body of CHrist (Acts 20:21, John 3:3, Ephesians 1:22-23, Romans 12:5)

  • Christ is coming again to receive His believers to Himself (1 Thessalonians 2:19)

 

Events:

  • Weekly Bible study on campus to pursue the Lord and the truth in God's word with other students
  • Each Friday during the school year, Christians on Campus hosts fellowship meetings at several homes in the community adjacent to Northwestern. These times generally include a home cooked meal, singing hymns, and mutual Christian fellowship through reading the Bible and reading excerpts of spiritual books.
  • In addition to the Friday night fellowship meetings, we regularly come together with other Christians from the NU Medical Center, the Law School, UIC, and the University of Chicago.
  • Campus ministers are available throughout the week to meet with students at the students' convenience for prayer and fellowship, reading the Bible, or simply to talk.
Summary: Christians on Campus is a campus group comprising of believers in Christ from various backgrounds. We warmly welcome all Christians in Christ, and reach out to the greater Northwestern community.

Name: Circle K
Description: The purpose of this organization is to promote service, leadership, and fellowship within members in order to not only become aware of and impact their community, but also encourage personal growth.
Summary: TBA

Name: Circle of Women @ Northwestern
Description:
Circle of Women is an international student-led organization that supports girls' education in developing countries. We partner with local NGOs all over the world to work on projects, and plan events to fundraise and spread awareness.

We’re motivated by 3 things. First, the world still under invests in girls. Even though a lot of progress has been made in terms of providing access to education for girls, still, there have been groups of girls that have been left behind in the broad rises to access to education. These girls are typically in the most difficult to reach places -- think indigenous, rural, communities, whose intersectionality in terms of broad societal marginalization has excluded them from big waves and progress towards universal access to education. This means that still, the most vulnerable girls are often the first ones to miss out on educations when families have to make hard decisions about who to send to school. 

Each project is tailored to the specific school and community; we take into consideration their needs rather than imposing our own agenda. Projects look different in each place. Some have focused on access like building dorms in Kenya, expanding or increasing quality of education like building computer labs in Peru or A-level classrooms in Tanzania

This is a video of the perfect example of what we try to power through our partnerships. This is a video of Bertha’s story. Bertha is a graduate of Orkeeswa, a secondary school in rural Tanzania Circle of Women partnered with in 2015. Link: https://vimeo.com/256892640
Summary: Circle of Women is an international student-led organization that supports girls' education in developing countries. We partner with local NGOs all over the world to work on projects, and plan events to fundraise and spread awareness.

Name: Club Baseball
Description:
Interest Form: NU Club Baseball Interest Form

If you're looking for a way to continue playing the game you love, but not quite at the rigor you did in your glory days, club baseball is for you. 

Stay tuned or contact us for info on tryouts.

Our schedule is usually something along these lines:

- 1-1/2 hour practices twice per week throughout the year (we have an practice facility w/ a batting cage)

- Fall Season: 1 league series, 1 or 2 non-conference series

- Spring Break: National Club Baseball Association sponsored tournament in Tampa, Florida

- Spring Season: 3-game series every weekend vs. NCBA Great Lakes West Division teams (March-May), with opportunity to advance to NCBA playoffs and World Series

For more information, please contact Co-Presidents Jimmy Lynn (jameslynn2021@u.northwestern.edu) or Andrew Marquardt (andrewmarquardt2021@u.northwestern)
Summary: NU Club Baseball is the best way to continue playing competitive baseball after high school. We practice two to three times a week year-round, and have games during the fall and spring. Tryouts will occur within a week or two of class starting.

Name: Club Cricket Team
Summary: Northwestern's official club cricket team, open to all undergraduate, graduate and faculty members.

Name: Club Field Hockey
Description: Club Field Hockey provides students of Northwestern the opportunity to play high quality field hockey in a fun environment. The recreational, yet competitive nature of the club enables members to enjoy the sport through outdoor practice and games in fall and spring, in addition to regular training games with the Chicago Field Hockey Club and tournaments at nearby universities. Additionally, the club fundraises and organizes social events to further bond the team. The club contributes to the growth of the field hockey community at Northwestern and the greater Chicago area.
Summary: Club Field Hockey is open to athletes of any skill level. The recreational, yet competitive nature of the club will enable members to enjoy the sport through training sessions, away games, tournaments, and bonding events.

Name: Club Figure Skating (NUFSC)
Description: The Northwestern Figure Skating Club consists of the NU Synchronized Skating Team (The Purple Line) as well as an individual freestyle skating program. Members of the club have the opportunity to continue figure skating in college and experience collegiate-level competition. The synchronized skating team draws in both seasoned synchro skaters as well as freestyle skaters who have never been on a synchro team before. Our season runs during fall and winter quarter and practices occur 2-3 times a week. Practices consist of both off-ice and on-ice work, coordinated by the team's coach.  We travel to 3 competitions in the winter, and we end the season with our annual ice skating exhibition for family and friends!
Summary: The Northwestern Figure Skating Club consists of the NU Synchronized Skating Team as well as an individual freestyle skating program. Members have the opportunity to continue figure skating in college and experience collegiate-level competition.

Name: Club Golf
Description: Club golf was brought back to campus during the 2013-2014 school year.  The club was created in order to provide a place for students to play competitvely, in regional tournaments in the spring and fall, as well as recreationally.
Summary: Club Golf was re-formed during the 2013-2014 school year.  We will be playing recreationally at local courses as well as competitively in regional tournaments.  Club Golf was created so give students a chance to play competitively and recreationally.

Name: Club Softball
Description: We are a fun group of female student-athletes who come together to play the sport we love - fastpitch softball. We play other university club teams at a competitive level as part of the National Club Softball Association. In 2019, we ended our season ranked 12th in the Nation after our first ever trip to Nationals.
Summary: Northwestern Club Softball is a competitive, collegiate girls' fastpitch softball team. We are a member of the National Club Softball Association and play teams generally located in the Midwest region. 2019 was our 1st appearance at the national tourney.

Name: Club Spikeball
Description:
Whether you're a seasoned veteran and are ready to compete in the next Spikeball College National Championship, or just love playing casually and are looking to hang out with a fun group of students, Club Spikeball is the place for you!  No experience necessary, just come ready to have fun!

top plays
Summary: We are a team dedicated to competing in the sport of Spikeball roundnet and providing a supportive community for Northwestern students.

Name: Club Tennis
Description:
Our team is close to 100 people. Based on tryouts, we will select Men's A-team, Men's B-team, Women's A-team, and Women's B-team. A-team practices twice a week including co-ed practice on Sundays. B-team practices once a week. The top members of the team sometimes compete against other schools in the USTA Tennis on Campus format.

Practices are held at night, a variation of times between 8pm-11pm, at the Combe Tennis Center inside the Henry Crowne Sports Pavilion. 

Follow us on instagram @nu.clubtennis

Please feel free to reach out with any questions at nuclubtennis@gmail.com

 

Please don't request to join the roster yet. Thank you!
Summary: Club Tennis is a group for students who want to continue playing tennis at a competitive level, but in a more recreational environment.

Name: Club Water Polo
Description:
Practice schedule:

Generally M-TH 8:30-10:00 at SPAC during the fall, Monday and Wednesday 8:30-10:00 at SPAC during offseason.


Competition schedule:

Generally three tournaments in the fall finishing with the Big Ten Championships / Then approximately one or two tournaments in winter and spring quarters / One home tournament a year (generally held in the winter) / Womens tournaments in spring


League affiliation:

Big Ten Water Polo.


Club dues:

Club dues vary per year but are generally around $150 which includes travel, lodging, and entry fee to tournaments.


Tryout schedule:

We are always willing to accept new players. Please contact the president for further information.
Summary:
Practice:
Generally M-TH 8:30-10:00 at SPAC
Three tourneys in the fall finishing with the Big Tens Champ (Men's League)
Home tourney winter quart
Three tourneys in the spring finishing with the Big Ten Champ (Women's League)
Tennessee trip in April

Name: CodeID: Code for Inclusion and Diversity
Summary: TBA

Name: Cognitive Systems and Artificial Intelligence Student Group
Summary: TBA

Name: College Democrats
Description: The Northwestern University College Democrats serves as a campus hub for progressive thought and action. In an effort to increase student involvement in politics and voter turnout among college-aged students, we host events with distinguished keynote speakers every academic quarter, sponsor colloquia on campus, and organize a multitude of canvassing and outreach opportunities in Evanston and the greater Chicago area. In addition, we hold weekly meetings on campus, where we discuss current events, debate progressive ideals and policy, and, most importantly, build a strong community.
Summary: The NU College Democrats serves as a campus hub for progressive thought and action. We hold weekly meetings on campus, discussing current events, debating progressive ideals and policy, and, most importantly, building a strong community.

Name: College Feminists
Description: College Feminists is the premier feminist and pro-choice organization on the Evanston Northwestern campus. We meet at the Women's Center, discussing issues ranging from domestic violence to the college hook-up scene. We believe that every woman should be able to make her own decisions regarding abortion and birth control and we seek to educate students and the community at large about their rights to such decisions. We also work to counteract negative images of women and work against gender stereotyping. We believe in a progressive, informed, and open-minded community. We hope to accomplish these goals by rallying, supporting and educating one another in the Northwestern Community and also by creating a network with other college campuses nationwide.
Summary: College Feminists is a premier feminist and pro-choice organization on the Evanston Northwestern campus. Email nufeminists@gmail.com to find out when we meet. New members are always welcome!

Name: College Republicans
Description:
College Republicans is Northwestern's conservative student organization that supports the ideals of the Republican Party. We host high-profile speakers, participate in campus debates and activities, and provide a variety of opportunities for all political backgrounds.  We bring speakers to campus who appeal to moderates, libertarians, objectivists, and conservatives of all colors, and all are welcome to attend meetings and events.  

Get on our email list at: https://tiny.cc/nucr2020
Summary: College Republicans is Northwestern's conservative student organization that supports the ideals of the Republican Party. We host high-profile speakers, participate in campus debates, and provide a variety of opportunities for all political backgrounds.

Name: Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies
Description: The Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies is an interdisciplinary academic endeavor that aims to promote and stimulate conversations on indigeneity and indigenous populations in the Americas and the transnational imaginary at Northwestern University.
Summary: The Colloquium on Indigeneity and Native American Studies is an  academic endeavor that aims to promote and stimulate conversations on indigeneity and indigenous populations in the Americas and the transnational imaginary at Northwestern.

Name: Communications Residential College - East Fairchild
Description: East Fairchild is a residential college south campus and houses 109 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in an open suite-style layout. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
Summary: East Fairchild is on south campus and houses 109 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in an open suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is available to all undergraduate students.

Name: Community Health Corps
Description:
CHC recruits new volunteers year-round. Please e-mail nucommunityhealthcorps@gmail.com if you are interested in joining!

 

The Northwestern Community Health Corps (CHC) is a grass roots student run organization that aims to empower individuals to better manage their health in Evanston and Skokie area.

 

CHC student volunteers launched and operate the Community Health Hub, a health resource desk at Evanston Public Library where they help community members navigate through their health related questions and connect individuals to existing health information and resources. In addition, through a unique partnership with the American Red Cross, CHC recruits and trains students to be trainers in CPR/First Aid/AED courses in order to provide these trainings free of charge to underserved populations in our community. CHC has formed partnerships with the Evanston and Skokie Public Libraries, Erie Family Health Center, Asian Human Services, the Evanston and Skokie Health Departments, and community health leaders.
Summary: Community Health Corps is a student group dedicated to improving health outcomes in the Evanston and Skokie area by increasing access to health information and resources.

Name: Community Standards Student Reps
Description:
Student Representatives and Student Panel Members are part of the Office of Community Standards Team. This position offers students the opportunity to build community while gaining professional and leadership skills as a part of their service. Students will apply skills such as critical thinking, navigating conflict, and managing interdependence throughout their time in the position.

The Student Representative serves as a hearing officer, with a staff member from the Office of Community Standards, in non-separation level cases of alleged violations of university policy involving student organization/groups. The Office of Community Standards developed this process to allow students a meaningful role and voice in the adjudication process of student organizations/groups.

The second position, a Student Panel Member, will serve on a three-person panel inclusive of students, faculty, and staff to hear cases and make decisions of alleged violation of University policies (non-sexual misconduct) that have the potential to result in separation (suspension, expulsion) from the university. A panel convened for a hearing will typically consist of two faculty/staff members and one student member.
Summary: TBA

Name: Comunidad Latinx
Description: The objects of this organization shall be to foster community oriented around Latinx identity, culture, and history; to provide a safe space for its members; to give back to the local Latinx community; and to educate the wider university community and public about Latinx affairs.
Summary: TBA

Name: Consultants Advising Student Enterprises
Description:
Started in the spring of 2008, CASE is a student organization at Northwestern University dedicated to providing pro bono consulting advice to Northwestern-based organizations. Our work is grounded in our belief in the power of Northwestern University organizations to make a visible difference in our community, and we seek to harness our intellectual capital to help them become more efficient, active, and impactful.

The way we approach this mission is two-fold.

First, we provide measurable results to our clients. We stand behind our work 100%, and we follow through with our clients to ensure our recommendations are fully implemented.

Second, we provide the best possible learning experience for our consultants. Through ‘hands-on’ consulting experience, we develop our members to be well-rounded, analytical minds.

How to join:
CASE formally recruits twice per year. We will send out applications, after which there will be two rounds of interviews composed of both behavioral and case style questions.

However, we encourage students who are interested to learn more at http://www.nucase.org/.
Summary: Started in the spring of 2008, CASE is a student organization at Northwestern University dedicated to providing pro bono consulting advice to Northwestern-based organizations. Our work is grounded in our belief in the power of Northwestern University

Name: Contemporary Thought Speaker Series
Description: The CTSS is an undergraduate initiative at Northwestern supported by the Offices of the President, the Provost, and the Division of Student Affairs. Our board of students seeks to identify and secure the most forward-thinking minds of our generation to speak to the Northwestern community on the purpose and value of a university education in today's world.
Summary: The CTSS invites the most influential and forward-thinking minds of our time to speak to the Northwestern community on issues of universal importance. Our mission is to encourage cross-campus dialogue and intellectual community at Northwestern.

Name: Cookology
Summary: Cookology is established to provide opportunities for Northwestern students to explore cooking techniques, recipes, and ethnic cuisines and cultivate interests in culinary arts through student-run restaurants, cooking lessons and catering events.

Name: COPE (Cancer Outreach Prevention Education)
Description: C.O.P.E. unites and empowers college students in their initiatives to fight cancer through public awareness, fundraising, and patient support (volunteering) for a variety of cancer-related organizations. It is a group devoted to developing leadership, providing service with compassion and maturity, and positively impacting university and national medical communities. We are a creative, diverse, and dynamic bunch, and love new members to jump in at anytime.
Summary: C.O.P.E. unites and empowers college students in their initiatives to fight cancer through public awareness, fundraising, and patient support (volunteering) for a variety of cancer-related organizations. It is a group devoted  to developing leadership,

Name: Cornerstone Anglican Church
Description:
Encountering Christ with boldness & humility.
Growing in faith through life together.
Inviting all to God's table.
Committed to love.

We meet every Sunday morning at 10 am in the Great Room

We seek to demonstrate Christ’s love through relationships, to unite and build up believers in their faith, and to deliver the gospel to Northwestern and the wider North Shore community.  In addition to weekly Sunday morning worship services, Cornerstone Anglican Church provides a place of fellowship and edification for Christians through Bible studies, prayer meetings, discipleship, and retreats. 

At Cornerstone Anglican Church, we provide the support base needed for effective ministry, loving community, and transformative worship as we deliver His love and message of hope to all those around us. We need your help in building Christ’s Kingdom!

Read more on our website. 

Find us on campus!
Summary:
Encountering Christ with boldness & humility.
Growing in faith through life together. 
Inviting all to God's table. 
Committed to love.

We meet every Sunday morning at 10 am in the Great Room.

(Formerly Church of the Redeemer)

Name: Council on Chinese Affairs
Description: We provide a platform for all the students and scholars from Northwestern University to discuss and explore issues on current economic, political and cultural situations, as well as to catalyze further understanding of business and economy relations between China and other countries. We bring in professors and professionals of diverse backgrounds and fields to share opinions and develop cross-border understanding on contemporary China.
Summary: We provide a platform for all the students and scholars from Northwestern University to discuss and explore issues on current economic, political and cultural situations, as well as to catalyze further understanding of business and economy relations

Name: Crossword Club
Summary: Just your local crossword crazies. Our focus is building a community on campus for meeting new folks and having fun with crosswords. We also contribute weekly crosswords in the Daily Northwestern.

Name: Crossword Team
Description: Northwestern Crossword Team (NUXW) is the premier crossword team on campus. We are a co-ed team equally focused on improving our crossword skills and building a friendly, supporting community on campus. We work to facilitate a welcoming environment for students while also completing crosswords together. Meetings take place Monday nights, and application opportunities will be available at the beginning of each quarter. Students of all crossword abilities are welcome to apply!
Summary: NUXW is a co-ed team equally focused on improving our crossword skills and building a friendly, supporting community on campus.

Name: Cru
Description:
What is Cru about?

 

Real faith. Real relationships. Real life.

 

Northwestern Cru is a community where the gospel captures hearts, transforms lives, impacts the world and launches men and women into a lifelong adventure with Jesus Christ. We’re glad you’re here. In short, we are about students becoming world changers. God has you in one of the most exciting places of your life—the campus. Unlike any other place (or likely any other time in your life) the world is literally all around you. Take a look around you, I’m willing to bet that within a few minutes of where you’re sitting right now you can meet someone from a different country, a different culture, and a different family setting than your own. And you may not be able to see it right now, but within a number of years these very people that you are sitting around in class and living next to right now in your dorm, house or apartment building will be people who give shape to the culture, the community, the nation and the world! The campus is a pretty amazing place!

 

What’s more, amidst this amazing setting we see that God is doing something big on the campus. Have you ever been confused about God? Have you ever felt disconnected from Him? Have you ever wondered if he was really real at all? Or maybe you believe that He is there, but you just don’t feel close to Him or you are trying to figure out this faith thing. Well, our experience tells us that these are common questions for today’s generation—and for those who wonder, more are discovering something real and fresh in a personal relationship with God! In fact if you’ve ever wondered some of these things,take a few minutes now and email one of us. We may not have all the answers but would love to hear your story.

 

Cru is a movement of people across the globe that are growing in and helping others grow in a personal relationship with God–one filled with increasing purpose, hope, honesty, & intimacy. So why did you come to college? What will you leave with? What’s your purpose in life? We hope that you’ll find us, find God, and find the adventure that is waiting for you!

 

If you are curious about this relationship with God, or want to learn more about Christianity a great resource is Knowing God Personally from EveryStudent.com
Summary:
What is Cru about?
Real faith. Real relationships. Real life.
Northwestern Cru is a community where the gospel captures hearts, transforms lives, impacts the world and launches men and women into a lifelong adventure with Jesus Christ.

Name: CURE
Description: We work in small, interdisciplinary teams to research new solutions to healthcare problems with the help of faculty and professionals from Northwestern and beyond. The teams compete to create the best solutions before presenting their results at a final symposium in the spring. CURE provides a collaborative, peer-led environment for students to get involved in cutting-edge research.
Summary: CURE (Competition for Undergraduate Regenerative Engineering) is an engineering student research group designed to tackle medical challenges with regenerative engineering solutions. We use model wound systems and hands-on methods for applicable research.

Name: Cycling
Description: Northwestern Cycling is a co-ed club sport open to both undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy riding their bicycles. The team organizes group rides of varying distance and speed throughout the year and competes in the Midwest Collegiate Cycling Conference for road races in the spring. Visit www.northwesterncycling.com for more information!
Summary: Northwestern Cycling is a co-ed club sport open to both undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy riding their bicycles. The team organizes group rides of varying distance and speed throughout the year and competes in collegiate races in the spring.

Name: Dale Duro Latin Dance Company
Description: Dale Duro Latin Dance Co. (DDLDC), Northwestern’s Latin dance team, is an inclusive dance group started in 2018 composed of Latin culture appreciators of all backgrounds and skill levels. We teach free workshops of varied Latin dance styles throughout each quarter, host community bonding events like karaoke nights and movie nights, and perform in our BIG annual spring show where we showcase our talents in salsa, bachata, merengue, flamenco, cumbia, reggaeton and more. We hope to continue fostering a supportive environment where we can all grow as Latin dancers, all while enriching and strengthening our perspective on Latin culture.
Summary: Dale Duro is looking to create an inclusive community for all students searching to enrich their appreciation for Latin culture through dance.

Name: Dead City Productions
Description:
Dead City Productions is a group of Northwestern students, alumni, and their guests who participate in various types of gaming in the form of live-action roleplaying, strategic board-gaming, and other entertaining games.  We are open to anyone willing to participate — no experience necessary!

Live-action roleplaying, or LARPing, is ideal for gamers as well as actors who enjoy the more improvisational side of acting.  Dead City Productions' LARP takes place in the form of a continuing, 10-game-long story occurring roughly every other week.  We also occasionally host one-shot games, in which a story begins and is resolved in the course of one evening-long game session.  All of our games are run using White Wolf's Vampire: The Requiem system, which is sometimes supplemented with other White Wolf systems depending on the needs of the storytelling team.

Additionally, DCP includes a board-gamers' group.  Every Monday at 7 PM, we gather in the north side of the Norris ground-floor cafeteria to play board games.  A wide variety of games are brought in every week — from card games to strategy games to anything in between — and anyone is welcome to bring a game to play or simply join in the fun!

DCP has also recently begun running quarterly Tabletop RPG nights, where anyone can volunteer to run a tabletop game, and others can sign up to play! GMs can choose their system, and most games are newbie-friendly and open to anyone!

Visit our website at deadcityproductions.com to learn more about us and keep up-to-date with announcements! We also have a Facebook group at facebook.com/dcpnu! If you would like to receive email reminders about Dead City Productions, contact us at exec@deadcityproductions.com and we can add you to our listserv as well.
Summary: Dead City Productions is a group of Northwestern students, alumni, and their guests who enjoy live-action roleplaying, strategic board-gaming, and other forms of gaming. We are open to anyone interested in participating \u2014 no experience necessary!

Name: Dead Pancreas Society
Summary: TBA

Name: Deeva
Description: Deeva is a nationally-recognized, all-female competitive dance team that blends the best of Indian classical, Bollywood, folk, ballet, lyrical, and hip-hop. Founded in 2001, the team has a unique mission: to generate and participate in an intercultural dialogue through dance. Each dancer brings a unique background from the diverse regions of South Asia and knowledge of a variety of dance styles from all over the world. By choreographing dances that mix cultures, Deeva is excited to not only bring increased cultural awareness to the student body, but to have a cultural exchange through dance.
Summary: Deeva is a nationally-recognized, all-female competitive dance team that blends the best of Indian classical, Bollywood, folk, ballet, lyrical, and hip-hop, founded in 2001.

Name: Delta Chi
Description:
Originally founded as a law fraternity in 1890, Delta Chi made its first appearance at Northwestern in 1893. The transition from a law fraternity to a general membership fraternity forced the Northwestern chapter to close in the 1920s, only to recolonize in 1997. While the chapter house is located across the street from the fraternity quad (Next to Elder Residence Hall, on the west side of Sheridan Road), the brothers of Delta Chi take pride in being a unique. The Delta Chi is a fraternity that is not looking for a certain "type" of individual. Rather, Delta Chi is made up of a diverse group of students who take pride in their chapter and enjoy everything it has to offer. As a chapter, we:

-Have teams in Dance Marathon and Relay for Life 

-Host our major philanthropy event, "Delta Chi Movers" benefitting our national charity, The V Foundation for Cancer Research. In Spring 2012, we raised almost $3,000 for cancer research!

-Play most intramural sports (Our favorites are floor hockey in the winter and softball in the spring)

-Are consistently above the all-men's average GPA. In Spring 2012, we also had the highest GPA among all Greek organizations. In Spring 2012, we had 18 men with GPAs of 3.75 or better!

-Are an inclusive community that prides itself on close brotherhood and genuine camraderie among its members.
Summary: Founded as a law fraternity in 1890, Delta Chi was established at Northwestern in 1893. The transition from a law fraternity to a general-membership fraternity forced the Northwestern chapter to close in the 1920s, but recolonized in 1997.

Name: Delta Sigma Pi
Description:
Delta Sigma Pi is Northwestern's premier co-ed business fraternity.  Our activities focus on three aspects: Professional, Social, and Community Service.

 We develop our members professionally through a wide range of activities and career related workshops.  Past events have included a pro-bono consulting panel with a top consulting firm, a stock competition (open to the entire NU community), guest speakers, site visits, and courses on resume building, interviewing, and networking. We also provide several leadership positions and a connection to the vast alumni base of the national organization.  

Through Delta Sigma Pi, you will develop lasting relationships with brothers who share a common interest. Our members form a community and support each other in professional and academic endeavors.  We hold several social events per quarter and perform community service in the Evanston/Chicagoland area.
Summary: As the world\u2019s leading professional fraternity for men and women, Delta Sigma Pi develops principled business leaders for the future by providing a lifetime of opportunity for members.

Name: Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc.
Description:
Theta Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed January 9, 1971

"Intelligence is the Torch of Wisdom."

Organization Facts

National founding date: January 13, 1913

Colors: Crimson, Cream

Nickname: Deltas

You may view the Delta Sigma Theta national website at http://www.deltasigmatheta.org.
Summary: The Theta Alpha chapter has been serving the Northwestern Community since January 9, 1971. Since that date, women of the Theta Alpha chapter have taken a vow to serve their Northwestern community using the same founding principles of the Sorority.

Name: Design for America
Description: Design for America (DFA) is an award-winning nationwide network of interdisciplinary student teams and community members using design to create local and social impact. DFA teaches human centered design to young adults and collaborating community partners through extra-curricular, university based, student led design studios to look locally, create fervently and act fearlessly. DFA currently tackles national challenges in Education, Health, Economy and Environment. We take applications for new projects every quarter! Email northwestern@designforamerica.com to get the application.
Summary: Design for America creates local and social impact through design. By organizing interdisciplinary groups of students and working in an extra-curricular setting, we tackle social challenges from a unique, creative perspective.

Name: Desire 2 Aspire
Description: Desire to Aspire is a mentorship program that focuses on serving girls and young women. Mentors visit the girls after school weekly for an hour and participate in a variety of activities that enhance problem solving skills, confidence, coping strategies, and more. Mentors also help plan fun field trips for the girls outside of weekly meetings.
Summary: A mentorship program working with local Evanston schools to build connections with young women and build them up for success.

Name: Destino
Description:
Destino is an ethnic ministry at Northwestern designed to be a safe space for Latinx-identifying students to continue or initiate a relationship with Jesus Christ. We explore Latinx Northwestern students' ethnic identity in the context of Christianity and want to build up Latinx leaders who will spread the Gospel to the world. We are a welcoming and loving community who seeks to guide Latinx students in their spiritual walk, while also helping students to create friendships and resources that enhance their experience and life at Northwestern University. We believe everyone's Destino (destiny) is to walk with God and thus our goal is to help anyone interested in attaining this wonderful gift of life. 

 

Get in contact: https://forms.gle/NwUMt2kddjU8hqoQA
Summary: A spiritual resource for Latinx-identifying Northwestern students seeking to know God and develop or enhance their relationship with Jesus. Our goal is to cultivate Latinx students' interest and faith in God.

Name: Develop + Innovate for Social Change
Description:
DISC started as a student group in 2017 with the goal of expanding Northwestern students' perceptions of the capabilities of technology. Since then, we've gathered a diverse group of student leaders interested in using technology to make a positive impact on the world. We recognize the power of collaboration across difference, and look for the right balance of technical and non-technical skills when we work together.

We do this by assembling project teams of hardworking students, and challenging them to grow as they work with community clients making an impact in the Evanston/Chicago area.
Summary: DISC has the goal of expanding Northwestern students' perceptions of the capabilities of technology. Since then, we've gathered a diverse group of student leaders interested in using technology to make a positive impact on the world.

Name: Developer Student Clubs
Summary: N/A

Name: Diversity in Biological Sciences
Summary: DIBS is an organization committed to fostering a community for underrepresented minorities (URM) and LGBTQ students within IBiS. This includes increasing resources for URM/LGBTQ students and advocating for an inclusive environment.

Name: Dolphin Show
Description: The Dolphin Show is a non-profit student theatre organization that annually produces America's largest student-produced musical. Having evolved from a swim team fundraiser in the 1940's to an annual professional-caliber musical production, The Dolphin Show celebrates the diverse talents of the Northwestern University undergraduate community by providing opportunities to learn and excel in all artistic and administrative fields of non-profit theatre. The Dolphin Show additionally involves the greater Chicago area communities through outreach programming. Successful Dolphin Show Alumni include actors David Schwimmer, Warren Beatty and former Miss America Kate Shindle.
Summary: The Dolphin Show is a non-profit student theatre organization that annually produces the nation's largest student-run musical.

Name: Driskill Graduate Student Council
Summary: The DGP Student Council brings the concerns of students to the DGP administration and fills programming gaps in the areas of mentoring, social and research activities.

Name: Elder Residential Community
Description: Elder Residential Community is on north campus and houses 345 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This building is available only to first-year students.
Summary: Elder Residential Community is on north campus and houses 345 students in mostly double-occupancy and a very limited number of single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women live in separate wings of the same floor. This

Name: Engelhart
Description: Engelhart Hall apartments are open to all Northwestern graduate students, their partners and families. Engelhart amenities are tailored to meet the needs of its students and their families during their stay at no additional cost, unlike most other off campus apartment complexes. The Graduate Housing Assistants and on-site staff are dedicated to providing a supportive environment that fosters friendship and professional’s connections for students. With several different apartment sizes and options – twin studio, single studio, two bedroom shared living room, one bedroom or family two bedroom – Engelhart is sure to meet the diverse needs of the student population that resides there. Engelhart hall is conveniently located close to downtown Evanston near restaurants, banks, stores and public transportation. Additionally, Engelhart Hall is only blocks away from campus and academic buildings.
Summary: Engelhart Hall apartments are open to all Northwestern graduate students, their partners and families.

Name: Engineering World Health Northwestern University
Description: EWH NU is part of a larger national organization that is headquartered in Chapel Hill, NC and is comprised of about 50 chapter worldwide. EWH works with university-based biomedical engineers, industry professionals, charities that manage donated medical equipment, the international health community and developing countries to combine innovation in appropriate technology with direct support to medical technology management, maintenance and repair. To learn more visit www.ewh.org
Summary: EWH NU seeks to inspire and mobilize students to improve the quality of healthcare in vulnerable communities. It provides members of NU EWH with the opportunity to repair, build, and learn about medical devices in the developing world.

Name: Engineers for a Sustainable World
Description:
CLICK MEET ONLINE TO JOIN US FOR THE ORG FAIR TODAY!!!

 

Engineers for a Sustainable World (ESW-NU) is an action-based group, mobilizing students through education, training, and hands-on projects related to environmental sustainability. Membership is not limited to engineers, but rather includes students from all schools at Northwestern, and entails working in student teams with faculty and professional advisers to further sustainability both locally and internationally. Our projects range in focus from renewable energy to urban agriculture, environmental technology, and much more. For more information, please contact us at contact.eswnu@gmail.com!
Summary: ESW empowers students to take on leadership roles in applying the principles of sustainability to their present and future work through action-based engineering projects and the education of ourselves and our community on sustainability topics.

Name: Engineers Without Borders
Description:
Engineers Without Borders-Northwestern works cooperatively with international communities to add engineering expertise to community-driven projects that address the community's most prevalent problems. Members of EWB-NU work throughout the academic year to brainstorm, research, survey, design, and prototype solutions to these problems, while working closely with a group of professional engineering mentors, an NGO, and most importantly, the partner community. These designs range from household necessities, to sanitation needs, to civil works, and beyond. Approximately once a year, EWB-NU sends a group of students and mentors to the community we work with to conduct further research and/or implement a phase of the project while building relationships with the members of the community.

EWB-NU also engages with the Northwestern, Evanston, and Chicago communities in to promote sustainability, engineering education, and stronger bonds between Northwestern and our surrounding communities. We do this through regular on-campus events, mentorship of local Chicago middle schools, and our developing service projects. We are always looking to increase the outreach that we do, so if you have ideas or a connection you would like to make, please reach out!

EWB-NU welcomes students of all academic backgrounds who are interested working toward making a positive impact on the world. Students gain experience in project management and leadership, design, teamwork, cross-cultural communication, fundraising, and interdisciplinary problem solving.
Summary: The mission of EWB-NU is to engineer and implement solutions that enrich the lives of communities and meet basic human needs through the completion of educational and collaborative projects \u2014 both locally and abroad.

Name: Environmental Engineering Undergraduate Society
Description: The Environmental Engineering Undergraduate Society (EnvEUS) at Northwestern gives students the opportunity to meet other Environmental Engineering students, participate in career development events, and apply technical skills outside of the classroom.
Summary: EnvEUS fosters community within the Environmental Engineering department at Northwestern.

Name: EPIC
Description:
Sign up for EPIC's email list here: bit.ly/epicnu

Our website: https://epicatnu.com/

 

EPIC not only plans and creates amazing events and programs but also has internal teams that work on entrepreneurship focused projects and exposes students to the world of startups. Read below for brief descriptions on each team and/or program: 

General Membership: General membership is an opportunity for students to try out entrepreneurship in an open and supportive environment. They get exclusive access to EPIC events ranging from kick-ass speaker panels, design pop ups, product demos, and more. All internal and external EPIC members are also General Members.

Launch: Launch is a quarter-long student-led incubator program where you will learn everything from ideation to execution and turn napkin sketches into real, scalable businesses. Learn the ins and outs of an entrepreneurial mindset, then embark on an entrepreneurial journey (often for the first time) through an action-driven curriculum. Participants will form teams to start new companies that they build throughout the quarter, culminating in a Demo Day.  In the last 2 years we’ve helped 100+ students start over 25 new companies; you could be next.

Sprout: A week-long trip to the Bay Area with Workshops, Speakers, Site Visits, Networking, Startup Challenge, Food, Fun over Winter Break.
Summary: EPIC is Northwestern's interdisciplinary hub for entrepreneurship. From networking with alums and startup-building workshops, to our annual trip to Silicon Valley, to our accelerator, EPIC is the great starting place for entrepreneurship at Northwestern.

Name: Epic Movement
Description:
Epic Movement is a ministry of Cru, and shares in its mission to join God’s work of transforming lives of students and faculty, so that their hearts and lives are given to Jesus Christ.  As an ethnic focused ministry, Epic specifically focuses its resources, thinking, and training on transformation and mission among Asian Americans.  Epic shares in Cru’s statement of faith.

Mission: To bring the gospel of Jesus Christ to the world through Asian American students and faculty.

Vision: Asian American movements mobilized to take their place in God's redemptive mission.
Summary: Epic Movement is a Cru ministry, focused on reaching Asian American students and faculty through building Christ-centered movements that are culturally meaningful and significant.

Name: Equestrian Team
Description: We are Northwestern University's Club Equestrian Team. We train under Coach Meggie Cramer at On Course Riding Academy in Wauconda, IL.  We show on the IHSA circuit and focus on equitation, but it is not a requirement to show in order to be part of the team.  Members come from varying levels of experience and riding styles including hunter jumper, dressage, polo, and western. The average member rides in a group lesson (2-5 riders) with the team about once a week. We enjoy hanging out as a team through a variety of social and fundraising events on and off campus.
Summary: We are Northwestern University's Equestrian Team! We train under Coach Meggie Cramer at Red Coat Farm Riding Academy in Hawthorn Woods, IL.  We show on the IHSA circuit, and riders of all skill levels, including beginners, are welcome to join!

Name: Esports Club
Description:
A club for casual and competitive video gaming in the Northwestern community. Currently, there are regular meetings for League of Legends, Overwatch, and the Super Smash Bros. Series. While other franchises currently do not have regular meetings, there are plenty of ways to engage through Discord and through their respective games. If enough interest is expressed to have in-person meetings for game, they can easily be added.

Discord Invite: https://discord.gg/f5Hvydb (Join the Discord, it's where the vast majority of our events happen!)

Braden's (the President) Discord: Svobo#3780 (Feel free to DM me with any questions/concerns!)
Summary: A club for competitive and casual video gaming in the Northwestern community. Competitive includes, but is not limited to, League of Legends, Super Smash Bros., Overwatch, and CS:GO. Casual encompasses everything else people are interested in.

Name: Ethics Bowl
Description: Ethics Bowl strives to spark interest in and awareness of societal issues involving ethics on campus. The organization spurs debate, intellectual growth, and an enrichment of perspectives in the community through an analysis of cases and competition in the Intercollegiate Ethics Bowl.
Summary: Ethics Bowl strives to spark interest in and awareness of societal issues involving ethics on campus.

Name: Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium
Description:
The Northwestern Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium (ESG) began in 2010 as an informal group of graduate students who were studying different disciplines, but doing similar work in the field of ethnic studies, an interdisciplinary field “that starts from the assumption that race and racism have been, and continue to be, profoundly powerful social and cultural forces in American society and in modernity at large” (as described by the Ethnic Studies Department at UC Berkeley). Although students were in programs as varied as African Studies, African-American Studies, American Studies, Anthropology, Asian-American Studies, Communication Studies, History, Musicology, Performance Studies, Religion, Rhetoric, and Sociology, they were all connected by an interest in similar authors, theories, and methodologies.

The ESG was created to provide an intellectual and social home for interested graduate students. Our programming activities, such as our quarterly potlucks and end-of-the-year workshop, are geared toward helping students achieve personal and professional goals as it relates to their work as Scholars of Color and scholars working in ethnic studies.
Summary: The Northwestern Ethnic Studies Graduate Student Colloquium (NU ESG) provides an intellectual and social home for graduate students doing work in the field of ethnic studies.

Name: Evans Scholars
Description:
Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University
