Name: Lion Dance
Description: Lion dance is a form of ancient Chinese dance performed during traditional and cultural festivals, where a pair of performers would mimic a lion's movements in a lion costume. Believed to bring luck and good fortune, the performance combines elements of dance, martial arts, and theatrical story-telling. Our organization's purpose is to share this aspect of Chinese culture with the Northwestern community and provide an opportunity for interested students of any background to learn this unique dance.
Summary: Lion dance is a form of ancient Chinese dance performed during traditional and cultural festivals, where a pair of performers would mimic a lion's movements in a lion costume.

Name: Lipstick Theatre
Description: Lipstick Theater aims to produce dramatic works that are written by women playwrights, have strong women characters, have a largely women-based ensemble, and/or address women’s issues. Lipstick Theatre hopes to foster discussions about the role of women in the larger artistic community, at Northwestern and elsewhere.
Summary: A student theatre group dedicated to providing creative opportunities for women theatre artists and producing feminist works.

Name: Living in Color
Description:
-lives in color:
/l\u012bvz in \u02c8k\u0259l\u0259r/, origin - people of color
The term, lives in color, focuses on the heterogeneous, always fluid, lived experiences of us and other others...
Summary: tba

Name: Lovers & Madmen
Description:
"Lovers and Madmen have such seething brains, such shaping fantasies, that apprehend more than cool reason ever comprehends."-William Shakespeare (A Midsummer Night's Dream)

Lovers & Madmen is a student theatre group at Northwestern University that produces a full season of classical and classically-inspired works each year. We seek to serve the NU, Evanston, and Chicago communities with our Mainstage season, as well as other smaller-scale productions, readings, and events. We are also committed to outreach, educational programming, and keeping in touch with our alumni.

Lovers & Madmen is open to all who wish to participate. We encourage anyone interested, regardless of previous experience or skill level, to get involved!

The Executive Board takes on new members through petitions which occur in Fall and Spring. We select producers and directors for our season through petitions which happen in Spring. Positions on the Executive Board or as a producer or director are unfortunately limited and these petition processes are competitive. We always see far more wonderful, qualified people than we can accept.

One can also be involved in our productions as an actor (Audition with Early Fall, Winter, and/or Spring Generals) or as a production team member (Email our friendly producers). We also are interested in working with artists who have ideas for smaller-scale projects ("Special Events"). We accept and produce these ideas on a rolling basis based on the project's artistic merit, relevance to our season and mission, and what we have the resources for.

More information about L&M and our productions can be found on our Instagram or Facebook.
Summary: Lovers & Madmen is a student theatre group at Northwestern University that produces a full season of classical and classically-inspired works each year.

Name: Lumi Tutors
Description: tba
Summary: tba

Name: Lutheran Campus Ministry
Description:
LCMNU is a welcoming community experiencing, living, and sharing the love of God through scholarship, service, and faith.  LCMNU is a student-led ministry that welcomes all of God’s people regardless of race, color, national origin, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, parental status, marital status, disability, citizenship, or veteran status. As one of  180+ campus ministries of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA), LCMNU shares in the mission “to invite people in academic settings to engage more deeply with the teachings of Jesus Christ and the community that bears his name, so that they can discover and fulfill their vocation as disciples.”

We invite you to go to https://www.lcmnorthwestern.org/ to learn more about us, and we especially invite you to join us. During the fall 2020 quarter, we will worship at 11am every Sunday and gather every Wednesday at 7:00 pm for a brief evening prayer and 21theo, an educational hour focusing on Lenny Duncan's Dear Church and the ELCA's role in racial justice. All events will be virtual and hosted on Zoom. Welcome to LCMNU!
Summary: Lutheran Campus Ministry is a welcoming community experiencing, living, and sharing the love of God through scholarship, service, and faith.

Name: makenew
Description: [make]new aims to create a support network of Northwestern students from diverse backgrounds that can provide emotional and relational support for one another. College is a time of growth and change in which everyone experiences ups and downs; having a network of close personal relationships is crucial for the difficult patches. We hope to forge a community where lifelong friendships are formed. It is vitally important that we encourage honest conversations between students of all faith backgrounds, and many of our meetings will be focused on fostering open dialogue about God and Christianity, as well as other worldviews, faith, and values. Finally, we seek to create a space for Christian students to experience real growth in their faith as they interact with one another through day to day student life.
Summary: [make]new is a Christian fellowship where students of all backgrounds can experience close community and learn more about the Christian faith.

Name: Mariachi Northwestern
Description: Mariachi Northwestern is a student group that strives to expose Mariachi music and culture to our surrounding communities! We have performed at events ranging from Dillo Day to Google HQ and all over the Chicagoland area.  Any singer, violinist, guitarist, bass, or trumpet player is welcome to join us, no Mariachi background or Spanish language prerequisite necessary.
Summary: Northwestern's first and premier Mariachi group! Celebrating the culture and tradition of Mariachi music at NU. All NU students are welcome to join!

Name: MarketWatch
Description: MarketWatch is a student-led pre-professional group with a focus on researching various markets and financial instruments, in addition to conducting informational interviews with Northwestern alumni.
Summary: MarketWatch is a student-led group with a focus on researching various markets and financial instruments, in addition to conducting informational interviews with Northwestern alumni.

Name: Masculinity, Allyship, Reflection, Solidarity
Description: We are an all-masculine-identifying organization dedicated to ending rape culture and "restrictive masculinity" on campus through self-work & peer-led discussions. MARS is a space to be vulnerable, genuinely learn about yourself, build connections with others, and be an ally for those impacted by various forms of violence on campus. You will learn skills in teaching, leading discussions, and developing activities aimed at exploring how re-imagining rigid societal expectations of masculinity can help lessen acts of violence as well as improve overall well-being.
Summary: We are an all-masculine-identifying organization dedicated to ending rape culture & restrictive masculinity on campus through self-work & peer-led discussions. MARS is a space to be vulnerable, genuine, build connections & learn to support others.

Name: Masters in Engineering Management Student Advisory Board
Description: The Student Advisory Board for MEM is a group of MEM students that represent the student body. SAB hopes to foster community within MEM by hosting social events, increase relationships between MEM with other graduate programs, and to market the MEM brand. The greater goal is to increase the value of the MEM degree.
Summary: The Student Advisory Board for MEM is a group of MEM students that represent the student body.  SAB hopes to foster community within MEM by hosting social events, increase relationships between MEM with other graduate programs.

Name: Mayfest
Description: Mayfest is responsible for producing Dillo Day, the largest student-run music festival in the country, as well as a series of special events throughout spring quarter. The largest of these events are Mayfest's Battle of the Bands and Battle of the DJ's competitions, in which the winners of each event earn a slot to perform on the Main Stage at Dillo Day. We book A-list artists for our Main Stage and we collaborate with FMO, Northwestern's black student alliance, to book artists for our second stage - and it's all free to Northwestern students! We work year round to ensure that Dillo Day is safe, fun, and inclusive for everyone that is a part of the Northwestern and Evanston communities. Past artists include Daniel Caesar, Hippocampus, A$AP Ferg, Rico Nasty, Regina Spektor, Kendrick Lamar, Steve Aoki, Chance the Rapper, 2chainz, The Mowgli's, Anderson .Pakk, and ScHoolboy Q. This year's lineup coming soon!
Summary:
www.dilloday.com

Mayfest produces Dillo Day, as well as a series of special events throughout spring quarter. We book A-list artists for the largest student-run music festival in the country - and it's all free to Northwestern students.

Name: McCormick Graduate Leadership Council
Description:
The McCormick Graduate Leadership Council (MGLC) has three main goals:

  1. Build a graduate student community among the eight departments within the McCormick School.
  2. Organize social, academic, and professional activities
  3. Facilitate communication between McCormick graduate students and the McCormick Dean's office
Summary: The McCormick Graduate Leadership Council helps graduate students connect through networking, professional development and social events.

Name: McCormick Student Advisory Board
Summary: McCormick advisory board for undergraduate students.

Name: McManus
Description: Home to Sigma Alpha Iota (SAI), the music fraternity for women, 720 Emerson is located on south campus and houses 26 women in single and double rooms. Residents are close to Foster-Walker, Allison, and Willard for dining. Because this is special interest housing, priority is given to members of SAI.
Summary: Home to Sigma Alpha Iota (SAI), the music fraternity for women, 720 Emerson is located on south campus and houses 26 women in single and double rooms. Residents are close to Foster-Walker, Allison, and Willard for dining.

Name: Medical Makers
Description: The purpose of Medical Makers is to innovate, design, and build medical devices that serve unmet clinical needs. Medical Makers aims to help members learn the prototyping process and acquire technical skills in medical device design.
Summary: tba

Name: Medill Undergraduate Student Advisory Council
Description: MUSAC works to improve the student experience at Medill by listening to student feedback, organizing events and providing feedback on a number of initiatives. The council’s biggest event each year is the Student Showcase, where the best student work is displayed in the MTC Forum and Lobby for students, faculty and staff to enjoy.
Summary: The Medill Undergraduate Student Advisory Council is a selection of freshmen, sophomore, junior and senior Medill students that represents the undergraduate community to members of Medill's administration on work with them collaboratively.

Name: Mee-Ow Improv and Sketch Comedy
Description:
Founded in 1974, Mee-Ow Comedy is Northwestern University's premiere short-form comedy group combining sketch comedy, improv, and live music.  Mee-Ow has an impressive list of alumni, including Seth Meyers and Julia Louis-Dreyfus.  

Come audition for us, work with us, and check out our shows!  We can't wait to make something funny with you!
Summary: Founded in 1974, Mee-Ow is Northwestern University's premiere short-form comedy group combining sketch, improv and rock n' roll.

Name: Men's Basketball
Description:
The Northwestern Club Basketball Team has been competing against regional junior college and club teams for over 20 years. We serve as an outlet for the competitive desires of talented NU students and as a platform for exceptionally gifted players to make the next step up to the varsity team.

We are a proud member of the NCBBA league and play between 20 and 30 games a year. We also compete in several club tournaments throughout the season. Anyone interested in playing is welcome to attend our tryout generally held the first week of October. 

If you have any questions or would like to learn more about the team, please feel free to contact us at jaydenlogan2021@u.northwestern.edu
Summary: The Northwestern Club Basketball Team has been competing against regional junior college and club teams for over 20 years. We serve as an outlet for the competitive desires of talented NU students and as a platform for exceptionally gifted players

Name: Men's Club Lacrosse
Description:
MEN’S CLUB LACROSSE

The Men’s Club Lacrosse team is part of the Great Lakes Lacrosse League (GLLL). We play competitively against teams in and around the Chicago-land area. The fall season begins in September and runs to the end of October. The spring season begins in late March and extends to early May.

Games

We typically play anywhere between 4-6 games in the fall against teams in the Chicago-land area. The bulk of our schedule is in the spring which includes approximately 10-12 games during the regular season and a year-end bracket style tournament to determine the GLLL champions. We play all other teams in the “Chicago Division” of the GLLL: Northern Illinois, Western Illinois, University of Chicago, Lake Forest College, and Loyola University. We also play teams in the Central (e.g. University of Wisconsin – Madison) and Eastern (e.g. Notre Dame, School Craft) division during the regular season. We will occasionally travel on away games for regular season competition and the year-end tournament which is hosted on a rotating basis.

Practices

In the fall, we are scheduled to practice three times a week, as well as opportunities for group fitness. We stress the importance of coming to practice, so please try to arrange your class schedule around practice times. Practice times will be in the evenings usually from either 7-9pm or 8-10pm.

In the winter, we reserve a two hour block in the University’s indoor turf facility. The format for this time block is more flexible that in the fall and spring. At times, we practice. Other times we devote the time to the development of specific skills and non-contact drills.

In the spring, we are scheduled to practice two times a week, reserving the third and possibly fourth day of activity for competition. Attending practices in the spring is integral to success during competition. We encourage 100% participation in practice and other events in the spring. Practice times will be in the evenings usually from either 7-9pm or 8-10pm.

*Please note that the practice schedule may change according to our allocated field space and time each season.

Dues

All members are required to pay club dues, which are approximately $225. This is necessary to cover the league fees, referee fees, travel costs, apparel, and social events. The apparel provided by the Club for its members is: 1 reversible jersey, 1 pairs of shorts, and additional apparel will be made available trough the team shop (1 tee, 1 sweatshirt, and 1 pair of sweatpants). Members have an opportunity to order protective equipment (e.g. helmet, gloves) through the club at a discounted rate.

Tryouts

Practice will begin at the end of New Student week. We encourage players with any previous playing experience to join and truly welcome all to join. A percentage of the membership has not played lacrosse before arriving to Northwestern campus. In addition to playing lacrosse, the team arranges outings and gatherings in order to build a strong community for the players.

If you have any questions about the Men’s Lacrosse Club, please contact us at coletingley2022@u.northwestern.edu.
Summary: The NU Men's Lacrosse Club welcomes all undergrads/grad students to join. Membership includes players with a wide range of skill from beginner to former NCAA athletes. We aim to have fun during practices and compete in the Great Lakes Lacrosse League.

Name: Men's Club Soccer
Description:
The NU Men's Club Soccer team is comprised of student athletes looking to continue playing competitive soccer without the restrictions and demands of a Varsity program during their undergraduate and graduate experiences. Our roster is brimming with talent, including former Varsity athletes and high school standouts, and we are exceptionally proud of the club's professionalism and level of play. In the past, our club finished twice in the Top 10 in the nation, we are extremely excited to continue to build on the club's recent successes.

Our fall season consists of 10 regular season games against other teams in the Western division of the Midwest conference. Pending qualification, the Midwest regional tournament takes place in late October, and the national tournament takes place in mid-November. With practices two times a week and games on the weekend, the season is fast-paced and demands a sizable commitment, but does not conflict with class time.

The informal winter season consists of one practice a week at the University's state-of-the-art indoor sports facility, including participation in an indoor league that plays once a week in Chicago. Our spring season, though less formal than the fall season, generally consists of about 8 games, including a weekend away for a tournament--the past two trips have been to Ohio State and Michigan State.

THIS YEAR, TRYOUTS WILL BE SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 22TH AND MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 23RD FROM 9 - 11 AM BOTH DAYS. THEY WILL BE LOCATED ON LONG FIELD, WHICH IS DIRECTLY NORTH OF ELDER. PLEASE SHOW UP ABOUT 30 MINUTES EARLY TO WARM UP AND BRING BOTH A LIGHT AND DARK SHIRT. Additional tryouts will occur depending on if a player is asked to return the following day. The roster tends to come in at around twenty-five to thirty athletes, and club members will be expected to pay a specified amount in team dues at the beginning of the season.

We practice and play our home matches at the fantastic Lakeside Field on the shore of Lake Michigan, and travel within the region to all of our away matches.

Although we are committed to success on the pitch, the very fabric of NU Men's Club Soccer is our committment to commraderie. Playing for the club is an awesome opportunity to continue to play competitive soccer, and provides a close-knit community for incoming students at the beginning of the academic year.
Summary: The NU Men's Club Soccer team is comprised of student athletes looking to continue playing competitive soccer without the restrictions and demands of a Varsity program during their undergraduate and graduate experiences.

Name: Men's Ice Hockey
Description: We are Northwestern's Men's Club Hockey Team. We practice twice a week on Monday and Wednesday. We usually play 2 games a weekend, 3 weekends a month during fall and winter quarter; we travel to about half of our games. We are affiliated with the ACHA. To see more please visit http://northwesternhockey.org/
Summary: We're NU's Club Hockey Team. We practice on Monday and Wednesday. We usually play 2 games a weekend, during fall and winter quarter; we travel to about half of our games. We're affiliated with the ACHA. Please visit http://northwesternhockey.org/

Name: Men's Rugby Football Club
Description:
Originally founded in the spring of 1972, the Northwestern University Men's Rugby club is a competitive Collegiate Division II rugby club in the National Collegiate Rugby organization.

Northwestern Men's Rugby's main season is during the fall, where it competes against teams such as Western Illinois, Eastern Illinois, Illinois State, Loyola, University of Chicago, etc. The squad, consisting of players with high levels of prior experience in rugby to players who have never heard of rugby, welcomes all players to join if they are interested in pursuing an active and new sport at the collegiate level.

Northwestern Rugby also competes during the spring, playing several Chicago area rivals as well as out-of-league squads. Northwestern Rugby are the 2007 CARFU Champions, the 2008 CARFU Runner-ups, and the 2009 CARFU Champions. More recently, NURFC finished the fall 2016 season as CARFU Champions and WISCARFU Championship Finalists. Additionally, Northwestern won the Chicago Cup in 2017. The team also competes every year in the Big Ten Sevens Tournament.

If interested please contact Marc Worden (President) at marcworden2022@u.northwestern.edu, or at the official NU Men's Rugby email address, nu.mensrugby@gmail.com. Feel free to visit our official Facebook page seen below for up to date practice and team information.
Summary: Originally founded in the spring of 1972, the Northwestern University Men's Rugby club is a member of the NCR organization. Follow us on Facebook and Instagram for event information.

Name: Men's Ultimate Frisbee
Description:
Northwestern Ultimate Team.

We are a team of friends and brothers that work hard and play hard together. We practive 2-3 times a week and attend 6-8 tournaments over the calendar year, competing in USA Ultimate's Division 1 College Series.

Our team values are borrowed from Revolver out of San Francisco. These values can mean different things to each player at each practice or tournament. These values ground us and allow us to improve every day as players, teammates, and men.

I = Intensity: We play hard at practice, in scrimmages, and at tournaments.
 
H = Humility: We respect our teammates, our opponents, and the game. We don’t cheat to win, and we don’t put ourselves above the team.
 
D = Discipline: We show up whether we want to or not. We work out and make sure our bodies are healthy and ready to compete.

Some words from Chucktown (NUT ’03, Coach ’12-’13):

  • Learn how to play the right way and how to be the man you want to be in the world. The winning, the fulfillment of your hopes and dreams: it all comes in time. We can’t control when or where it comes. We can control how we show up and how much we choose to believe in the process. We CAN buy in.

Email captains@nutultimate.com or check nutultimate.com for updates from the top.

 

Best,

Captains
Summary: Northwestern Men's Club Ultimate team.

Name: Men's Volleyball
Description:
Do you have high school varsity or club volleyball experience and want to continue playing at a high level in college? Northwestern Men's Club Volleyball is an opportunity for students to do just that. In the midst of COVID-19, we practice twice a week and plan to compete in matches and tournaments once it is safe to do so. We are a member of MIVA (Midwest Intercollegiate Volleyball Association) and annually compete against Big 10 teams at various tournaments throughout the Midwest.

---

Though we've concluded our normal tryouts, we're always open to new players joining the team.  If you'd like to tryout, please fill out the following form and reach out to us at the email/number below.

---

Join our men's volleyball team if you’re looking for thrilling competition and great brotherhood!
Summary: NU Men's Volleyball is an opportunity for players who played competitive volleyball in high school at the club/varsity level to continue playing on a high-level team with multiple matches and tournaments each quarter.

Name: MENA Student Association
Description: TBA
Summary: TBA

Name: Menstrual Equity Activists
Description:
Our goals and 3 pillars:

1. Service: provide free, safe, and accessible menstrual products to Evanston service partners such as homeless shelters, free clinics, food pantries, LGBTQI+ resource centers, domestic violence shelters, and other non-profits that distribute products, in order to fulfill the needs of our community.

2. Education: educate our local community on menstrual health through 2 programs

  • PERIOD TALK strives to facilitate conversations around periods and empower menstruators and non-menstruators to advocate for period health. 
  • Cup & Cloth is a workshop centered around menstrual equity through the promotion of reusable and sustainable menstrual hygiene products. It covers how to clean and care for your menstrual cup, as well as tools to drive conversation around the intersection between period health and climate change.

3. Policy: aim to advocate for systemic change through policy and legislation regarding menstrual equity. Reaching out to state representatives, canvassing, and lobbying are all important in making period poverty a mainstream issue and one that our legislators will prioritize. Right now we are focusing on passing a bill to provide free menstrual products to homeless shelters statewide.

Our COVID-19 Response!

  • Identifying and delivering menstrual products to local shelters that are in need.
  • Sharing our petition on social media and talking to local legislators to pass a bill that will provide free menstrual products to homeless shelters statewide. Homeless menstruates are some of the most vulnerable people during this pandemic. 
    • Sign our petition here
  • Advocating for the SNAP bill in Illinois to cover menstrual products.

For the school year, we will be implementing a multitude of community initiatives within Northwestern and locally, led by our members!
Summary: We are a menstrual equity activism group focused on alleviating period poverty & period stigma through education, service & policy reform in Evanston and the state of Illinois.

Name: MENtal Health
Summary: MENtal Health combats stigma around mental health to the male population of NU. MENtal Health responds to gender discrepancies in use of mental health resources at NU. We aim to combat negative perceptions of masculinity that can lead to health issues.

Name: Mental Health Mix & Mingle
Description: Mental Health Mix and Mingle (MHMM) is a group for graduate students in the two programs housed within The Family Institute at Northwestern University (Counseling and Marriage & Family Therapy). The group is designed to bring together the students from both programs in social, professional, and educational events to foster connections and relationships among peers.
Summary: Mental Health Mix and Mingle is a graduate student-based group that aims to connect the two graduate programs housed within The Family Institute (Counseling and Marriage & Family Therapy).

Name: Mentorship Opportunities for Research Engagement
Description: The organization provides opportunities for graduate students and postdocs, primarily in STEM (Science, Technology, engineering, and Math), to mentor high school students at local high schools who are pursuing independent research projects are who are generally interested in STEM. The goal of the organization is foster interest in STEM by connecting those in the field with students.
Summary: The organization provides opportunities for graduate students and postdocs, primarily in STEM (Science, Technology, engineering, and Math), to mentor high school students at local high schools.

Name: MEOR
Description:
Meor Northwestern is a campus-based organization dedicated to extending Jewish learning opportunities to the broadest spectrum of Jewish students at Northwestern University. Through timely classes, lively discussions, transformative trips and other programming, our goal is to inspire a life-long love affair with Jewish learning and living. Further, we encourage the development of a vibrant, tolerant campus community in which every Jew is welcomed and valued.

Meor Northwestern recognizes that Jewish growth is a perpetual process, and that each student, emerging from his or her unique Jewish background, must develop at his or her own pace. We are committed to offering guidance and opportunities at each step of a student’s personal Jewish journey.
Summary: Meor Northwestern is a campus-based organization dedicated to extending Jewish learning opportunities to the broadest spectrum of Jewish students at Northwestern University. Through timely classes, lively discussions, transformative trips and other

Name: MiniChefz
Description: MiniChefz is a non-profit organization comprised of college students. We have worked together to develop a curriculum based around nutrition, healthy eating, and a healthy lifestyle. Our volunteers dedicate themselves to improving their cooking skills and learning the curriculum in order to travel into neighboring communities and work with the youth population in order to help encourage healthier life choices. Nutrition is a key component to a healthy life. Our goal is to create healthy eating habits for youth in order to prevent many of the health issues that arise in adulthood.
Summary: MiniChefz is an organization that looks to encourage healthy eating and nutrition among the youth of our city.

Name: Minority Association of Pre-Med Students at Northwestern
Description: The purpose of MAPS is to serve the minority pre-health students of Northwestern University, by providing valuable information that pre-health students need, prior to attending medical or graduate school, through meetings, workshops, events, etc. This organization works diligently to try to stimulate the interests, of pre-health students at Northwestern University by encouraging and promoting all minorities in medicine and other health professions. As the representative voice of Northwestern’s minority pre-health students, MAPS seeks to instill a consciousness in its members about contemporary issues and disparities of the medical world, especially those that pertain to minority groups. MAPS aims to prepare its members for the rigors of their health and science careers in an efficient manner.
Summary: The purpose of MAPS is to serve the minority pre-health students of Northwestern  by providing valuable information that pre-health students need, prior to attending medical or graduate school, through meetings, workshops, events, etc.

Name: MIXED Student Association
Description: Multiracial Identity Xperience Education and Dialogue (MIXED) Student Association, was founded in 2013 as the Mixed Student Coalition and renamed MIXED Student Association in 2020. MIXED was founded to provide a space for those who identify with a multiracial background or have interest in mixed race affairs. MIXED serves to create an inclusive community for people of all racial/ethnic backgrounds by hosting fun activities as well as generating discussions and bringing in speakers with an emphasis on the multiracial experience.
Summary: MIXED serves to create an inclusive community for people of all racial/ethnic backgrounds by hosting fun activities as well as generating discussions and bringing in speakers with an emphasis on the multiracial experience.

Name: Mock Trial
Description: Northwestern Mock Trial (NUMT), 9th-place finishers at Nationals the past two seasons, competes against the top programs across the nation in simulated trial tournaments where participants are scored for their advocacy skills as lawyers and performance as witnesses. The program offers team members the opportunity to improve their public speaking abilities, analytical skills, trial advocacy techniques and acting capabilities while experiencing the drama of a courtroom. Mock Trial is perfect for those who are competitive, enjoy public speaking or love to act. We take new members from all experience levels-- more than half of our members joined with no mock trial experience--and majors, whether you're interested in the law or just love performing in front of others. No matter your interests, there's a spot for you on NUMT!
Summary: NUMT competes against the top programs across the nation in simulated trial tournaments where participants are scored for their advocacy skills as lawyers and performance as witnesses.

Name: Moneythink
Summary: Moneythink sends Northwestern students to visit various high schools in the Chicagoland area weekly. There, we educate dozens of under-resourced students in essential financial skills, preparing them for college life and beyond.

Name: Morning Mentors
Summary: Morning Mentors aims to develop the graduate community by providing an opportunity for community service and bringing together students of different departments with similar goals and interests by facilitating a tutoring program for a local school.

Name: Mortar Board
Summary: Mortar Board is the premier national honor society for students of senior standing that recognizes superior achievement in scholarship, leadership, and service.

Name: Multicultural Filmmakers Collective
Description: The purpose of the Multicultural Filmmakers Collective is to nurture, promote, and ally multicultural student filmmakers at Northwestern University, as well as support student films that present multicultural concerns and experiences. We define multicultural as including, but not limited to, underrepresented races, ethnicities, religions, genders, sexual orientations, and socioeconomic statuses. In addition to general meetings, our programming includes film screenings, script workshops, and speaker events.
Summary: The purpose of the Multicultural Filmmakers Collective is to nurture, promote, and ally multicultural student filmmakers at Northwestern University, as well as support student films that present multicultural concerns and experiences.

Name: Multicultural Greek Council
Description: The MGC is a unique community of fraternities and sororities; each of these member organizations’ foundations is founded upon celebrating cultural diversity and educating the community about its rich cultural heritage.  The MGC and the Greek-letter organizations are powerful media through which group members can express and share their cultural pride.  The members cherish the belief that the college experience is more valuable when it includes self-expression through the richness of diversity.
Summary: The MGC is a unique community of fraternities and sororities; each of these member organizations' foundations is founded upon celebrating cultural diversity and educating the community about its rich cultural heritage.

Name: Multicultural Student Affairs
Description: Multicultural Student Affairs is committed to fostering an inclusive environment that promotes identity development, intercultural exchange, academic excellence, and leadership. While our departments primarily focus on traditionally under-served student populations, we strive to play an important role in creating an institutional climate that values diversity and educates the Northwestern community about cultural competence and social justice.
Summary: Multicultural Student Affairs is committed to fostering an inclusive environment that promotes identity development, intercultural exchange, academic excellence, and leadership. While our departments primarily focus on traditionally under-served student

Name: Muskwa Club Northwestern Chapter
Description:
Our organization is one of over 75 Muskwa chapters and locations nationwide. Muskwa was originally founded by students in 2010, and has since grown into an international, federally-recognized non-profit organization. Our four-year-long effort to save the endangered vaquita porpoise is by far our biggest project, but we also conduct other activities including educational field trips, fun and family-friendly social events, and engineering projects. Our chapter focuses on education and engineering solutions for the vaquita.

    Since 2012, Muskwa has directly educated over 18,000 people at 50 awareness events across the United States and abroad. We are also highly active through social media; our coalition's petition to permanently remove lethal gillnets from the vaquita's range has accrued over 94,000 signatures.
Summary: Our mission is to save the vaquita porpoise, which is the world's most endangered marine mammal. We accomplish our mission through public outreach and engineering projects.

Name: Muslim-cultural Students Association
Description: The Muslim-cultural Students Association (McSA) is a community oriented organization that caters to the many different needs of Northwestern students. Our members are Muslim and non-Muslim alike. Even with such a diverse membership, our fundamental goals remain the same. Be it Discover Islam Week, philanthropy food drives, Ramadan dinners, or simply tutoring younger students, our primary motive is to promote the human values that Islam emphasizes: community, equality, justice, mercy, compassion and peace. In addition, by supporting other organizations or events, we hope to foster unity not only in McSA, but also among other NU student organizations, faculty and administrators.
Summary: The Muslim-cultural Students Association (McSA) is a community oriented organization that caters to the many different needs of Northwestern students. Our members are Muslim and non-Muslim alike. Even with such a diverse membership, our fundamental goals

Name: National Association of Black Journalists
Description:
The National Association of Black Journalists serves as a resource and outlet for graduate and undergraduate students interested in pursuing a career in mass communications and journalism.
As an auspice, the Northwestern chapter seeks to uphold an organic atmosphere and community in which all of our members can grow professionally and personally. NABJ-NU also creates opportunities for students to develop meaningful relationships, harness impressive skills and build confidence in their careers.
NABJ welcomes students who are majoring in journalism and also those who are not.
Summary: The NU Chapter of the National Association of Black Journalists is an organization of students seeking to provide quality programs and services to aspiring black journalists. The organization serves to strengthen the ties among black journalists.

Name: National Pan-Hellenic Council
Description:
The National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC) at Northwestern University consists of seven of the "Divine Nine" historically black fraternities and sororities. Each of the NPHC organizations evolved during a period when African Americans were denied essential rights and privileges afforded to other college students. NPHC organizations maintain high positive standards for its member organizations and ensure the perpetuation of responsibility and privilege through engaging in service to the African American community at NU and the community at large.

 

The 2020-2021 Council of Presidents Executive Board:

Soteria Reid - President

Kamaryn Johnson - Vice President

Akwasi Boachie - Secretary

Chelsea Franklin - Treasurer

Rome McGhee - PR Director
Summary: The National Pan-Hellenic Council, Inc. (NPHC) at Northwestern University consists of seven of the "Divine Nine" historically black fraternities and sororities.

Name: National Residence Hall Honorary
Description: NRHH strives to provide recognition for individuals who have contributed to the advancement of college and university housing. It ensures the advancement of member chapters through resource sharing, programming, and leadership development opportunities.
Summary: Northwestern University's chapter of the National Residence Hall Honorary

Name: National Society of Black Engineers - Northwestern Chapter
Description: The National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE)'s mission is to increase the number of culturally responsible black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally, and positively impact the community.
Summary: The National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE)'s mission is to increase the number of culturally responsible black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally, and positively impact the community.

Name: National Student Speech-Language-Hearing Association-NU
Description: The NU NSSLHA Chapter is a pre-professional association for graduate and undergraduate students interested in the study of communication sciences and disorders (CSD).  We are one of over 300 university chapters representing the greater national organization of NSSLHA, which is the only student organization recognized by the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA), the national professional, scientific, and credentialing association for the communication sciences and disorders.
Summary: The NU NSSLHA Chapter is a pre-professional association for graduate and undergraduate students interested in the study of communication sciences and disorders (CSD).

Name: Neuro Club
Description:
The Northwestern University Neuro Club brings together the diverse set of students interested in any of the numerous fields of Neuroscience. We hope this club will not only inform the Northwestern community of the many facets of Neuroscience but also centralize the resources of both of the Northwestern Campuses to give a well-organized structure for education in Neuroscience. We hope to accomplish these things through events, service projects, and other ways.

The Community Service Committee works with local Evanston and Chicago schools and organizations to plan community service events at least once per quarter. 

The Speaker Committee brings in (at least one) speaker from the field of Neuroscience per quarter.

The Public Relations Committee publicizes club events and helps recruit committed members who are willing to contribute to the organization.
Summary: The Northwestern University Neuro Club is a student organization with the goal of furthering the education and understanding of neuroscience and related fields within and surrounding the Northwestern University community.

Name: New Life Volunteering Society
Description:
New Life Volunteering Society is a non-profit volunteering organization for students from medical schools at CMS, UChicago, Northwestern, Loyola, and UIC and undergraduates from Northwestern, Loyola, and UIC. The NLVS organization has a clinic in Little India in the Devon neighborhood where medical and undergraduate students can volunteer. At Northwestern, we are a health-oriented volunteering club that helps serve the Chicago and local Evanston communities. Some of our initiatives include designing and presenting health series at homeless centers, tutoring, and volunteering at local community centers, retirement homes, and health clinics, such as the NLVS clinic.

NLVS members are also connected with the NLVS chapter at Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine and we sometimes hold events with them. Please contact us with any questions!
Summary: New Life Volunteering Society (NLVS) provides health-related service and leadership opportunities for Northwestern students.  We have ties to health clinics in the Chicago area, the Feinberg School of Medicine, and Evanston-based organizations.

Name: New Morning
Description:
This organization facilitates connections between students who have experienced a loss. 

In an effort to destigmatize and normalize grief, we provide a collective space for support, communication, and education. We seek to offer a ‘less heavy’ alternative arena (vs traditional therapy), that builds community amongst students who are at varying points in their grieving process with the hope of offering models/mentors of ‘vulnerability with resilience.’ We work to create an inclusive space that encourages students to share and remember their loved ones, as well as convene together in celebration to honor our beloved. We also endeavor to develop opportunities and events that can serve to educate our friends/networks in their efforts to support us in our grief journey.
Summary:
This organization facilitates connections between students who have experienced a loss. 
In an effort to destigmatize and normalize grief, we provide a collective space for support, communication, and education.

Name: New Movement Project
Description:
The objectives of New Movement Project (NMP) is to offer students support, resources, and programming with the goal to facilitate artistic discoveries and participation in the endeavors of other members, including those that reach beyond the university community.  NMP’s programming initiatives include producing the Fall Dance Concert, hosting guest artists for residencies & workshops -- including David Parker & The Bang Group (2009); Emily Johnson (2010); Cyrus Khambatta (2011) -- and sponsoring individuals’ own projects as they make discoveries through movement.

New Movement Project enriches and enhances the dance experience of all actively motivated members of the Northwestern dance community. New Movement Project utilizes its resources as well as departmental, university, and community partnerships to provide students with elements of the dance experience not regularly provided by the curriculum.
Summary: NMP's mission is to provide students with the resources and programming to support their artistic discoveries through dance by producing the yearly Fall Dance Concert, hosting guest artists for residencies and workshops, and supporting projects.

Name: New Student Organization Review Committee
Summary: This group meets quarterly to deliberate on proposals for new registered student organizations to be recognized.

Name: Nine Lives
Description:
Nine Lives Podcast shares true, unaltered stories from the Northwestern community with the general student body. Our purpose is to foster a sense of community through personal narratives that touch on universal topics. We offer a creative outlet for producers as well as a medium for the tradition of oral storytelling to thrive on campus.

Our stories range from the hilarious to the somber, the poignant to the absurd. What unites them is a reflection on the collective human experience. By joining our team or contributing a story of your own, you can add your voice to that narrative.

But most importantly, we wouldn’t have a podcast to produce if it weren’t for our contributors. Pitch us any story – as long as it’s true and it’s yours, it’s worth telling.

All 'Cats have Nine Lives, share one of yours!
Summary: Nine Lives Podcast shares true, unaltered stories from the NU community with the student body.

Name: Niteskool Productions
Description: Niteskool is the premier music management and video production group dedicated to finding and promoting the most talented musicians at Northwestern. We aim to bring these artists into the spotlight on campus and catapult them to success in the broader music industry. Niteskool Productions focuses on producing high-quality music videos to connect Northwestern students to their talented peers and provide otherwise unavailable opportunities to student musicians.
Summary: Niteskool Productions is the premier music management and video production group. Through highly professional student-produced music video content, Niteskool aims to expose Northwestern talent to the greater student body.

Name: Norris Box Office
Description: The Norris Box Office serves as a ticketing agent for student organizations holding accounts with the Student Organization Finance Office or a University department.  Services include ticket printing and sales (on-site and on-line), individual stamp and envelope sales (cash only), and domestic fax send/receive.
Summary: Northwestern University department within Student Affairs serving as primary ticket printing and sales agent for registered Northwestern University student organizations and departments. Located on the first floor of Norris University Center.

Name: Norris Cashier's Office
Description: The Cashier's Office works in conjunction with the Student Organization Finance Office to maintain a student organization banking structure that faciliates transaction-based requests.  It offers starting funds, depository and coin counting services, as well as notary services.
Summary: An office within the Cash Operations Area that offers deposit and starting fund services for student organizations.

Name: Norris Operations Staff
Description: Room set-ups, information desk, and Center Managers of the Norris University Center.
Summary: Norris Operations Staff student employee site.

Name: Norris University Center
Summary: Home to an array of services, resources, and meeting spaces, Norris University Center is the center of campus life at Northwestern community.

Name: North by Northwestern
Description:
North by Northwestern is one of Northwestern University’s best independent online publications, updated around the clock with stories about campus and culture. In Spring 2008, we launched a print magazine. Both online and off, we report the truth, tell stories and have fun.

We started over the summer of 2006 because we wanted to do online journalism and there was no place for it at Northwestern. This is a site where we can talk about what’s actually on our minds, share our passions and have a conversation with our readers.

We’ve been honored with 32 Mark of Excellence awards from the Society of Professional Journalists and won the 2008 National Online Pacemaker Awards.

North by Northwestern is proud to be a member of the Campus Progress journalism network.

Let us know if you want to get involved. We’re always looking for new writers, editors, photographers, videographers, multimedia producers, designers, social media managers, marketers and businesspeople.
Summary: North by Northwestern is one of Northwestern University's best independent online publications, updated around the clock with stories about campus and culture. In Spring 2008, we launched a print magazine. Both online and off, we report the truth,

Name: Northwestern A Cappella Community Alliance
Description: NACCA serves to provide organizational representation for all a cappella groups on Northwestern's campus. NACCA administrates auditions, preferences, and conferrals for all potential new members of the Northwestern A Cappella Community. They also plan and facilitate A Cappella Fest during Wildcat Welcome Week.
Summary: The governing body of Northwestern's 14 a cappella groups.

Name: Northwestern Anime Club
Description:
Welcome to NU Anime Club! Our group brings together students at Northwestern University for gatherings and events focused on all things Japan: anime, manga, video games and much more.

Check us out on Facebook and feel free to email us with questions! NU Anime Club FB 

Our group prides itself on having diverse interests and offering activities to promote them. Although each week you will find us meeting to watch the latest shows from Japan, we spend time as a group doing much more:

  • Art Group/Doujinshi Creation
  • Gunpla and Model Building
  • Video and Board Games
  • Karaoke
  • Cosplay and Lolita Fashion
  • Guest Speakers
  • Local Conventions
  • Group Trips
  • Theater Showings

Visit our site for more info!
Summary: Come enjoy Anime, Japan's unique style of animation, with NU Anime Club. Experience the wealth of genres and styles that Anime has to offer and talk about it with us!

Name: Northwestern Art Review
Description: The Northwestern Art Review is an academic organization based at Northwestern University that seeks to promote art historical discourses at the undergraduate level. By publishing an annual journal of art scholarship and critique, the Northwestern Art Review strives to provide a forum for greater exchange among an expanding community of students who devote their time to studying, thinking and writing about art. Additionally, the Northwestern Art Review serves as a dynamic force on campus and within the Chicago Area promoting art and creatively influenced events and programming.
Summary: The Northwestern Art Review is an academic organization based at Northwestern University that seeks to promote art historical discourses at the undergraduate level. By publishing an annual journal of art scholarship and critique, the Northwestern Art

Name: Northwestern Bhangra Dance Team
Description: Passion, dedication, and talent united to form Northwestern Bhangra in 2006. An enthusiastic co-ed university dance team known for its energy on and off the stage, the troupe performs bhangra, a traditional folk dance originating in the Indian state of Punjab. The team has performed at numerous campus events, imprinted its name all over the Chicagoland area, and entertained the bhangra community across the nation. Throughout the years, the team has performed at prestigious competitions such as Bhangra in the Bell, Bhangra Blowout, Bhangra in the Burgh, Nachte Raho, and many others. As they continue to inspire others with their dynamic style, the bhangra team shares and celebrates Punjabi culture with the Northwestern community. Northwestern Bhangra is a true family, and they always animate the stage with personality and originality while remembering their traditional roots.
Summary: Founded in 2006, Northwestern Bhangra aims to promote awareness of Punjabi culture through dance. Since our founding, we have grown into a team that performs at events all around the Chicagoland area and at competitions across the nation.

Name: Northwestern Career Advancement
Description: The mission of Northwestern Career Advancement (formerly University Career Services) is to foster excellence in career development, preparation, and professional opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students and alumni by providing comprehensive services and programming and by promoting strong partnerships with employers, academic departments, and the university community.
Summary: The mission of Northwestern Career Advancement (formerly UCS) is to foster excellence in career development, preparation, and professional opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students and alumni by providing comprehensive services.

Name: Northwestern Chinese Christian Student Fellowship
Description:
We are a group of Chinese students, scholars and local families united by the Christian faith. We share the gospel and study Bible every Friday evening on Evanston campus. Our door is open to all.

If you want to know us and need help from us, please come to us on Friday night (6:30PM -- 9:30PM).

Welcome!!
Summary: We are a group of Chinese students, scholars and local families united by the Christian faith. We share the gospel and study Bible every Friday evening on Evanston campus. Our door is open to all.

Name: Northwestern Club Swim Team
Description:
Northwestern Swim Club was founded in 2008 providing a club swimming opportunity for undergraduate students at Northwestern. We practice three to four times a week at Norris Aquatics Center at SPAC. We typically go to two to three meets a quarter. We host our annual home meet during the beginning of fall quarter. Our competition season ends with a trip to CCS Nationals in early April.

 

2019 Tryouts: 

Sunday, September 29 4-5:30pm @ Norris Aquatics Center in SPAC 

 

Practice schedule:

Fall quarter:

Tuesday: 8:30PM-10:00PM 
Saturday: 4:00PM-6:00PM 
Sunday: 4:00PM-6:00PM 

One dryland session (time TBD, it depends on club member's availability)

Winter/Spring quarter: 

Monday: 8:30PM-10:00PM 
Thursday: 8:30PM-10:00PM
Saturday: 4:00PM-6:00PM 
Sunday: 4:00PM-6:00PM 

One dryland session (time TBD, it depends on club member's availability)
Summary: Northwestern Club Swimming was founded in 2008 providing a club swimming opportunity for undergraduate students at Northwestern. We practice three to four times a week at Norris Aquatics Center at SPAC and attend meets throughout the year.

Name: Northwestern Community Development Corps
Description: Northwestern Community Development Corps (NCDC) is a student-run organization that seeks to engage students in community development at Northwestern University, in Evanston, and throughout Chicago. We promote civic engagement through direct service, social awareness, and advocacy. Utilizing existing skills, talents, and abilities, we strive to build mutually beneficial relationships, enriching both our campus and the communities, while forming a foundation for the future.
Summary: Northwestern Community Development Corps (NCDC) seeks to strength community through creating and maintaining mutually beneficial partnerships between and among Northwestern and its Evanston and Chicago neighbors.

Name: Northwestern Community Ensemble
Description: We are Northwestern's premier gospel choir founded in 1971 performing spiritual, gospel, and anthem music from the black Christian tradition. We seek to provide Northwestern's African American community as well as the broader Northwestern community opportunities to engage with Black culture, gospel music, and christian faith through our concerts and other performances.
Summary: We are Northwestern's premier gospel choir founded in  performing spiritual, gospel, and anthem music from the black Christian tradition.

Name: Northwestern Crew
Description:
Northwestern Crew is a co-ed club sport that competes with other club and varsity programs throughout the county. We are an active team throughout the entire year with our main seasons in fall and spring and indoor training in winter. Practices take place at the Dammrich Rowing Center in Skokie during fall and spring season and at the Henry Crown Sports Pavilion during winter season.

While learning to row/cox and working on technique and speed, novice (new) rowers and coxswains will participate in 1 - 2 races in fall and 3 - 4 races in spring. The team takes a spring training trip during Spring Break to prepare for spring racing in Oak Ridge, TN.

Novice practices will take place weekday mornings and on selected weekends at the coaches' discretion. Racing takes place on the weekends as well.

Experienced rowers and coxswains are welcome to practice and race at varsity level. All are welcome!

Please contact Abby Ekstrand: vwomenscaptain@northwesterncrew.com for all women’s team inquiries and Conrad Skala: vmenscaptain@northwesterncrew.com for all men’s team inquiries.
Summary: Northwestern Crew is a co-ed club sport that competes with other club and varsity programs throughout the county. We are an active team throughout the entire year with our main seasons in fall and spring and indoor training in winter.

Name: Northwestern Economics Tournament
Description:
The purpose of Northwestern Economics Tournament (NET) is to give high school students opportunities to explore the field of economics before entering college. This organization aims to introduce high school students to economics in a welcoming environment through competitions and interactive speaker events. NET also encourages the participation of Northwestern students, who plan and organize the event. 

We’re looking for students from all backgrounds who are passionate about economics and can think creatively about adapting NET to a new virtual environment for the 2021 Event.
Summary: We are a small group of Northwestern students who organize an annual economics tournament for high school students from the Chicago area and around the country.

Name: Northwestern Emergency Medical Organization
Description:
Details & the application for our Winter 2020 Basic Emergency Medical Technician (EMT-B) training course can be found here: https://tinyurl.com/nemo-app-2020. Applications have closed for this year! For the 2021-22 EMT-B Course, please check back in next fall. For more information and questions, please email nemo@u.northwestern.edu.

Northwestern Emergency Medicine Organization serves to promote a greater visibility for the broad-range applications of emergency medicine on campus and within the Greater Chicago area. Whereas other health organizations on campus attract pre-health students exclusively, NEMO teaches life-saving knowledge and skills to the entire Northwestern community.
Summary:
Interested in Emergency Medicine?
Want to learn more about how to deal with medical emergencies? We offer an EMT-B course and other opportunities to learn and teach life-saving knowledge to the NU community!

Name: Northwestern Energy Technology Group
Description: NETG organizes student seminars, guest lectures, movie nights, and social outings for students. Our events focus on themes of renewable energy, environmental protection, and resource management. We have 5-10 active officers, and we are continually recruiting new students to plan and execute events.  Please visit netg.northwestern.edu to join our listserv.
Summary: NETG aims to advance the research and development of sustainable energy technologies by providing educational and collaborative opportunities for Northwestern University students. Please visit netg.northwestern.edu to join our listserv.

Name: Northwestern Financial Wellness
Description:
Managing personal finance can be a daunting task. The Office of Undergraduate Financial Aid is committed to educating and empowering Northwestern students to make informed decisions about money management. The Financial Wellness website helps to equip students with the knowledge and resources to manage their finances at Northwestern and beyond. Topics include:

Money 101: The basics of financial literacy and personal finance, including budgeting, banking, and credit.

Financial Planning: Prepare for life after Northwestern with information about retirement planning, tax help, and more.

Student Loan Management: Information and resources about loan repayment

Saving in College: Browse money saving tips and discounts available to NU students.
Summary: We encourage students to plan for anticipated expenses, prepare a budget, and consider the impact their financial decisions will have on their credit.

Name: Northwestern Flipside
Description:
Free Everywhere, $2.30 Canada

Like The Onion ? The Daily Show? The Colbert Report? The Northwestern Flipside is a satirical publication and official student group at Northwestern University. Founded in 2008, we make ~1000 people laugh, chuckle, and smile to themselves daily. We publish articles and headlines online each day, with bi-weekly print issues and occasional video, radio, and magazine content. All are welcome to contribute in any capacity possible. You can write, act, edit, or just attend meetings to throw out some topics or ideas. Come participate in one of the most fun groups on campus!

The Northwestern Flipside is a member of the Flipside News Network, which includes other satirical publications such as The Stanford Flipside, The USC Flipside, The Feinberg Flipside, The Deerfield Flipside, The Mizzou Flipside, The Flipside International and The NorShore News.

All names and quotes are made up unless a public figure is being satirized. Remember, these are all jokes.

 

Contact

If you would like to join The Northwestern Flipside, recommend an idea, submit an article, or have any questions, please email contact@northwesternflipside.com

 

Links

Visit our official site to read past articles and find more information!

Check out our Facebook page here, and be sure to follow us on Twitter @realnuflipside!
Summary: The Northwestern Flipside is Northwestern University\u2019s official satirical newspaper. We publish new content online daily, as well as monthly print issues distributed across campus. Visit our website at www.NorthwesternFlipside.com for more information!

Name: Northwestern Formula Racing
Description:
Formula SAE

Formula SAE (FSAE) is an intercollegiate engineering design competition organized by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE), where student teams design, build, and race formula-style cars. FSAE began in the USA in 1978, and now includes hundreds of international teams that compete in eight competitions around the world.

The FSAE series is internationally regarded as one of the most rigorous collegiate design competitions. Each year, teams spend 8 to 12 months preparing for competition.

The concept of the competition is for students to design, build, and race a prototype formula-style vehicle. The prototype is marketed towards the non-professional, weekend autocross racer. It must be high-performance, low cost, easy to maintain, and suitable for manufacture at 1000 units per year. Students manage all aspects of the project like a small business, from the technical design to the management of an interdisciplinary team.

Engineering

Teams have overwhelming freedom in the design of their cars. This is evident in the variety and ingenuity presented at each competition. Technical restrictions only exist to ensure safety, and do not limit creativity. Students engage a panel of industry judges to defend their design decisions with supporting analysis. Student drivers compete against the clock in a series of driving events to demonstrate real-world performance of their vehicles.

Business and Marketing

Building a racing car is not all engineering. Complex projects require strong leaders and a cooperative environment to succeed. In addition to managing the project, students must present a business case to a prospective manufacturer as well as a detailed manufacturing and cost analysis, showing complete understanding of what it takes to bring a product to market.

Perspective

FSAE converts classroom knowledge to real world experience. Involvement in the complete design process is a unique educational opportunity.
Summary: McCormick Student Group

Name: Northwestern Geoclub
Description: Northwestern Geoclub is a coalition of students passionate about the outdoors, science, and inclusion. We strive to make our club accessible members both inside and outside the field of geology, creating a diverse and like-minded community!
Summary: Northwestern Geoclub is a coalition of students passionate about the outdoors, science, and inclusion. We strive to make our club accessible members both inside and outside the field of geology, creating a diverse and like-minded community!

Name: Northwestern Hawai'i Club
Description: The Hawaii Club shares Hawaiian culture with the Midwest through events such as our annual luau. We also encourage the "Aloha Spirit" across campus and are ambassadors to Hawaii students during their college careers. We always encourage the participation of anyone who loves or might like to love the Hawaiian culture!
Summary: The Hawaii Club shares Hawaiian culture with the Midwest through events like our annual luau. We also encourage the "Aloha Spirit" across campus and are ambassadors to Hawaii students during their college careers.

Name: Northwestern Karate
Description:
Join us for karate and self-defense classes!

All sessions are beginner-friendly!

 

Karate Classes:

Beginner/Intermediate-specific: Tuesdays – 7-8 pm

Everyone (includes Advanced): Saturdays – 12:30-2 pm

 

 

Check out our club's Facebook page website: www.facebook.com/NUkarate

 

Are you interested in learning a traditional Japanese martial art? Strengthening your body as well as your mind? Having fun, making friends, and learning something new? Then check out Northwestern Karate! The club is open to students, faculty, staff, and other members of the Northwestern University community. The club teaches Shotokan karate three times a week at the Evanston campus. In addition, the club sponsors an annual collegiate competition, seminars, and social functions. No previous experience in martial arts is necessary to join the club, and beginners are always welcome. For those with previous experience, we welcome all practitioners of traditional Japanese karate. A number of the students and instructors are members of the AAKF/ITKF, but the club is open to members of other affiliations (ISKF, WKO, etc.) and unaffiliated dojos.
Summary: Are you interested in learning a traditional Japanese martial art? Strengthening your body as well as your mind? Having fun, making friends, and learning something new? Then check out Northwestern Karate Club!

Name: Northwestern NAfME Collegiate
Description: Northwestern NAfME Collegiate is a group dedicated to the development and preparation of future educators within the Northwestern music education department. NU NAfME encourages collaboration with classmates, faculty, and the surrounding music community to enhance the music education experience. In addition to the acclaimed music instruction provided by the Bienen School of Music, NU NAfME works to provide opportunities and programming in order to develop the musicianship, leadership, and educational expertise of music education students so that they may become successful contributors to the music education profession.
Summary: Learn more about us at www.nu-nafme.org

Name: Northwestern News Network
Description: We are the only broadcast news station on Northwestern's campus. We produce, shoot and report for three weekly newscasts specializing in campus news, sports and politics. Our staff members shoot, edit, and anchor all of our content, and we often travel to cover news in Chicago and beyond. The shows are created by students, for students. The network has won many accolades including national Emmys and Best All-Around Newscast from the Society of Professional Journalists.
Summary: NNN is the only broadcast news station on campus. We produce, shoot and report for three weekly newscasts specializing in campus news, sports and politics, in addition to our online platforms.

Name: Northwestern News Network-Sports
Description: We are the sports department of Northwestern's student television station. Our group produces our own sports television show which we shoot once a week. Our staff member shoot, edit, and anchor all of our content, and we often travel to road games.
Summary: We are the sports department of Northwestern's student television station. Our group produces our own sports television show which we shoot once a week. Our staff member shoot, edit, and anchor all of our content, and we often travel to road games.

Name: Northwestern NuTango
Description: NuTango is a Northwestern University student-run organization for Argentine Tango. We host lessons, practices, and dance events. NuTango is dedicated to provide a fun and friendly environment for beginners to start in Tango, as well for more experienced dancers to continue dancing. In our events, we strive to create an open environment that encourages members to explore the role of lead and follow. Additionally, we embrace musical variety by playing a wide range of songs from traditional Tango to modern. We are open to everyone in the Northwestern community as well as general public of Chicago area.
Summary: NuTango is a Northwestern University student-run organization for Argentine Tango. We host lessons, practices, and dance events.

Name: Northwestern Political Union
Description:
The Northwestern University Political Union (PU) is a community of students united by their common interest in discussion of political and global affairs. Bringing together students of various backgrounds, ideologies, and political persuasions, the Political Union aims to foster a revival of intellectualism, sincerity, and sophistication in Northwestern’s campus political discourse.

PU holds weekly meetings in a variety of formats, including student debates, lectures from faculty, discussions over dinner, and special guest speakers. All undergraduates are welcome at PU meetings and there is no membership fee to attend our events.
Summary:
The Northwestern University Political Union is a community of students united by their common interest in discussion of political and global affairs.

Visit http://www.nupoliticalunion.com/ for more information.

Name: Northwestern Public Health Review
Description: See more information at our website (https://sites.northwestern.edu/nphr/) and on our blog (https://nphr.wordpress.com/).
Summary: NPHR is a student-run academic journal. Our goal is to take you behind the scenes of public health and provide a simpler platform for students and faculty to share their public health perspectives, ideas, and original research.

Name: Northwestern Quest Scholars Network
Description: The Northwestern Quest Scholars Network (NUQSN) is Northwestern University's only low-income and first generation advocacy group. NUQSN serves over 20% of the Northwestern population as both a community and advocacy group for low-income and first generation students and their allies. NUQSN also serves as a resource for the Chicagoland grade school and high school communities, both mentoring underprivledged youth and educating low-income students about scholarship and educational opportunities at Northwestern and beyond.
Summary: NUQSN aims to create an engaged and supportive community for low-income and first-generation students as well as their allies in addition to ensuring equal opportunities for all low-income and first-generation students on Northwestern's campus.

Name: Northwestern Raas
Description: Northwestern Raas has been blending its passion for dance with a dedication to promoting awareness of South Asian culture since its founding in 2014. As the University’s premier co-ed Raas and Garba team, a dance form that originates in the Indian state of Gujarat, Northwestern Raas is known for its strong sense of community and enthusiasm both behind the curtain and on stage. The team has delighted audiences across the nation in multiple national competitions per year including Raas Royalty, Nasha, Raas Mania, and Pittsburgh Raaz. Northwestern Raas is more than just a college dance team — it’s a family, with a network of alumni, that continues to inspire, educate and engage those around them in the beauty of South Asian culture.
Summary: Northwestern Raas is the University's premier co-ed Raas and Garba team, a high-energy folk dance originating from the Indian state of Gujarat.

Name: Northwestern Sketch Television
Description: NSTV (Northwestern Sketch Television) is a College Emmy-award winning sketch comedy group from Northwestern University. The team, which includes over eighty students working in various positions, writes, directs, shoots, edits, promotes and acts in a wide variety of sketches throughout the year. In addition to making content for the Internet and an annual feature-length campus premiere, NSTV sponsors and performs in live shows and facilitates guest speakers, workshops and field-trips. Check us out at www.northwesternsketchtv.com!
Summary: NSTV (Northwestern Sketch Television) is a College Emmy-award winning sketch comedy group from Northwestern University. Including over eighty students working in various positions, we write, direct, shoot, promote, and act in a wide variety of sketches.

Name: Northwestern Ski Trip
Description:
\u200b\u200bThe Northwestern University Ski Trip’s mission is to provide fun, social, and adventurous vacations to Northwestern students. The club provides quality trips for large groups of Northwestern students at much lower prices than available to the individual adventurist.

 The modern club runs a highly anticipated annual ski trip at the start of every winter break. Due to the outstanding number of students who participate Northwestern Ski Trip is currently one of the largest student-run ski trips in the nation.

 Every year the club hosts 800-1000 NU students for a week at a select mountain out West. In the past, NU Ski Trip has visited some of the top ski resorts in the country including Aspen, Breckenridge, Telluride, Jackson Hole, Park City, Big Sky, Winter Park, Copper Mountain and Steamboat.

\u200bThe best part? Due to the large number of participants, NU Ski Trip gets one of the best deals around. Though ticket prices vary from year to year, each participant will receive 6 nights of lodging in mountainside, condo-style accommodations and a 4-day lift pass for under $500. Throughout the week, students enjoy deals and discounts at local restaurants and bars, as well as discounted rental equipment and lessons. NU Ski Trip also sponsors events such as après ski gatherings, karaoke nights, ugly sweater parties, tubing extravaganzas and a free private concert!

 History repeating itself is an age-old tradition of NU Ski Trip, and every year somehow finds itself being more meaningful than the last. We hope to see you on the slopes!
Summary: Each year, our organization plans a trip out west for 800-1000 Northwestern students to ski and snowboard after fall quarter finals week.

Name: Northwestern Swing Dance Syndicate
Description:
NSDS is an organization run out of the community building grant of the graduate school to promote stronger community via swing dancing - lindy hop, blues, balboa, and a range of other dances. We host lessons throughout the year, as well as organizing all-Chicago dance events, with nationally renowned swing bands. We are open to everyone in the Northwestern community, from beginners to advanced dancers. 

There are several ways to connect with us and the community of dancers that we have.

1) Facebook group is our most active mode of communication among our group within NU and broader Chicago area.

2) Our group has an email listserv where we send out information about dance classes and events on campus that we organize. Subscribe by sending an email to listserv@listserv.it.northwestern.edu with no subject and SUBSCRIBE NSDS in the body, or contact us directly and we'll help you out.

3) The club's official email address is nuswingdance@gmail.com. Send us requests, questions, suggestions, etc.

Hope to see you dancing with us!
Summary: Lindy Hop, East Coast, Charleston, and Balboa are what we do. We focus and promote social dancing with (new) friends by providing weekly dancing classes, quarterly dances with live band, and occasionally dance workshops.

Name: Northwestern Taekwondo
Description:
Northwestern Taekwondo Club is a community of students who love to kick! Our members are of all skill and experience levels; from black belts with 10+ years of experience to some who have never heard of Taekwondo before joining, we are open to all. We offer practices, hold belt tests, attend competitions, and perform at the annual KASA show. We are more than a team; we are a family :)
 
Our practices are mainly led by our experienced student captains, and are supported by a WTF-based external dojang. Practices involve a variety of activities including fitness training, sparring, poomsae, and demonstration prep. Join us Mondays 7-9pm, Wednesdays 8-10pm, and Saturdays 12-2pm in the Henry Crown Studio 1B.
Summary: As the premier martial arts club on campus, we're dedicated to providing a friendly motivating environment for members of all abilities. We compete in tournaments and perform in shows year-round. Come learn the world's most popular martial art with us!

Name: Northwestern Triathlon Club
Description: The Northwestern Triathlon Club strives to make all members more confident in their triathlon abilities! We train together for both local and national competitions (or just for fun if racing isn't for you). We host swim, bike, and run workouts throughout the school year, all of which are optional. Throughout the year, we race local races as well as races across the midwest as part of our conference, the MECTC. The club is open to people of all ability levels, and currently has 75+ members. Whether you are a competitive athlete who is looking to improve, or somebody who wants to stay in shape while in college, this is the right club for you!
Summary: NU Triathlon competes at the highest level of collegiate triathlon and welcomes students of all abilities and backgrounds to join us. Already an elite triathlete? Ran or swam in high school? Don't know what a triathlon is? There's a place for you here!

Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Energy Club
