Description: The Northwestern Undergraduate Energy Club (NUEC) seeks to develop and foster a community of NU undergrads who are passionate about the energy industry through educational, professional and discussion-based activities. By providing opportunities to learn about clean energy research, network with energy professionals and companies, or engage with energy initiatives both locally and globally, NUEC hopes to develop leaders in energy policy, business, and technology.
Summary: NUEC seeks to develop a community of NU undergrads who are passionate about the energy industry through educational, professional and discussion-based activities.

Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal
Description: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal (NULJ) provides a platform for the submission and discussion of law-related topics for students at Northwestern University. Our mission is to encourage legal and political awareness in the Northwestern community. Our website is thenulj.org
Summary: Northwestern Undergraduate Law Journal (NULJ) provides a platform for the submission and discussion of law-related topics for students at Northwestern University. Our mission is to encourage legal and political awareness in the Northwestern community.

Name: Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal
Description: The Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal is an annual peer- and faculty-reviewed publication of research articles written by Northwestern undergraduates from all academic fields.  NURJ provides students the opportunity to experience writing and submitting original research.  The goals of the Journal are to encourage the dissemination of ideas, increase undergraduate involvement in research, and recognize the impressive work being performed by undergraduates.  NURJ staff members participate in finding peer and faculty editors, compiling the articles for the annual edition, designing the annual edition, and spreading the word about NURJ to the NU community.
Summary: The Northwestern Undergraduate Research Journal (NURJ) is an annual student-produced journal that showcases outstanding research done by Northwestern undergraduates from across all academic fields.

Name: Northwestern University American Society of Mechanical Engineers
Description: The Northwestern chapter of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (NU ASME) allows students to interact with practicing mechanical engineering professionals, providing the opportunity to network, develop skills, and work collaboratively. This also creates a community around mechanical engineering that enables skill sharing and mentoring within the field as well as cross-collaboration with other student groups. Additionally, NU ASME serves to inform students of career opportunities directly related to the field of mechanical engineering and connect students, professors, and professionals to relate academic knowledge to industry applications.
Summary: The Northwestern University chapter of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers

Name: Northwestern University Catholic Student Association
Description:
The Catholic Student Association (CaSA) is the student group representing Catholic students and their friends at Northwestern University. We are affiliated with the Sheil Catholic Center*. We invite students and their friends to connect with one another and with the greater Sheil community and staff. We provide opportunities to engage in fellowship, education, prayer and service. These events will reflect the seven tenets of Catholic social teaching (life and dignity of the human person, call to community and participation, caring for the poor and vulnerable, the dignity of work and the rights of workers, solidarity and finally, care for God’s creation) and/or the seven facets of Campus Ministry as outlined in Empowered by the Spirit.
The purpose of Catholic Students Association at Northwestern University is to serve as  the first line of hospitality and outreach for Catholic students and their friends at Northwestern University, to foster communication between Catholic students and the Sheil Catholic Center, and to aid the director/chaplain of Sheil in his efforts to create a more unified Sheil. CaSA supports Sheil’s mission: “to prepare Catholic Disciples of all ages to lead lives of faith and reason by together worshiping, learning, growing, and serving the Northwestern community and beyond."

We aim to
-encourage fellowship and community with Northwestern student body
-provide opportunity for spiritual growth through academic means   
-spread the good news of the gospel
-encourage service
-encourage personal development and the development of leaders for the future
-evaluate the effectiveness of Sheil Catholic Center and identify ways to improve community, liturgy and spirituality

*Sheil Catholic Center welcomes all students into a faith community in the Roman Catholic tradition. Sheil sponsors retreats, lectures, discussions, service trips, bible study, small faith groups and many other ministries and activities. Masses are at 9:30, 11, 5 pm, and 9 pm on Sundays during the school year.
Summary: CaSA gathers Catholic students and their friends to grow in friendship with each other and Christ. We invite students to explore faith, serve others, and enjoy each others' company. Our home is the Sheil Catholic Center.

Name: Northwestern University Community for Human Rights
Description:
The Northwestern University Community for Human Rights (NUCHR) is the leading voice for global human rights on campus.

Through informed dialogue, weekly meetings, educational excursions, an annual spring break trip, social events, and year-round programming, we bridge connections between undergraduates and international discussions on current human rights issues. Our group is oriented to assist students in grappling with complex histories and inequities in order to develop deep critical thinking abilities and to mobilize inspired action.

Each January, NUCHR's explores a distinct topic in the field of human rights while playing host to the largest student run, student attended human right's conference in the nation.
Summary: Welcome to the NU Community for Human Rights! Our aim is to spark dialogue, foster activism, and improve awareness surrounding global and local human rights challenges.

Name: Northwestern University Dance Marathon
Description:
Overview

Now in its 48th year, Northwestern University Dance Marathon (NUDM) is one of the largest independent student-run philanthropies in the nation. Our mission is to unite the Northwestern, Evanston, and Greater Chicagoland communities through philanthropic fundraising, service, and education. A year-long effort culminating in a 30-hour dance marathon, NUDM strives to create an inclusive and enriching environment for the NUDM student body, our rotating primary beneficiary, and our longstanding secondary beneficiary, the Evanston Community Foundation (ECF). Since 1975, NUDM has raised more than $20 million for more than 35 different charitable organizations.

Our History

In 1975, Northwestern University Dance Marathon, the philanthropic child of Alpha Tau Omega fraternity and the Associated Student Government, was born on the Northwestern University Evanston campus. It was initially called the “Dance to Give Them a Chance” marathon, and it benefited the American Epilepsy Foundation and the Arc. Fifteen couples made it through the 52-hour marathon, raising $9,100 at Blomquist Memorial Gymnasium.

NUDM is now one of the world’s largest collegiate philanthropies! Last year, NUDM raised $674,325 for Compass to Care – which strives to eliminate the monetary burden of traveling to treatment for families with a child who is ill – and the Evanston Community Foundation – which funds a variety of local grants to deserving organizations with the goal of helping Evanston thrive.

Where We Are Now

This year, NUDM is thrilled to partner with Chicago Youth Programs (CYP). CYP is a nonprofit organization striving to improve the life opportunities and health of youth in low-income neighborhoods, primarily on the south and west sides of Chicago, through long-term academic, emotional and mental support. CYP gives their participants the tools for self-regulation, empathy and communication, while also enriching their passions through socializing programs in arts and culture. This year, NUDM and CYP are working together to help Chicago’s youth overcome systemic inequities and obtain the higher education necessary to break the cycle of poverty. 

For more information, see nudm.org.
Summary: NUDM is a year-long effort culminating in a 30-hour dance marathon that unites the Northwestern, Evanston, and Greater Chicagoland communities through awareness, service, education, and philanthropic fundraising.

Name: Northwestern University Effective Altruism
Description:
Listserv form: bit.ly/nueasignup

 

Are you a Northwestern undergrad hoping to learn about the most fruitful ways to combat the world's most pressing issues? Join Northwestern Effective Altruism (NU EA)!

From engaging with researchers focused on increasing efficiency of poverty alleviation, to interacting with professionals who work high-paying jobs to increase donation potential, to discussing high-impact careers with other students, Northwestern EA nurtures a community of students who aim to promote positive impact effectively.

 

Feel free to reach out to us with any questions at effectivealtruism@u.northwestern.edu!
Summary: Effective altruism is a philosophical and social movement that uses evidence and reasoning to determine the most effective ways to do good.

Name: Northwestern University Fossil Free
Description:
Fossil Free Northwestern is a group of students, faculty, staff, alumni, and community members calling on Northwestern University to remove its investments in coal and move toward divestment from all fossil fuels. We aim to build a sustainable endowment that refuses to fund climate change, pollution, or injustice. 

 

We're part of an international Fossil Free movement made up of colleges, cities, religious institutions, and more all taking action against climate change through socially responsible investing.
Summary: Fossil Free Northwestern is a group of students, faculty, staff, alumni, and community members calling on Northwestern University to remove its investments in coal and move toward divestment from all fossil fuels. We aim to build a sustainable endowment

Name: Northwestern University Model United Nations
Description:
Please see our website numun.org for more information!

The Northwestern University Model United Nations conference originated in 2004 when a group of dedicated Northwestern undergrads sought to fill a void in the community’s extracurricular department. In the years since, the conference has almost tripled in size, but its dedication to delegate experience has never changed. NUMUN is typically hosted every year at the Norris University Center on campus, directly adjacent to Lake Michigan.

Our mission is to be provide a premier high school conference and field a top tier competitive travel team. Our high-quality, dedicated secretariat and staff create a personal, professional, and passionate simulation experience. We seek to broaden delegates’ knowledge of worldwide politics, increase interpersonal skills, and create impactful experiences.
Summary: Our mission is to offer a premier Model UN conference for High School students from around the world, while fielding a top flight competitive travel team that can compete on the national American circuit.

Name: Northwestern University Nanotechnology Club
Summary: The Northwestern University Nanotechnology Club (nanoNU) is an interdisciplinary student organization focused on the current and potential applications of nanotechnology in society.

Name: Northwestern University Native American and Indigenous Student Alliance
Summary: Northwestern University Native American and Indigenous Student Association is dedicated to promoting and inspiring the interests of the community of Native American students and those who appreciate Native American cultures at Northwestern University.

Name: Northwestern University Outdoors Club
Description: NUOC is a group of students who love the outdoors! Everyone and anyone is welcome to join, lead, or plan trips. Prior experience is rarely necessary. During our 54 years of existence on the Northwestern campus, we have gone backpacking, canoeing, hiking, climbing, camping, skiing, snowshoeing, spelunking, and more. We also provide free gear rentals to club members. The next adventure is up to you! Send us an email at nuoutdoorclub@gmail.com to join our listserv!
Summary: Providing your outdoors fix since 1965.

Name: Northwestern University Philosophy Society
Description: Northwestern Undergraduate Philosophy Society (NUPS) is designed much like the Academy of Athens, where students come together to agree, dissent, contemplate, consider, and debate with each other. The club meets once a week, Thursdays at 7:00 at the Celtic Knot on Church St., to discuss philosophical quandaries. Topics are often brought from Northwestern philosophy classes, but not necessarily -- some themes last year were philosophy and jokes, a philosophical reading of a Borges's Library of Babel, thoughts on consciousness and existentialism. The club is not exclusive to philosophy students, although you should consider yourself a student of philosophy. In addition to weekly meetings, NUPS annually hosts Philnight, a evening where professors present brief arguments and engage with students. Information is usually distributed through listserv, sign up to be in the loop.
Summary: Northwestern Undergraduate Philosophy Society (NUPS) is designed much like the Academy of Athens, where students come together to agree, contemplate, consider, and debate with each other.

Name: Northwestern University SACNAS Chapter
Summary: SACNAS is a society of scientists dedicated to fostering the success of Hispanic/Chicano and Native American scientists\u2014from college students to professionals\u2014to attain advanced degrees, careers, and positions of leadership in science.

Name: Northwestern University Sailing Team
Description:
Past History:
The Northwestern Sailing Team can trace its history back to the late 1950's when teams practiced in downtown Chicago, with the NU boathouse constructed on campus in 1974. Since that time the NU sailing team has ranged from a relaxed learn-to-sail program to a nationally competitive team attending numerous national championships and graduating two college all Americans: Roslyn Rea who received sailing's top honor 1987 and Scotia Ryer in both 1995/1996. Today Northwestern continues to be a top school in the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association.


Schedule:

Competition occurs from early September through Thanksgiving and starts back up in late March continuing through early June with regattas most weekends. The Northwestern sailing team attends upwards of 25 events each year. Practice is held in the fall and spring Monday thru Thursday from 3-6 out of the NU boathouse. Team members are asked to attend practice at least twice a week. Single-Handed and Sloop Nationals occur in the fall while Co-ed, Women's, and Team Race Nationals are held in the spring.

League Affiliation:

College sailing features over 200 schools and is governed by the Inter-Collegiate Sailing Association (ICSA). The ICSA is broken down into seven regional districts, with the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association, of which Northwestern is a member, stretching from Minnesota to Ohio.


Club Dues:

200 dollars per year. Team members are also required to purchase proper sailing gear their first year.


Tryout Schedule:

Try outs are held each fall.


Practice Locations:

NU Sailing Center, located on south beach which features a fleet of 12 420's and 8 lasers.


Competition Locations:

Schools all over the country, however most events are in the Midwest. Frequent locations are Wisconsin, Minnesota, Ohio State, and Michigan, however this past year we attended events in Seattle, Larchmont, and Dallas.
Summary: We are a student-run, student-led club sport team at Northwestern, practicing on Lake Michigan out of the NU Sailing Center and competing in regattas on both a local and national scale.

Name: Northwestern University Space Technology and Rocketry Society
Description:
NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY SPACE TECHNOLOGY AND ROCKETRY SOCIETY is a organization comprised of four different aerospace interest teams. The mission of each team is outlined below. Overall, the goal of NUSTARS is to advocate for research related to space exploration.

NASA Student Launch (NSL): Design, build, and launch a reusable rocket with science payload, in accordance with NASA Student Launch competition rules

Aero NU: Design, build, and fly remote controlled planes.  Our newest team!

NUSTARS Experimental Technology (NSET): Three fast paced, quarter long aerospace-related projects.  Reach out for more info!

Certification and Education: focus on new members, aims to provide the skills and training necessary to succeed in other groups of NUSTARS. The primary objective of Education and Certification is for members to build and launch a high powered rocket for Level 1 High Power Rocketry Certification. In non-COVID times, this also includes engaging students and educators at Northwestern and in the Evanston and Chicago communities in learning about the Universe, space technology, and rocketry.

 

*NUSTARS is always looking to expand and create new teams. Any student with a passion for aerospace is encouraged to join!

Past teams include: 

Revolutionary Aerospace Systems Concept- Academic Linkage (RASC-AL): complete the design and documentation for a scientific payload, in accordance with the NASA Revolutionary Aerospace Systems Concept- Academic Linkage rules

Near Space Exploration Team: design, build, and launch a high altitude weather balloon with the long term goal of completing a data logging system and competing in a national design competition

Alka-Rocket: design, build, and launch an alka-seltzer powered rocket in accordance with the Bayer Alka-Rocket Challenge
Summary: We are Northwestern's aerospace interest group dedicated to participating in NASA competitions, rocketry challenges, and approved student proposed projects. We also reach out to local schools to get the next generation excited about space exploration.

Name: Northwestern University Special Olympics
Description: The purpose of Northwestern University Special Olympics is to integrate individuals with developmental disabilities in our community through athletic competition, inclusive programming, and events to raise awareness. The objective of Northwestern University Special Olympics shall be to partner with Evanston Special Olympics in joint programming. Northwestern University Special Olympics coordinates over 100 student volunteers and coaches for Special Olympics athletes in the community, special events on campus, and awareness and educational outreach about intellectual disabilities.
Summary: Northwestern University Special Olympics is the oldest and largest collegiate Special Olympics chapter. Our mission is to integrate individuals with developmental disabilities into our community through inclusive programming.

Name: Northwestern University Table Tennis Club
Description:
History

The Northwestern University Table Tennis Club (NUTTC) was founded on March of 2006. Inspired by the table tennis talent and potential at Northwestern, a group of students came together to form a club to encourage and foster the skills and interests of table tennis enthusiasts around campus. Also, we seek to provide opportunities for students to compete in regional and national tournaments. Now, the club holds weekly practices and organizes local and regional tournaments throughout the year, and will be travelling to various locations to compete with other colleges. 

Philosophy

The club is open to all skill levels from those never having held a ping pong paddle before to those who have been trained by coaches for many years. We encourage all those who have interest in the sport to come join us at our practices. Attendance is not mandatory; members can come and go as they please. 

About the Club

We have around 15-20 regular members attending our weekly meetings. We have four tables, thanks to the great support of Norris and the Sports Club Department. We also provide table tennis balls and paddles for those who do not own one.

Practice Schedule

Our practices are typically held Sunday, Tuesday, and Thursday evenings from 8-10 pm at SPAC, in the second floor tennis court bleachers. 

Email reminders will be sent weekly. To receive these reminders or hear more weekly updates of the club, please subscribe to the listserv by employing the following steps:

1) Send e-mail to listserv@listserv.it.northwestern.edu without any subject line.
2) Type the following command in the message:

SUBSCRIBE NUTableTennis Firstname Lastname

(ex. SUBSCRIBE NUTableTennis John Smith)
Summary: The NUTTC is a student-ran group group focusing on the development of skill and interest in table tennis on campus. The club has both a competitive and recreational team to suit the preferences of students' interest.

Name: Northwestern University Veterans Association
Description:
Come and learn how you can be a part of Northwestern University’s commitment to:

•Actively RECRUIT the most innovative and creative leaders produced by our Nation’s military
•Consistently INCREASE its VETERAN POPULATION and their contribution to collaborative scholarship
•PROVIDE world class SERVICE to its Veteran population
•FOSTER COLLABORATION efforts between NUVA and the full spectrum of University institutions and organizations to address shared interests and achieve common goals
•Positively IMPACT the QUALITY OF LIFE of both Veterans and their families within the NU community and all Veterans throughout the greater Chicago area
•Provide a community for veterans and supporters of Northwestern to get together, connect, and have fun!
Summary: Mission: NUVA provides Veterans access to the resources, support and advocacy they have earned, deserve and require to succeed in higher education, to achieve their academic goals, and to gain meaningful employment following graduation.

Name: Northwestern University Women Filmmakers Alliance
Description:
Come to the club fair: https://northwestern.zoom.us/j/96223587796

The Northwestern University Women Filmmaker's Alliance is a student-run film board dedicated to supporting women and LGBTQ+ in the entertainment industry. We provide grants, mentorship events, industry panels, and many other exciting events to the RTVF community.
Summary: Supporting the advancement of women in film

Name: Northwestern Wildside
Description:
Wildside is the Official Student Section of Northwestern Athletics. Every time you attend a Northwestern athletic event and cheer from the student section, you are a part of Wildside. Wildside is also a specific organization, with multiple committees and an executive board, that works alongside the Athletic Department to improve student gameday experiences, improve our home team advantage to better support our athletic teams, and increase overall school spirit across the entire campus.

 

Go 'Cats!
Summary: Wildside is the Official Student Section of Northwestern Athletics. All students at Northwestern are members of Wildside. Wildside also allows for greater involvement for students through committee and executive leadership positions.

Name: Northwestern Women's Club Basketball
Description:
History: Women's Club Basketball began in 1995, or so we are told. 

Practice Schedule: We practice twice a week for two hours, Sunday and Tuesday evenings at SPAC on campus. We often have optional pick-up games throughout the year.

Competition Schedule:

FALL: We play the majority of our games in the fall quarter, competing against several Chicago community and Division III colleges. We also play the club teams from other Big 10 and Division I schools from the Midwest. We also attend tournaments in the Midwest.

WINTER: We enter our team into the Frat-tastic, guy's IM (intramural) league (the co-ed league isn't competitive enough for us), play a few more games against community colleges and club teams, and we play in one/two more tournaments. The highlight of our season is the regional tournament held at the end of winter quarter. This is where we try desperately to make it to nationals, but always manage to get beat by the University of Illinois club team. Maybe next year.

SPRING: We don't play any formal games in the spring, but we try to continue playing pick-up. Just to make sure we don't lose that jumpshot. 

League affiliation: None

Club Dues: $110/year (or $55/quarter)

Try-outs: Try-outs are usually the first Sunday and Tuesday evenings after the start of classes. Look for us at the Activities Fair or check our Facebook page during the first week of classes to find out specific dates!

Frequency: Practices are twice per week, and games usually start towards the end of October and continue at a rate of one to two per week until Thanksgiving. Games during winter quarter are less frequent--usually on weekends. When we play in the Chicago area, travel time to games varies typically between twenty minutes to an hour or so. When we play at tournaments like Southern Illinois or Indiana, we leave for the entire weekend and travel about five hours both ways. However, that is the farthest that we travel.
Summary: Women's Club Basketball is everything you dreamed it would be and more. We road trip around the midwest playing basketball in the varsity team's old uniforms. We are often mistaken for D1 athletes when we eat at Chipotle after our games. Come tryout!

Name: Nous Fe
Description: Through our partnership with the Haitian-based non-profit, Angel Wings International, Nous Fé aims to provide all interested northwestern students with opportunities to engage in non-profit work to empower the patient population of Jacmel, Haiti. Nous Fé  also recruits medical service teams comprised of Northwestern undergraduate students to travel to Jacmel, Haiti, and provide medical service and patient care.
Summary: Nous F\u00e9's purpose is to provide all interested students at Northwestern with the opportunity to engage in meaningful and sustainable global health work through medical service and non-profit work with Angel Wings International.

Name: NROTC
Description:
The Northwestern NROTC unit was established as one of six original units in the United States. Today, the program develops midshipmen mentally, morally and physically and imbues them with the highest ideals of duty, and loyalty.

We welcome all freshmen and sophomores to contact Lauren Kearney for more information.
Summary: The NROTC Program was established to educate and train qualified young men and women for service as commissioned officers in the Navy and Marine Corps.

Name: NSSLHA-Undergraduate
Description:
The purpose of our organization is i) to encourage professional interest among undergraduate students in the study of Human Communication Sciences and Disorders, ii) to provide opportunities to gain practical and applicable experience and knowledge related to a future career in CSD, iii) to serve as a welcoming, open, and tolerant space to kindle CSD-related discussion by those pursuing or interested in the field of study from all identities and backgrounds, iv) to spread awareness of CSD causes to our general student body members and peers and v) to develop and sustain a meaningful and mutually beneficial connection between NSSLHA-Undergraduate and NU NSSLHA Graduate as well as faculty and leaders in the CSD Department. The intended goals for the organization are primarily based in the furthering of the bond within the CSD undergraduate community and in providing adequate and useful support, guidance, and opportunities to successfully achieve their professional goals with ease. 

More information on the overall mission and purpose can be found from the national NSSLHA organization.
Summary: NSSLHA-Undergraduate creates an open, inclusive, and equitable space for undergraduates interested in the study of Human Communication Sciences and Disorders to come together in pursuit of academic, social, and professional opportunities in this field.

Name: NU Asian Magazine
Description: NU Asian Magazine is Northwestern University’s Asian American-interest magazine. We publish at least twice a year and cover anything and everything related to the greater Asian American community.
Summary: NU Asian Magazine is Northwestern University's Asian American-interest magazine. We publish at least twice a year and cover anything and everything related to the greater Asian American community.

Name: NU CatToonz
Summary: N/A

Name: NU Curling
Description:
NU Curling is a community-building graduate club dedicated to teaching and playing the great winter sport of curling. Our FREE events take place at the Chicago Curling Club, located a short carpool ride away in Northbrook. From fall to spring we host weekly lessons, games, and broomstacking (post-game drinks and snacks) and would like all of you to join in. Newcomers are highly encouraged to come try it out, as are any curling pros.

In addition to these weekly events, we have also sent teams to Regional and National Curling Tournaments and have held the Northwestern Bonspiel to end our past six seasons.
Summary: A community-building graduate club dedicated to teaching and playing the great winter sport of curling. Our FREE events take place at the Chicago Curling Club, located a short carpool ride away in Northbrook. From fall to spring we host weekly lessons.

Name: NU Graduates Mentoring Undergraduates
Summary: The long-term objective of the organization is to develop a stronger sense of community between graduate and undergraduate students at Northwestern University through mentorship.

Name: NU Heights
Description:
The volunteers involved with NU Heights have the opportunity to tutor and mentor local students in elementary, middle, and high school. The subjects include math, science, and reading comprehension, among others. There are morning and afternoon shifts each day throughout the week to fit your schedule! 

Tutors working in a classroom during the school day may assist the teacher with various tasks, work one-on-one with a student, or help a small group of students independently. The responsibilities vary depending on the teacher. After school, tutors may offer homework assistance, mentor, or do various fun activities with the students. There are also opportunities to work in Spanish since many of our students are ESL and use Spanish at home.
Summary: The volunteers involved with NU Heights have the opportunity to tutor and mentor elementary and middle school-aged students in various local schools. Tutors work either in classrooms throughout the school day or during after-school activities.

Name: NU Nights
Description: NU Nights is a student-led organization with the aim of bringing substance-free, late night programming activities to Northwestern undergraduate students and uniting our campus community through these activities. Programming includes a variety of on-campus and off-campus events, catering to the needs and interests of our student body, usually between 6pm to 12am on Thursdays or Fridays. Events include, but are not limited to, arts and crafts, game nights, trivia, excursions, and student group collaborations.
Summary: NU Nights is a student-led organization with the aim of bringing substance-free, late night programming activities to Northwestern undergraduate students and uniting our campus community through these activities.

Name: NU Photonics/SPIE
Summary: We welcome people from the fields of engineering, materials science, chemistry, and others. We promote the science of light at Northwestern, as well as foment social and professional interaction of our student members and faculty.

Name: NU Robotics
Description:
NU Robotics is a student-run organization that sponsors a multitude of engineering focused projects for Northwestern University. Our mission is to develop a core community of undergraduate student builders interested in robotics and unifying them across majors. We offer a place for students to express their creative and innovative side as they work on student-created projects and apply the knowledge learned in class to gain practical experience in a fun way. The projects range from technical research projects to start-up ideas to yearly competitions. We welcome every type of student and hold workshops during the fall to teach and provide hands-on experience to newcomers, so students from all over can join the build!

We strongly encourage interested members to join our slack workspace- this is where we do most of our communication!  We'll send out reminders about events and give updates on what's happening in the club as well.
Summary: NU Robotics Club is an open interdisciplinary group working on robotics competitions and design projects in teams of undergraduate students. We are always looking for new project ideas, feel free to reach out. All skill levels are welcome!

Name: NU SIAM Student Chapter
Description: The aim of the Northwestern Student Chapter of SIAM is to provide a platform for students involved in science to interact with one another. We organize social and scientific events that bring together students from all areas of science as SIAM is a strong promoter of interdisciplinary collaboration. Students that use mathematical, computational, statistical, or visualization methods for their research are strongly encouraged to become a member and participate in this organization!
Summary: NU's official student chapter of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. We organize events to promote interaction between students involved in different areas of science.

Name: NU Solar Car Team
Description:
The Northwestern University Solar Car Team (NUsolar) is an undergraduate student-run organization that designs, builds, and races solar-powered electric vehicles. We are one of the most diverse student organizations within the McCormick School of Engineering. Our members come from all areas of expertise: software, electrical, mechanical, and chemical engineers, as well as economics, music, journalism, and film majors.


NUsolar’s mission is to prepare Northwestern students for careers in engineering, manufacturing, marketing, and leadership positions, by providing the opportunity for them to engage in real-life, out-of-the classroom projects. Our members learn how to function in a specialized team and work within budgets and deadlines. They make connections with their peers and with our advising professors, as well as with potential employers in all sorts of fields.

Each summer, our team participates in two nation-wide solar car races, the Formula Sun Grand Prix (FSGP) and the American Solar Challenge (ASC). Both races are endurance-type races in which we compete against teams from other universities, driving our car for up to a week on only the power we can get from the sun.

In addition to racing our car, we also participate in numerous outreach events in the wider Chicago area. We frequently take our car to elementary schools and community service events to promote an interest in STEM education and increase awareness for “green” vehicle alternatives within our community.
Summary: We are an undergraduate student team at Northwestern that builds solar powered electric vehicles, which we race in a number of national competitions against other university teams. We are also active in the chicago community.

Name: NU Syllabus Yearbook
Description:
Syllabus, founded in 1885, is the official undergraduate yearbook of Northwestern University. Published by SPC (Students Publishing Company) and run by Northwestern students, Syllabus seeks to include memorable events and highlights of each year as well as campus groups, organizations, and living units. All seniors are invited to have their portrait taken for inclusion in our senior section. Parents and friends of graduating seniors may purchase a special ad. Syllabus yearbooks are delivered on campus in May of each year.

 

The Syllabus is created by students, for students. There are opportunities for photography, design, and copy writing ranging from academics, to sports, to clubs and organizations within Syllabus.
Summary: Syllabus, founded in 1885, is the official undergraduate yearbook of Northwestern University. Published by Students Publishing Company, Inc. Syllabus features the memorable events that make up the collective Northwestern experience.

Name: NU Thrift
Description: We are a student-run thrift store currently organizing pop-ups at the end of every quarter. Our mission is to bring affordable and sustainable casual clothing to Northwestern students, while also providing funding to student activist groups by donating our proceeds.
Summary: We are a student-run thrift store currently organizing pop-ups at the end of every quarter. Our mission is to bring affordable and sustainable casual clothing to Northwestern students, while also providing funding to student activist groups.

Name: NUIdeas
Summary: NUIdeas is a multi-level grant competition that fund's students ideas for change at NU. Applicants are coached by professionals as they advance through the 3-step process to improve on their presentations. Winners can receive up to $10k.

Name: Office of Fraternity & Sorority Life
Description:
Vision Statement:

We aim to create a socially just and responsible fraternity and sorority community.

Core Values:

  • Wellness: the physical, mental, and emotional well-being of the chapter.
  • Accountability: the knowledge of, commitment to, and willingness to accept responsibility for policies and expectations.
  • Chapter Development: the ongoing individual and collective development of members.
  • Social Justice: the holistic understanding of privilege, power, and oppression and a commitment to action.
  • Campus & Community Partnership: the contribution to campus and surrounding communities through the development of sustainable and purposeful partnerships.
Summary: The Office of Fraternity & Sorority Life provides support for the vibrant community of affiliated students at Northwestern University.

Name: Office of Student Enrichment Services
Description: Student Enrichment Services (SES) works with low-income and/or first-generation students to enhance their academic success, personal development, and professional growth. Through campus-wide partnerships, SES builds an inclusive Northwestern community by engaging students and their allies with programming and dialogue around the low-income and/or first-generation experience.
Summary:
Hear from students, staff, and faculty about their first-generation and/or low-income experience at Northwestern.
http://www.northwestern.edu/enrichment/about-us/we-are-here-video/index.html

Name: OM at Northwestern
Description: OM at Northwestern is a spiritual student group on campus whose mission is to share and cultivate an awareness of Hinduism with the Northwestern community through social events, educational discussions, and dialogue. Our vision is to have safe spaces for students to explore their curiosities in Hindu culture and traditions, while also being able to pray in comfort. All undergraduates, graduate students, faculty and staff are welcome to participate in OM's activities. Members of OM do not have to be Hindu or have a background in Hinduism.
Summary: Religious/Spiritual Hindu student organization on Northwestern University Evanston campus

Name: Omega Delta Phi Fraternity, Inc.
Description:
Alpha Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed November 25, 1997

"One Culture, Any Race."

Omega Delta Phi's Signature Events: Founders' Month Celebration, Cesar Chavez Day of Service, and Silver Rose Scholarship Banquet

You may visit the Alpha Alpha Chapter's website at http://www.nuodphi.com/.

 

National Organization Facts

National founding date: November 25, 1987

The purpose of this Brotherhood, a Service/Social fraternity dedicated to the needs and concerns of the community, is and shall be to promote and maintain the traditional values of Unity, Honesty, Integrity, and Leadership. This Brotherhood was founded in order to provide, to ANY man, a diverse fraternal experience which coincides with a higher education.

You may view the Omega Delta Phi national website at www.omegadeltaphi.com.
Summary: The Alpha Alpha Chapter of Omega Delta Phi was installed at Northwestern University on November 25th, 1997. The brothers of Omega Delta Phi make it their organization's goals to graduate its members and to serve its surrounding communities.

Name: One Book
Description: Over the summer, copies of this year's book will be delivered to the homes of every incoming first-year undergraduate and distributed to hundreds of members of Northwestern’ s faculty, staff and graduate student communities as well as community partners beyond our campus.
Summary: Nate Silver\u2019s improbably entertaining book on statistics and forecasting, The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail \u2014 but Some Don\u2019t, is Northwestern University\u2019s One Book One Northwestern all-campus read for the 2016-17 academic year.

Name: Opera Project for University Singers
Summary: Opera Project for University Singers (OPUS) is an ensemble of undergraduate singers and actors at Northwestern University who seek to direct, produce, and perform student-driven opera.

Name: Order of Omega
Description: The purpose ofthe Delta Nu chapter of Order of Omega is to recognize those fraternity men and women who have attained a high standard of leadership in interfraternity activities, to encourage them to continue along this line, and to inspire others to strive for similar conspicuous attainment. Students with Junior or Senior status, 3.5 GPA or higher, and exemplary leadership abilities will be invited to apply for membership in Fall and Spring quarters.
Summary: The purpose of the  Delta Nu chapter of Order of Omega is to recognize those fraternity men  and women who have attained a high standard of leadership in  interfraternity activities, to encourage them to continue along this  line, and to inspire others

Name: Out Da Box
Description:
Out Da Box is Northwestern's hit Campus Sketch Comedy and Improv group — their Spring Show in Shanley being the must-see show of the Northwestern Season. For more than 30 years, Out Da Box has strived to bring comedy to all Northwestern Students — of any major or background — through their consistently sold-out improv and sketch comedy shows. ODB commits to pushing social and political boundaries all while raising the bar of comedy on campus! Out Da Box has many prestigious alumni who've gone on to Second City, IO, and Comedy Central.
 
For audition information to join this one-of-a-kind group on campus, email president Arshad Baruti at arshadbaruti2022@u.northwestern.edu!
Summary: From what started as a revue of the African American Theater Ensemble in the 1970s, ODB has emerged with sold-out sketch and improv shows that provide a spotlight for students of color and marginalized identities to practice comedy on their own terms.

Name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (Graduate chapter)
Summary: The goal of this oSTEM chapter is to empower LGBTQIA+ people in STEM to succeed personally, academically, and professionally by cultivating environments and communities that nurture innovation, leadership, and advocacy.

Name: Panhellenic Association
Description: The Northwestern Panhellenic Association (PHA) consists of 12 nationally-recognized chapters. Each sorority has a chapter house on the south end of Northwestern's campus. All of the organizations have a long-standing (inter)national history and traditions as many of the Northwestern chapters are more than 100 years old. Nearly 1600 women of all backgrounds and interests are members of PHA sororities at NU. Panhellenic women are leaders and participants in campus organizations, serve the NU and Evanston communities, and excel in the classroom.
Summary: The Northwestern Panhellenic Association (PHA) consists of 12 nationally-recognized chapters. Each chapter has a sorority house on the south end of Northwestern's campus, and all of the organizations have a long-standing history at NU.

Name: Panoramic Photography
Description: Panoramic Photography serve photographers on campus through providing workshops on photography skills, group photoshoots in Chicago, and an online magazine where photographers can showcase their work.
Summary: Panoramic Photography serve photographers on campus through providing workshops on photography skills, group photoshoots in Chicago, and an online magazine where photographers can showcase their work.

Name: Paracombatives Jujutsu
Description:
History: In 1977, John Lewis, a former member of the US Army special forces and Northwestern instructor, founded the ParaCombatives Martial Arts Institute and started the Northwestern University Ju-Jutsu program in Evanston, Illinois.  During the ensuing nineteen years Lewis trained thousands of Northwestern students and graduated many black belt instructors in Miyama Ryu Ju-Jutsu and ParaCombatives Ju-Jutsu. Lewis is also noted for inventing and developing the Ju-jo and Ju-jo Magnum (Ju-Jutsu lanyardstick) while at Northwestern.


Practice schedule: Practices change quarterly. For spring 2019, our practices are Sundays 10-11:45 AM, Mondays 6:45-9 PM, and Thursdays 8-10:15 PM, all in Henry Crown Sports Pavilion studio 1B.


League affiliation: None

 

Club dues: $15/quarter.

 

Practice locations: Classes are held in Henry Crown Sports Pavilion, studio 1B.
Summary: Paracombatives JuJutsu teaches students self-defense in a practical setting. We provide students the skills necessary to protect themselves against violence in an urban environment. Our club welcomes students of all experience levels.

Name: Parliamentary Debate Union
Summary: Parliamentary debate is a form of extemporaneous debate in which two teams of two people go against each other. You can debate about almost anything and no prior experience is needed!

Name: Peer Health Exchange
Description:
Our Mission

Peer Health Exchange’s mission is to empower young people with the knowledge, skills, and resources to make healthy decisions.

We do this by training college students to teach a skills-based health curriculum in under-resourced high schools across the country.

Our Vision

Peer Health Exchange, with our partners, will advance health equity and improve health outcomes for young people.

Core Values

Our core values form the foundation of our organizational culture and guide our approach to achieving our mission and vision.

Health

We believe that all young people deserve equal access to the knowledge, skills, and resources that support their physical and mental well-being. In partnership with communities, we exist to help young people achieve more positive and equitable health outcomes.

Equity

We believe that all young people deserve equitable opportunities to learn about and act for their health. For our part in that work, we deliver a culturally appropriate, trauma-informed curriculum that focuses on the barriers facing the most marginalized youth. To do so, we address the effects of power and privilege in our work and strive to be anti-racist, anti-nationalist, anti-queerphobic, anti-transphobic, anti-sexist, anti-classist, and anti-ableist.

Agency

We believe in the potential of every young person. We work to empower young people to make active, informed choices about their health. In turn, we recognize the value each one of us brings to our work. We commit to making full use of our own agency as individuals and as an organization in service of our goals.

Communication

We rely on direct and honest exchange for all that we do. We value communication as essential to articulating our vision and goals, forming strong relationships, working through challenges, and learning from and with our young people and partners.

Impact

We know that achieving long-term success will require reflection, innovation, and sustained effort. To further our impact, we hold ourselves to meaningful and measurable outcomes, evaluate our successes and challenges openly, and act on what we learn.

History

In 1999, six Yale undergraduates began teaching health workshops in New Haven public schools in order to fill the gap left by an underfunded, understaffed district health program. In 2003, the founding members of the group established Peer Health Exchange to replicate this successful program in other communities with unmet health education needs. Since then, we have trained more than 8,500 college student volunteers to deliver effective health education to over 115,000 public high school students in New York City, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay Area, and Washington, DC, seeing strong initial results.
Summary: Peer Health Exchange\u2019s mission is to empower young people with the knowledge, skills, and resources to make healthy decisions.

Name: Peer Inclusion Educators
Description: Peer Inclusion Educators (PIE) is a student organization dedicated to fostering an inclusive learning environment for issues surrounding personal awareness and social justice to peers through facilitation of specific and intentional programming to campus organizations such as student groups, Greek letter organizations and residential communities.
Summary: Peer Inclusion Educators (PIE) is a student organization dedicated to fostering an inclusive learning environment for issues surrounding personal awareness and social justice to peers through facilitation of specific and intentional programming to campus

Name: Phi Alpha Delta
Description: The fundamental objective of Phi Alpha Delta is to assist undergraduate students to make an informed choice in selecting law as a career, in deciding which law school to attend, and in preparing for the rigors of law school. Phi Alpha Delta is an international coed professional fraternity, and it remains the only Law Fraternity with a national Pre-Law Program committed to meeting the needs of undergraduate students interested in the law.
Summary: Phi Alpha Delta is an international coed professional fraternity, and it remains the only Law Fraternity with a national Pre-Law Program committed to meeting the needs of undergraduate students interested in the law.

Name: Phi Delta Epsilon
Description: The Illinois Gamma chapter of PhiDE International Medical Fraternity at Northwestern University provides its members with mentorship, leadership and volunteering opportunities, social activities and scientific education. Our international philanthropy is Children's Miracle Network Hospitals, which we fundraise for every year. PhiDE brings high-profile speakers to NU's campus to discuss important issues in the medical field, such as the new health care plan, the role of research and funding in medicine, and even speakers that advice pre-medical students on their path into medical school. Our recruitment of members occurs in the fall and spring quarters.
Summary: Co-ed International Medical Fraternity that provides, mentoring, networking, leadership development, scientific education, volunteering opportunities, and a support community on the NU campus.

Name: Phi Gamma Nu
Description: Phi Gamma Nu was a business fraternity founded at Northwestern in 1924. Recently the organization has re-instated its alpha chapter here and is in the building process. We accept students of all majors and backgrounds who have an interest in business. We intend to run events in philanthropy, career networking and develop communications skills among our members.
Summary: This is a professional development organization for Northwestern Undergraduate students of all majors.

Name: Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia
Description:
Iota Chapter, Northwestern University
630 Emerson St.

Installed: April 29th, 1910

Chapter President: Matthew Shipley

Organization Facts

National Founding Date: October 6, 1898 (New England Conservatory)

Object: The object of this fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit, the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students, the advancement of music in America, and a loyalty to the Alma Mater

Colors: Red, Black and Gold

Philanthropy: Mills Music Mission

You may visit the local website at: http://iotasinfonia.org

You may visit the national website at http://www.sinfonia.org
Summary: The object of this fraternity shall be for the development of the best and truest fraternal spirit, the mutual welfare and brotherhood of musical students, the advancement of music in America, and a loyalty to the Alma Mater

Name: Phi Sigma Pi, National Honor Fraternity
Description:
Our members are some of most involved students on campus. They are part of organizations including social fraternities/sororities, honor societies, athletic teams, student government and pre-professional groups. We embrace involvement in other organizations and membership in Phi Sigma Pi poses no conflict with membership in any other campus organization.

Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity is a gender inclusive fraternity open to undergraduate students attending four-year universities. Our purpose is to bring together some of the brightest and most motivated students on campus to encourage three ideals:

1) The acquisition and dissemination of information and knowledge through scholarship.

2) The application of professional skills and the fostering of leadership qualities by promoting and advancing the welfare of humanity.

3) The fostering of non-discriminatory, fraternal fellowship within our ranks.

Together, these three ideals are known as "The Tripod" of Phi Sigma Pi. As a member of Phi Sigma Pi, you must strive to embody these three principles. In turn, you take the first step in a lifelong journey filled with scholarship, leadership and fellowship. 

Phi Sigma Pi is open to both male and female students who meet the following criteria:

- Must have completed a minimum of one quarter at a university. 
- Must have a minimum 3.00 cumulative GPA on a 4.00 scale.

Phi Sigma Pi enables you to discover your potential, allowing you to change and inspire the world you live in. 

Brothers Are We.
Summary: Phi Sigma Pi is a gender inclusive National Honor Fraternity. It is a unique organization combining the best attributes of an honor society, service group and social fraternity. Phi Sigma Pi provides a supportive community and memorable experiences.

Name: Philanthropy Choir
Description: Philanthropy Choir is a student-run community service show choir dedicated to bringing quality musical performances to locations such as retirement homes, women’s shelters, and hospitals. This club is perfect for students of all experience levels who seek an outlet to perform music, have fun, and do good. Additionally, the choir will host video fundraisers throughout the year and donate all proceeds to charities.
Summary: Philanthropy Choir is a student-run community service show choir dedicated to bringing quality musical performances to locations such as retirement homes, women\u2019s shelters, and hospitals.

Name: Physicians for Human Rights Student Program
Description: The Physicians for Human Rights Student Program is a chapter of a national student program committed to advocacy for health and human rights violations on undergraduate and medical school campuses.
Summary: The Physicians for Human Rights Student Program is a chapter of a national student program committed to advocacy for health and human rights violations on undergraduate and medical school campuses.
