Name: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment
Description: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment (PIE) is Northwestern University's chapter of the International Game Developers Association. We run game tutorials, host game jams, and provide students with the resources to make their very own games. It can be tabletop games, video games, card games, or whatever you can think of.
Summary: Pioneers of Interactive Entertainment (PIE) is Northwestern University's chapter of the International Game Developers Association.

Name: Planned Parenthood Generation Action
Description: Planned Parenthood Generation Action is a movement of young people across identities and issues that organizes with, by, and for their generation in order to achieve reproductive freedom. Planned Parenthood Generation Action at Northwestern University will work with local Planned Parenthood staff to learn about and engage in youth organizing, leadership development, voter engagement programs, and infrastructure building.
Summary: Planned Parenthood Generation Action at NU will work with local Planned Parenthood staff to learn about and engage in youth organizing, leadership development, voter engagement, and other activities to promote reproductive rights and freedom for all.

Name: Plant-it Purple Graduate Garden
Description:
Plant-it Purple Graduate Gardens is a community garden located on the patio of the Technological Institute on Northwestern’s Evanston campus.  The garden provides a place where graduate students, staff, and others can interact and relax outside of their labs and offices.  Working in and utilizing the garden fosters relationships between graduate students from many different disciplines by bringing them together to cultivate and enjoy a living project.  The garden is a benefit and an outlet to students, staff, and the community.

 

Our organization is most active through our listserv and Facebook page (which is linked at the top right). Come join us, we'd love to have you!
Summary: We are a community garden located on the patio of the Technological Institute on the Evanston campus.  The garden is a place where graduate students, staff, and others can interact and relax outside of their labs and offices.

Name: Platypus Affiliated Society
Description: We are the Northwestern Chapter of the Platypus Affiliated Society. Platypus is a project for the self-criticism, self-education, and, ultimately, the practical reconstitution of a Marxian Left. The Platypus Affiliated Society, established in December 2006, organizes reading groups, public fora, research and journalism focused on problems and tasks inherited from the “Old” (1920s-30s), “New” (1960s-70s) and post-political (1980s-90s) Left for the possibilities of emancipatory politics today.
Summary: We are the Northwestern Chapter of the Platypus Affiliated Society. Platypus organizes reading groups, public fora, research and journalism on the history and present tasks of the Left and Marxism.

Name: Polish American Student Alliance
Description: The Northwestern University Polish-American Student Alliance (PASA) was founded in the fall of 1996. Since its establishment, PASA has grown tremendously. PASA's mission is simple: to promote cultural awareness of all things Polish. The organization does not restrict membership solely to those of Polish descent. It welcomes students with any interest in Polish history, society, and culture. Its dual goal is to teach as well as to learn. We have accomplished this in the past by advocating for Polish language education, hosting bonfires, and holding an annual Polish Culture Night.
Summary: The Polish American Student Alliance (PASA) seeks to connect the Northwestern community with Chicagoland's rich Polish traditions. PASA commits itself to building a strong community among its members and working with other cultural student groups.

Name: Pre-Dental Society
Description: Northwestern Pre-Dental Society (NUPDS) strives to unite NU pre-dental students and serves as a resource as students explore careers in oral healthcare or prepare to enter dental school.  NUPDS is focused on educating students about career options in dentistry and offering support to undergraduates navigating pre-dental preparations including course requirements, volunteer opportunities, and DAT test preparation.  NUPDS also aims to strengthen networking connections with dental professionals and students in the greater Chicago area as well as within the NU community.
Summary: The pre-dental society is a group dedicated to pre-dental preparation, education and service in the field of oral healthcare.  We strive to provide resources and a community for students pursuing pre-dental studies.

Name: Pre-Med Peer Mentoring
Description:
Many pre-med students, especially freshman, may not know many upperclassmen students because their classes consist of mostly underclassmen. Pre-Med Peer Mentoring Program (PPMP) is designed to bridge the gap and provide a simple way for pre-med freshman and sophomores to connect with upperclassmen mentors. 

 

This program promotes unity and collaboration within the pre-med community by creating a formal program to match upperclassmen that have successfully completed their pre-med coursework with underclassmen that are hoping to do the same. Upperclassmen mentors share their personal insights in succeeding in premed classes, along with many other personal experiences as a pre-med student.

 

For more info, please contact us at ppmp@u.northwestern.edu or click the blue globe icon right below to visit our website and read more about our program, meet our mentors, and more.
Summary: The purpose of the Pre-Med Peer Mentoring Program is to match pre-med underclassmen with successful pre-med upperclassmen to provide their personal insight on how to succeed as a pre-med student.

Name: Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University
Description: The Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University is a group dedicated to students who are pursing a pre-vet agenda on their path to veterinary school. The objectives of the Pre-Veterinary Society shall be to educate students interested in a career in veterinary medicine through guest lectures, meetings and community service. The society will aid students in the admissions process, promote connections between pre-veterinary students, and provide resources and guidance through the support of the University Academic Advising Center.
Summary: The Pre-Veterinary Society at Northwestern University is a group dedicated to students who are pursing a pre-veterinary agenda on their path to veterinary school.

Name: Project RISHI
ShortName: Rural India Social and Health Improvement
Description: Our purpose is to establish a sustainable community clinic in Northern India and provide medical care, health education, and easy access to health resources. Annual fundraising efforts culminate in a student-led trip to the clinic each summer. We will improve the infrastructure and aid the clinic such that it will become the center of the community's health system.  Throughout the year, members develop projects that will be implemented in Charnia, and network to create relationships with sponsors. During past trips to Charnia, members have conducted needs assessments, analyzed data, held health camps, and formed relationships with community members.  Currently, the Northwestern chapter is advised by physicians at Feinberg School of Medicine.
Summary: Project RISHI (Rural India Social and Health Improvement) is a national non-profit organization dedicated to advancing public health and addressing social issues in rural India. We are partnered with a site in Northern India named Charnia.

Name: Project SOAR
Description: Project SOAR matches one Northwestern student with one Evanston child so that the two can have a mutually enriching experience. As a Northwestern mentor, you will meet with your mentee on a weekly basis. Meetings can be throughout Evanston or Chicago and are planned based on your own schedule. SOAR is not a tutoring program, it is meant to provide role models for those children that want and need them.
Summary: Project SOAR pairs Northwestern students with at-risk Evanston youth for one-on-one mentoring.

Name: Project Sunshine
Description: Project Sunshine is a nonprofit organization focused on bringing joy to pediatric patients and their often forgotten caregivers! We work on delivering "the healing power of play" to children in hospitals through interactive events such as Teleplay, care packages, and arts and crafts. We also actively fundraise for our cause in order to raise money to support the national Project Sunshine headquarters, as well as strive to embody the organization values of SHINE (Safe, Healthy, Inclusive, Nurturing, Engaging).
Summary: Delivering the healing power of play to pediatric patients!

Name: Psi Chi
Description: Psi Chi, the International Honor Society in Psychology, was founded in 1929 with a mission to encourage excellence in scholarship and advance the science of psychology. More than three-quarters of a million lifetime members have joined including Distinguished Members such as Drs. Albert Bandura, B. F. Skinner, and Phillip Zimbardo. A few popular Membership Benefits include international recognition for academic excellence, as well as access to psychology-related publications and more than $400,000 in annual awards and grants. Lifetime Membership is open to undergraduate and graduate students, transfer students, full-time faculty members, and alumni. Individuals become members by joining their local Psi Chi chapter. See our specific membership requirements. After potential members are approved by a local faculty advisor, all 1,150+ Psi Chi chapters process their new members on our online system. The Psi Chi Central Office, located in Chattanooga, Tennessee, manages the Society under the direction of the Board of Directors, who are Psi Chi members elected by the chapters to guide the Organization. Psi Chi is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies and is an affiliate of the American Psychological Association (APA) and the Association for Psychological Science (APS). Our sister honor society is Psi Beta, the national honor society in psychology for community and junior colleges.
Summary: Recognizing and promoting excellence in the science and application of psychology.

Name: Public Affairs Residential College
Description:
The Public Affairs Residential College (PARC) is a south campus living community at Northwestern University focused on integrating public affairs concepts into the living environment. The building houses 70 students in single and double-occupancy rooms. Floors are co-ed, with students from different genders living on different sides of each floor. This building is available to all undergraduate students.

As a Residential College, PARC has special access to university resources and faculty which make our living experience particularly unique!  As a PARCer you can participate in Firesides with professors, an amazing yearly formal, weekly Munchies and Cookies and Conversation, trips to Chicago and cool places on campus, philanthropy events, Intramural Sports and much, much more!

At PARC, almost everything you need is right next door, if not in PARC itself. But for a Res College to be truly great, it has to be more than a pretty building in a convenient part of Campus; it has to be a community. What really sets PARC apart is the people. Even though our name says “Public Affairs,” the students who live here are diverse in their areas of study. While we have our fair share of SESP and Medill students, each of Northwestern’s six schools is generously represented in PARC’s student population, even McCormick (the walk to Tech from NMQ is really not that bad). Your fellow PARCers will help you grow both academically and personally. Not only will you learn from PARC’s college staff and guest speakers; you will also learn from your fellow PARCers themselves. Students in PARC hold leadership positions in countless organizations on campus, whether for student-run publications, engineering societies, student government, and more. PARC fosters dialogue between students so that ideas can flow freely between us. At PARC you won’t just find a dorm; you’ll find a home.
Summary: The Public Affairs Residential College (PARC) is a south campus living community at Northwestern University focused on integrating public affairs concepts into the living environment. The building houses 70 students in single and double-occupancy rooms.

Name: Public Speaking Club
Description: NU Public Speaking Club provides a unique opportunity to help members develop their speaking, listening and leadership skills. Members learn techniques for overcoming stage anxiety, connecting with any audience, assimilating verbal and non-verbal communication skills, and achieving a commanding executive presence. We have weekly meetings to practice giving prepared/impromptu speeches and provide feedback to each other. We also organize workshops, guest lecture series, and social events.
Summary: Our mission is to empower NU Students to become eloquent speakers and confident leaders through continuous opportunities to develop their communications and leadership skills in an inclusive community.

Name: Pura Playa
Description:
Pura Playa is Northwestern University's plastic waste reduction team. We are an Engineers for a Sustainable World (ESW) project (though students from all disciplines are welcome to join) that aims to address plastic use in our community and its effect on the environment.

Our method is to educate ourselves and our community about plastic pollution and reduce plastic usage at Northwestern University.

We are currently working on the Northwestern Thinks Outside the Bottle campaign, encouraging the University to go bottled water-free. We are also working on a recycling project and a microplastic filtration project.
Summary: Pura Playa is Northwestern University's plastic waste reduction team. We are an Engineers for a Sustainable World (ESW) project that aims to address plastic use in our community and its effect on the environment.

Name: Purple Crayon Players
Description: Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre and community service organization that produces professionally written theatre for young audiences within our mainstage season, as well as special projects and events by, with, and for youth. This year, you can use theater to engage, inspire, and educate audiences of all ages as an actor, director, designer, storyteller, teaching artist, team member or project leader.
Summary: Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre company on the Northwestern University campus committed to creating high quality productions, events, and educational materials regarding all aspects of theatre for young audiences.

Name: Purple Haze
Description:
Formed in 1996, Purple Haze has been singin', dancin' and lovin' for 25 years! Completely run by students, we rehearse on a weekly basis and put on a killer show every quarter. In the fall, we invite other groups from nearby colleges to perform in our Best of the Midwest concert. In the winter, we combine a cappella with games and improv for Too Much A Cappella Makes the Baby Go Deaf, based on the Neo-Futurists' popular Chicago show. And in the spring, we devise a new script to go with our songs and a theme of our choosing.

Aside from campus shows, Purple Haze also performs throughout the Chicagoland area.  In the past, we have even sung on ABC Chicago News! Purple Haze has released nine studio albums, with many songs recognized on national a cappella compilation CDs. Mouth Off, an a cappella podcast, called us “the best you’re going to hear out of the whole midwestern United States” and “the group that everyone wants to party with!” Our music is available on iTunes and Spotify.

Purple Haze goes on tour every year, alternating between domestic and international trips. We have recently flown to Fort Lauderdale, FL where we held workshops at various local schools and traversed the South Florida area. Past tours also include Havana, Cuba, Montreal, and Amsterdam. We also compete biennially in the International Championship of Collegiate a cappella, making it to the ICCA Semifinals in 2016 and 2018! But most importantly, Purple Haze is a group of friends who love to sing together!
Summary: In the vibrant Northwestern a cappella community, Purple Haze prides itself on maintaining the highest standards of musicality while keeping the fun and love alive!

Name: Queer Pride Graduate Students Assocation
Description:
Northwestern University’s Queer Pride Graduate Student Group is an award-winning social, advocacy, and academic group for the LGBTQ+ graduate student community at Northwestern. Founded in 2005, our membership now includes more than 400 graduate students. QPGSA is committed to develop an inclusive and affirming sense of community among the LGBTQ+ graduate students at Northwestern. We do this in four primary ways

 

  • Advocacy: As a campus advocacy group, increasing visibility and awareness of the interests impacting Northwestern's LGBTQ+ communities.
  • Social: As a social group, providing extracurricular and networking opportunities for graduate and professional students.
  • Service & Activism: As a political advocacy group, working in concert with various LGBTQIA+ organizations to advance the interests of and provide services for the broader Chicago LGBTQ+ community. 
  • Academic: As an academic group, promoting and encouraging intellectual debate over the issues that impact these communities broadly. We do this primarily through our annual Queertopia conference, which is going into its 14th year.

 

In addition to various quarterly and monthly social events, we also work collaboratively with NU’s Rainbow Alliance, the Gender and Sexuality Resource Center, Kellogg’s Gay and Lesbian Management Association, Northwestern Law’s OUTLaw group, the Women’s Center, and Northwestern Medical School’s Out Network. Further, we regularly collaborate with other TGS graduate associations, including the Black Graduate Student Association, Communidad Latinx, and Graduate Women Across Northwestern. In the past, QPGSA has also teamed up with various Chicagoland LGBTQ+ organizations, such as Equality Illinois, Transformative Justice Law Project, and Howard Brown Health.

For more details and to see upcoming events, please check out our website: https://www.nuqpgsa.com/
Summary: The Queer Pride Graduate Student Association (QPGSA) is an award-winning social, advocacy, and academic group for the LGBTQ+ graduate student community at Northwestern University.

Name: Quizbowl
Description:
Northwestern Quizbowl participates in academic, buzzer-based competitions primarily held in the Midwest, including novice tournaments, regular events, and national championships.

We frequently travel to the University of Chicago, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Michigan, among others.

We also host middle school, high school, and collegiate tournaments over the course of the academic year. We have also hosted 2005 ACF Nationals, the 2011 PACE NSC, and the 2012 College National Championships of the National History Bowl.
Summary: Northwestern Quizbowl participates in academic buzzer competitions against other colleges.

Name: Radius Theatre
Description: Founded in 2018, Radius Theatre is dedicated to empowering, celebrating, and highlighting non-white artists. We are most passionate about creating activism-centered art that puts artists of color at the forefront and organizing community dialogues surrounding race/ethnicity in the entertainment realm.
Summary: Radius Theatre is dedicated to creating theatrical opportunities for and amplifying the voices of students of color, or any students that feel they are misrepresented at Northwestern or in the entertainment industry as a whole.

Name: Rainbow Alliance
Description:
Check out our website:https://sites.northwestern.edu/rainbow/

Our purpose is to create a safe space at Northwestern University that encourages personal development for Northwestern’s 2SLGBTQ+ community and coalition building among our intersecting communities. To this end we:

  • Develop programming to actively address and solve issues surrounding gender and sexuality in the Northwestern community.
  • Provide a supportive and fun social environment that creates a sense of community.
  • Fight homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, heterosexism, and genderism and the intersecting oppressions experienced within our diverse community.
Summary: Our purpose is to create a safe space at Northwestern University that encourages personal development for Northwestern\u2019s 2SLGBTQ+ community and coalition building among our intersecting communities.

Name: RAISO
Description:
RAISO (Responsible AI Student Organization) is an open space for Northwestern students from various disciplines to learn and discuss how Artificial Intelligence systems are impacting our current and future society. As AI is creeping into areas such as education, healthcare, criminal justice, media, etc., we want to allow students a space to reflect on the potential benefits and ethical drawbacks of these systems and to collaborate with students from a wide variety of majors/minors to create and evaluate responsible AI systems.

 

 

By being a member of this community, you'll hear from speakers and activists working on responsible AI innovation and AI ethics, participate in reading groups to learn more about AI and it's interactions with your major, gain connections and possible funding for internships focused on Responsible AI, join a project group to work with students from different backgrounds on a topic of your interest, attend AI workshops and more.

 

 

We strongly encourage peers from backgrounds beyond CS/engineering to be a part of this group! Whether your interests are in global development, critical race studies, gender studies, psychology, social policy, etc, your knowledge and background are extremely valuable in helping create, shape, and evaluate responsible AI systems as they're deployed in our society. (Background or knowledge of AI is NOT required to be a part of the community!)

Please fill out this form if you're interested in joining our community: https://forms.gle/mbASmYcZUrn5Yvns8

 

 

Quick Articles for info on societal impacts of AI/AI ethics:
https://bdtechtalks.com/2019/04/15/trustworthy-ethical-artificial-intelligence/
https://www.technologyreview.com/2020/07/31/1005824/decolonial-ai-for-everyone/
https://scale.com/blog/if-youre-de-biasing-the-model-its-too-late
Summary: The Responsible AI Student Organization (RAISO) is an open community for students from all majors to learn about artificial intelligence and discuss its impacts on our society.

Name: Real Food at Northwestern
Description:
Real Food at NU is a student-led campaign at Northwestern University looking to shift the university's food system to one that is more socially just and environmentally sustainable.

We aim at getting NU to pledge to shift 20% of its food purchases to real food (as opposed to industrial food) -- food that is good for the earth it grows in, the farmers who grow it, the workers who process and sell it, the communities through which it passes, and the consumers who ultimately eat it.

FYI: The "realness" of food can be measured by the real food calculator tool, based on where the food is grown, processed, and consumed and who makes it all happen. [To check out more about the real food calculator, go here: http://www.realfoodchallenge.org/sites/g/files/g809971/f/201403/Real%20Food%20Guide%20Version%201.0%20March%202014_0.pdf ]

Have any questions? Comments? Want to get involved? Feel free to email us!
Summary: Real Food at NU, the Northwestern University student chapter of The Real Food Challenge, aims to build a just and sustainable food system at NU.

Name: Red Cross Club at Northwestern University
Description: We, as the Northwestern branch of the American Red Cross, work to provide relief to victims of disaster, strive to raise awareness for all of those in need, hold quarterly blood drives, raise funds to support the Red Cross' various initiatives, and support the Red Cross principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality, independence, voluntary service, unity, and universality.
Summary: Northwestern University chapter of the American Red Cross.

Name: Reformed University Fellowship
Description:
Reformed University Fellowship (RUF) is a Christian community at Northwestern seeking to reach out to people from diverse backgrounds with the message of the Gospel and to help one another live our lives in response to who Jesus is and what he has done for us. We meet every Tuesday night at 9pm for our large group meeting and offer a number of small groups that gather throughout the week to study the Bible, discuss a book, pray together, and build relationships with one another. We also host numerous social events and service opportunities throughout the year. Regardless of your beliefs or doubts, we would love to have you join us.

 

For more information on RUF and to be added to our mailing list, please visit www.rufnorthwestern.org
Summary: Reformed University Fellowship (RUF) is a Christian community at Northwestern seeking to reach out to people from diverse backgrounds with the message of the gospel and to help one another live our lives in response to who Jesus is and what he has done

Name: Refresh Dance Crew
Description:
To stay up to date on Refresh, Like us on Facebook at:

www.facebook.com/RefreshDanceCrew

Refresh Dance Crew was born in 2005 from a group of friends who wanted to learn how to dance. Since then, Refresh has grown into a large family of dancers with different styles that range from popping and breaking to choreography. People of all skill levels–from beginners to trained dancers–are welcome to attend weekly open sessions and free choreography classes. Additionally, Refresh holds auditions every quarter for specific shows. Refresh fosters a space of growth and community through a shared love of dance and three core values: respect, family, hustle.
Summary: Refresh Dance Crew was born in 2005 from a group of friends who wanted to learn how to dance. Since then, Refresh has grown into a large family of dancers with different styles that range from popping and breaking to choreography.

Name: Relay For Life
Description:
Relay for Life is the largest nationwide fundraiser for the American Cancer Society, raising hundreds of millions of dollars for cancer research and advocacy. Here at Northwestern, we have raised over $100,000 for 4 of the last 6 years and host an annual event with hundreds of participants. Throughout the year, we focus our efforts on advocacy, fundraising, and outreach, culminating in our final event in May, which is held in the Henry Crown Sports and Aquatics Pavilion.

Sign up for Relay at www.relayforlife.org/northwesternil

Watch a Relay promo video here: http://youtu.be/RF17W0cXe2A
Summary: Relay for Life is the largest nationwide fundraiser for the American Cancer Society, raising over $400 million for cancer research and advocacy. We regularly raise over $100,000 and host an annual event with hundreds of participants.

Name: Religious & Spiritual Life
Description:
The primary mission of the Office of the University Chaplains is to promote spiritual growth and nurture at Northwestern University.

Spiritual maturity entails

    * reflection on the meaning and purpose of human existence
    * appreciation for the depth and expanse of life
    * articulation of beliefs
    * development of spiritual resources to sustain one through good times and bad
    * a willingness to rethink values and to apply them to life
    * a concern for the welfare of humankind and a capacity to act with confidence upon that concern

Spiritual maturity is enhanced by critical dialogue and community with members of one's own tradition and through encounter with differing traditions.

Northwestern is privileged to enjoy a rich and diverse religious life, which supports and challenges the intellectual pursuits of the University.

We are delighted to introduce you to some of the organizations and programs at Northwestern that provide occasions for religious reflection and opportunities for worship, service, and action. Through the various religious traditions represented on campus, students may seek moral and spiritual insights into the meaning and value of human life and experience.

We invite you to explore the rich and varied options available to Northwestern students. Our office is open to all inquiries from students, their parents, and campus visitors. Campus religious leaders and advisors are always ready to help students broaden their faith.

It is our hope that together we can build a community of conscience and spiritual awareness and support the University's search for and celebration of "whatsoever things are true."
Summary: The primary mission of the Office of Religious & Spiritual Life is to promote spiritual growth and nurture at Northwestern University.  Spiritual maturity entails      * reflection on the meaning and purpose of human existence

Name: Renaissance Singers
Description: The Renaissance Singers is a student-led vocal ensemble that performs diverse repertoire from the Renaissance and Baroque eras, focused on the promotion of early music and, occasionally, commissions from student composers.
Summary: The Renaissance Singers is a student-led vocal ensemble that performs diverse repertoire from the Renaissance and Baroque eras, focused on the promotion of early music and, occasionally, commissions from student composers.

Name: Residential College Board
Description:
We serve as an advisory body for the residential colleges here at Northwestern University. Our membership is composed of the presidents of the ten residential colleges and eight executive officers. Each of the seven vice presidents specializes in an area specifically relevant to the residential college community: academic affairs, financial affairs, inter-college relations, philanthropic affairs, public relations, and social affairs. The president presides over the entire Board and coordinates long-term planning.

We hold general meetings every week in which we deal with problems and issues that arise during the week in individual colleges, plan activities for the entire residential college community, and discuss items for presentation to the University. In addition to these weekly meetings, the Executive Board meets every week to guide the Board's agenda.

The Residential College Board is responsible for a number of large-scale social events every year, including the Fall Formal, Winter Quarter Quiz Bowl, and the annual RCB Field Day.
Summary: RCB is comprised of the 10 Residential Colleges at Northwestern. Our motto, a tradition of living and learning, exemplifies our goal: to bring an enhanced sense of community to your dorm life and to help students learn outside the classroom.

Name: Residential College of Cultural & Community Studies
Description:
WELCOME! The Residential College of Cultural and Community Studies (CCS) is one big family of diverse and dedicated students. Its intimate setting and small population easily allow it be one of Northwestern’s best kept secrets. CCS houses 42 women, men, and all else on or off the gender spectrum in single, double, and triple-occupancy rooms. 

Students from as far away as China and as close as the western suburbs live together in CCS, one of Northwestern University's oldest residential colleges. Our majors range from RTVF to psychology to engineering, but we share a love of diverse cultures and concern for our local and global communities.

When not out enjoying the social scene around us on North Campus, we work with our fellows and outside organizations to put on activities like firesides, community service projects, and IM sports. For trips into Chicago, the Noyes El stop is conveniently close. Favorite outings include trips to ethnic neighborhoods, musical and dramatic performances, and camping.
Summary: The Residential College of Cultural & Community Studies (CCS) is one big family of diverse and dedicated students. Its intimate setting and small population easily allow it be one of Northwestern's best kept secrets.

Name: Residential Life
Description: University Residential Life (URL) is a Student Affairs department. Our vision is "Engage and educate: Creating communities of learners, leaders, and responsible citizens. "Through our mission we strive to promote a sense of community and encourage the growth and development of each student in a variety of living environments. Our program seeks to complement the academic mission of Northwestern University by providing students opportunities for learning in a safe, diverse, and respectful environment.
Summary: University Residential Life (URL) is a Student Affairs department. Our vision is "Engage and educate: Creating communities of learners, leaders, and responsible citizens. "Through our mission we strive to promote a sense of community and encourage the

Name: Residential Services
Summary: Residential Services at Northwestern is committed to providing an environment that fosters the academic and personal success of every student.

Name: Rince Cait
Description: Rince Cait is a Northwestern student group dedicated to bringing Irish Dancing and culture to the Northwestern community. We are a group of Irish dancers from all skill/ability levels and backgrounds who choreograph, practice, and perform traditional and modern Irish dance routines.
Summary: Rince Cait is a Northwestern student group comprised of dancers of all skill/ability levels dedicated to bringing Irish Dancing and culture to the Northwestern community.

Name: Rip & Roll
Description: Rip and Roll club is a collection of rollerbladers and people who ride ripsticks (a form of skateboard) for recreation. We believe that these sports have suffered from a lack of organization, leading to a majority of solo riders. We aim to bring students together through a common appreciation for adventure and freedom. We will build a community of friends and create a safe atmosphere to learn new techniques and celebrate the joys of "ripping and rolling."
Summary: A collection of rollerbladers and people who ride ripsticks aiming to bring students together to create a community of adventure and freedom

Name: Rogers/1856 Orrington
Description: Rogers House & 1856 Orrington are two separate communities located within the sorority quad on the south side of campus, that share a programming board. The joint communities have just under 60 residents, and the small community allows for a more tight-knit and close community.
Summary: Rogers House & 1856 Orrington are two separate communities located within the sorority quad on the south side of campus. These two communities share a programming board, and together house just under 60 residents.

Name: Russian Club
Description: Our purpose is to give Russian students of all levels and even students with no Russian knowledge an outlet outside of class to learn more about the Russian language and culture in an informal setting. We want to host fun events that improve students speaking ability (something not often focused on in class in favor of grammar and reading comprehension) and their knowledge of Soviet Russian and modern Russian food and culture.
Summary: Our purpose is to give Russian students of all levels an outlet outside of class to learn more about Russian language and culture. We want to host fun events that improve students speaking and their knowledge of Soviet and modern Russian food and culture

Name: Sargent
Summary: On-campus living facility.

Name: Save a Child's Heart
Description:
Northwestern for Save a Child's Heart, known on campus as NU for SACH, supports an Israeli-based organization called Save a Child’s Heart (SACH) that provides life-saving cardiac surgeries for children from developing countries who cannot afford these treatments. In fact, half of the children SACH cares for are from the Palestinian Authority, Jordan, and Iraq, caring for for any child regardless of race, gender, ethnicity, or religion.


Throughout the year, NU for SACH hosts fundraisers on campus and around Evanston to promote the organization. In addition, we also promote the importance of heart health and medicine through seminars and speakers. Overall, NU for SACH works to fundraiser and educate about the incredible organization of Save a Child's Heart.
Summary: NU for SACH supports an Israeli-based organization called Save a Child\u2019s Heart (SACH) that provides life-saving cardiac surgeries for children from developing countries who cannot afford these treatments.

Name: Scene+Heard
Description: Scene+Heard is purposed to connect artists and audiences and chronicle culture, on-campus and off. It was created on the basis of making arts more accessible and engaging to a broader network of students, rather than the more insular theater and music communities that often comprise the majority of performance audiences at Northwestern. The website, sceneandheardonline.com, will make information about performances more accessible to students through the prolific publication of new artistic and cultural events and happenings in our community.
Summary: Scene+Heard is Northwestern's official online arts and culture publication. Through dynamic content, exclusive interviews, and first-hand coverage of the best events on-campus and Chicago, we're transforming the way students interact with culture.

Name: Science Olympiad
Description: TBA
Summary: A volunteer-based organization committed to hosting a Science Olympiad invitational for Division C teams in Illinois and surrounding states and coordinating volunteers for Illinois Regional and State tournaments.

Name: Science Policy Outreach Task Force
Description: The Science Policy Outreach Task Force (SPOT) is a non-partisan organization of Northwestern University researchers focused on advocating for science, evidence-based reasoning, and scientifically-sound policy to the voting-aged public and policymakers. Members have the opportunity to learn and put effective science advocacy into political action through events to educate voters, meetings to educate and collaborate with policymakers, educational seminars to learn about the interface of science and policy, and activities with external science policy entities. As a group, our combined efforts allow for a greater impact toward the advocacy of science in politics than any one of us acting alone.
Summary: Advocating for science and evidenced-based decision making to policymakers and the voting public.

Name: Seabury Hall
Description: Seabury Hall is between north and south campus (right across from Technological Institute) and houses 24 students in single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a closed suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is available only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.\ufeff
Summary: Seabury Hall is between north and south campus (right across from Technological Institute) and houses 24 students in single-occupancy rooms, arranged in a closed suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is

Name: Seesaw Theatre
Description:
Seesaw Theatre produces highly interactive, multi-sensory theatre for autistic and otherwise disabled individuals. Founded with the belief that all individuals should have the opportunity to experience theatre in a welcoming, safe environment, we offer autistic and otherwise disabled individuals and their parents the ability to experience theatre together free from societal expectations of what behavior should look like in a theatrical setting. Our theatre spaces are used in innovative ways to create an entire world to absorb, full of features that engage a variety of senses. Seesaw Theatre is produced solely by undergraduate students and continues to provide theatre free of charge.

For more information about our work please visit http://www.seesawtheatre.org. 

To get involved email us at seesawtheatre@gmail.com.
Summary: Seesaw Theatre strives to enrich the lives of autistic and otherwise disabled individuals by increasing their access to theatre and fostering the use of performance as a channel for expression.

Name: Segal Professional Bridge
Description:
Segal Professional Bridge is an organization aimed at connecting students, faculty members and industry professionals who are passionate about design, innovation and entrepreneurship.

Highlights include:

  • Presenting students with networking opportunities through industry visits, speaker series, professional and societies panels
  • Exposing students to events hosted by the Northwestern and Chicago design communities
  • Providing students with opportunities for professional development through mentorship programming
Summary: Segal Professional Bridge is an organization aimed at connecting students, faculty members and industry professionals who are passionate about design, innovation and entrepreneurship.

Name: Senior Year Committee
Description: More information about about the Senior Year Committee can be found here.
Summary: Senior Year Committee

Name: Sexual Health and Assault Peer Educators
Description:
SHAPE is a Northwestern student organization affiliated with NU's Center for Awareness, Response, and Education (CARE) that combats rape culture and works to create a culture of healthy sexuality through education, public events, and an open dialogue on sexual health, sex positivity, and sexual assault. SHAPE's mission is to increase students’ comfort about sexuality, encourage them to learn and adopt healthy behaviors and help them recognize and address unhealthy and dangerous behaviors and attitudes regarding sexuality and relationships.

Members of SHAPE receive training from current SHAPE educators and Director of CARE, along with Northwestern's Title IX Coordinator and Northwestern- or community-affiliated doctors, nurse practitioners, advocates, counselors, and other experts in the fields of sexual health and sexual assault prevention. Peer educators are trained on a range of topics including:

  - Consent & Communication

  - Sexual Assault

  - Supporting Survivors

  - Safer Sex & STI’s

  - Intersectionality

  - LGBTQ+ sexual health and inclusivity

  - Healthy Relationships

  - Reproductive anatomy & birth control

  - Title IX

  - & More!

After training, peer educators provide presentations, workshops, and trainings to students, organize outreach events & tabling, collaborate with other student organizations, and serve as a resource for individual students looking for information about sexual health and sexual assault.

We also have a newsletter, The Bi-Weekly Shag, with upcoming campus/community events and fun sex tips! Join our listserv (SHAPEfriends@listserv.it.northwestern.edu) to get the best newsletter around & information on upcoming events, joining, etc.
Summary: SHAPE is a Northwestern student organization affiliated with CARE that combats rape culture and works to create a culture of healthy sexuality through education, public events, and open dialogue on sexual health, sex positivity, and sexual assault.

Name: SGI Buddhists for Peace
Description: We are members of the Northwestern University community contributing to the creation of a culture of peace and nonviolence based on the teachings of the Nichiren school of Mahayana Buddhism as practiced in the Soka Gakkai International-USA (SGI-USA). Recognizing that the point of departure for lasting peace is the establishment of a firm inner self that will not be shaken by the most difficult of circumstances, we aim to cultivate a network of friendship to support and encourage our fellow students (both undergraduates and graduates) and other members of the community to enjoy fulfilling, happy lives filled with hope for the future.
Summary: We are members of the Northwestern University community contributing to the creation of a culture of peace and nonviolence based on the teachings of the Nichiren school of Mahayana Buddhism as practiced in the Soka Gakkai International-USA (SGI-USA).

Name: SHARE Healthcare
Description:
Spreading Healthcare Awareness through Reciprocal Education.

Our goal is to become better educated healthcare students and develop critical thinking skills to become well-informed healthcare professionals and influence policy reform through reciprocal education. We meet bimonthly to encourage national discussion surrounding journal articles about a chosen topic. The subjects we are covering include political, cultural, gender, and other social determinants of health affecting healthcare today.
Summary: Spreading Healthcare Awareness through Reciprocal Education

Name: Shepard Residential College
Summary: Shepard is a multithematic residential college that houses 74 students, mainly sophomores and freshmen. It is located on south campus, at the center of the sorority quad. Its residents refer to themselves as "sheep."

Name: Shia Muslim Association
Description: SMA aims to educate our Shia Muslim members and the broader Northwestern community by upholding and promoting the teachings of the Sublime Quran, Prophet Muhammad, and the Twelve Imams from his Household. We actively get engaged in promoting dialogue with, creating cooperation with, and fostering participation in the broader Muslim and non-Muslim community at Northwestern University. We will contribute to religious and spiritual life on campus by shaping a forum for a comparative understanding of Shia Islam, other Islamic denominations, and other religions through holding lectures, workshops, and symposia.
Summary: SMA provides an educational forum for the intellectual development of Shia Muslims student community on campus. We seek to spread the knowledge of the Sublime Quran, the Prophet Muhammad, and the Twelve Imams through lectures and symposia.

Name: ShireiNU A Cappella
Description: In the past few years, ShireiNU has burst onto the Northwestern a cappella scene! Founded in 2009, ShireiNU a cappella continues to grow, entertaining audiences both on campus and around the country! When not touring and performing in cities like Boston and Chicago, ShireiNU can be found singing the National Anthem with the Chicago Bulls or at home in the Welsh-Ryan Arena. As a Fiedler Hillel student group, ShireiNU hosts Shabbat dinners and can often be found rehearsing at the Northwestern's Hillel building! Through fun campus performances, ShireiNU enjoys opening up its entirely student-arranged repertoire to both the Jewish and greater-Northwestern communities. At the end of the day, ShireiNU is a group of friends from all walks of life on campus who come together each week to share their love of music!
Summary: ShireiNU A Cappella is Northwestern's premier Jewish a Capella group, founded in 2009. With both Jewish and non-Jewish members, we sing English and some Hebrew music all over campus and throughout Chicagoland!

Name: SIG Theater
Summary: Special Interest Group in Chinese Theater (SIG Theater) is a TGS-sponsored theater club at Northwestern. Our goal is to broaden student life by hosting theater-related events.

Name: Sigma Alpha Epsilon
Description:
Illinois Psi-Omega Chapter, Northwestern University
2325 Sheridan Rd.

Installed 1894

Chapter President: Austin Gundry

You may visit the Illinois Psi-Omega Chapter's website at www.saeilpo.com

Organization Facts

National Founding Date: March 9, 1856

Colors: Royal purple, old gold

You may visit the national website at http://www.sae.net/

SAE Nationally:

227 total chapters + 19 colonies = 246 total groups
Approximately 13,000 undergraduates
Average chapter size, including pledges and actives, is 51 men.
Sigma Alpha Epsilon has initiated more than 305,000 men since badge sequences were first recorded.

The Fraternity’s largest chapters are located at the University of Texas at Austin, with 142 members, and the University of Colorado at Boulder, with 138 members.

There are approximately 190,000 living alumni in the Fraternity. 

The average colony size is 32 men, and the average colony GPA is 3.1.

Awards

NU's Greek Awards 2011-2012

  • Greek Leadership Award, JP McCleary

SAE National Awards 2011-2012

  • Zeal Award for National Chapter of the Year
Summary:
Illinois Psi-Omega Chapter, Northwestern University 2325 Sheridan Rd.

Chapter President: Austin Gundry
You may visit the Illinois Psi-Omega Chapter's website at  www.saeilpo.com
National Founding Date: March 9, 1856

Name: Sigma Alpha Iota
Description:
Sigma Alpha Iota is an international music fraternity for women, open to female students of all majors as an opportunity to continue their musical involvement after high school. We offer performance opportunities, music related philanthropies and social events and outings for all of our members. Our House is located in the Sorority Quad, right next to the Willard Residential College. As SAI is outside of the PanHellenic system, students are able to be in both SAI and a PHA sorority if interested. 

Visit our full website or visit our Facebook Page to learn more details!

___________________________________

Sigma Alpha Iota is an organization which promotes interaction among those who share a commitment to music. Members of SAI are active in all areas of campus music and campus life, working closely with faculty, administration, campus and community groups, music professionals and patrons. In addition to personal encouragement and support, members may receive scholarships, loans and awards in many areas and at all levels of music-related study. Sigma Alpha Iota has long been recognized as a leader in the field of music and provides a lifetime of fraternity contact.

The SAI Alumnae Association allows alumnae members to remain active and supportive of the ideals of SAI.

Members of Sigma Alpha Iota, in collegiate and alumnae chapters, devote their talents and energies to many national and international projects including those of Sigma Alpha Iota Philanthropies, Inc.:

  • The SAI quarterly, PAN PIPES, comprehensively lists American premieres and works-in-progress in each Winter issue, and is included in the Library of Congress Archives.
  • The People-to-People Music Committee, Inc., sends music, instruments, and educational materials to deserving musicians world-wide.
  • The triennial Inter-American Music Awards (IAMA) and commissions recognize and encourage the finest in creative composition throughout the western hemisphere.
  • Undergraduate, Graduate, and Doctoral Scholarships and Loans, Summer Music Scholarships, and Chapter Outreach Grants are available to SAI members and chapters.

Sigma Alpha Iota accepts with pride the responsibilities and privileges of being a leader in the pursuit of music creation, performance, and scholarship.

To visit our national website, click here
Summary: Sigma Alpha Iota is an international music fraternity for women, open to female students of all majors as an opportunity to continue their musical involvement after high school. Visit our website at http://sainorthwestern.wixsite.com/saibeta

Description:
Omega Chapter, Northwestern University
2249 Sheridan Rd.

Installed June 23, 1869

"In this sign you will conquer."

Chapter President: Joe Sauer

You may visit the Omega Chapter's website at http://northwesternsigmachi.com/.

Organization Facts

Colors: Blue, old gold

You may visit the national website at www.sigmachi.org.

  • Outstanding Recruitment

International Awards

Omega Chapter, Northwestern University 2249 Sheridan Rd.

"In this sign you will conquer."

Name: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.
Description:
About Sigma

Sigma Gamma Rho was founded on and continues to be steadfastly committed to the tenets of excellence in Scholarship, Sisterhood and Service.  Sigma Gamma Rho has a proud legacy of providing positive and proactive community leadership and support when and wherever needed as indicated by the sorority's international slogan, "Greater Service, Greater Progress."

 

 

Foundation

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was organized on November 12, 1922, in Indianapolis, Indiana, by seven young educators: Mary Lou Allison Gardner Little, Dorothy Hanley Whiteside, Vivian White Marbury, Nannie Mae Gahn Johnson, Hattie Mae Annette Dulin Redford, Bessie Mae Downey Rhoades Martin and Cubena McClure. The group became an incorporated national collegiate sorority on December 30, 1929, when a charter was granted to Alpha chapter at Butler University.


Soaring To Greater Heights Of Attainment Around The World, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, has met the challenges of the day and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.
Summary: The Eta Chapter of Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.

Name: Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc.
Description:
Tau Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed February 19, 2000

"Culture is Pride, Pride is Success."

President: Gabriella Rios

You may visit the Tau Alpha Chapter's website at www.tagammas.org. 

Organization Facts

National founding date: April 9, 1990

Mission Statement:

Through excellence in the organization’s five founding principles, Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc. provides opportunities for lifelong empowerment to its members, thereby positively influencing the global community.

Vision Statement: 

Empowered women leading the world.

Colors: Shocking Pink and Majestic Purple

You may view the Sigma Lambda Gamma national website at www.sigmalambdagamma.com.
Summary:
Tau Alpha Chapter, Northwestern University
Installed February 19, 2000
"Culture is Pride, Pride is Success."
President:  Gabriella Rios
You may visit the Tau Alpha Chapter's website at www.tagammas.org

Name: Sigma Nu Fraternity
Description:
Sigma Nu recolonized the Gamma Beta Chapter at Northwestern during the spring of 2013!

A group of 45 men came together to recolonize Gamma Beta in the winter of 2013. Since then, 15 more have joined in an effort to create a fraternity from scratch, to mold it into what they believe a model fraternity should look like. This group of men strive to create an inclusive, friendly, and collaborative environment where everyone is welcomed and encouraged to take on leadership opportunities. 

Now, we are 80 members strong and growing. With a new house, strong motivation, and a close brotherhood, we invite you to see if you want to be part of something greater than yourself.

...
Visit the website for more info and fill out a prospective member questionnaire!
http://becomeasigmanu.org/prospective-member-questionnaire

If you'd like to make a membership referral, please click the link below.
http://becomeasigmanu.org/membership-referral
Summary: Gamma Beta Chapter was founded in 1898 with a rich history and tradition at Northwestern and is committed to its principles of Love, Honor and Truth, and has stood in firm opposition to hazing since its founding in 1869 at the Virginia Military Institute

Name: Sigma Phi Epsilon
Description:
The Illinois Lambda Chapter of Sigma Phi Epsilon was founded at Northwestern University in 1989, and rechartered in 2016. As a chapter, we strive to provide the single best undergraduate Greek experience on campus. Please reach out if you would like to know more about us!

As a national organization, Sigma Phi Epsilon is the nation's largest fraternity with over 15,000 undergraduate members and more than 295,000 total lifetime members.
Summary:
Illinois Lambda Chapter, Northwestern University 
2341 Sheridan Rd.
"Building Balanced Men"

Name: Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
Description:
Alpha Beta Chapter, Northwestern University

Installed May 10, 2008

President: Elaine Jiang

"True to our colors, red and gold. Sisters forever, heart and soul"

Organization Facts

National founding date: March 23, 1994

The fundamental goal of Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority is to promote awareness of the myriad Asian/Asian-American cultures. Our sorority addresses this issue through leadership, outreach, individual, community interaction, and most importantly, the bonds of sisterhood. The sorority also promotes development among its members, the students and the faculty at each of the campuses we represent. In order to achieve this goal, we partake in political, social, educational, and cultural activities. Each effort improves our environment, and instills within our sisters experiences that will follow them long after they've graduated. Through a network of like-minded yet highly individualistic women, the sorority lends structure and support to sisters that share this Sigma vision. We believe the strength of our foundation derives from the unity of sisterhood, one that was proudly established years ago. In addition, we work in collaboration with other Greek and non-Greek organizations to provide services for the local communities and the community at large. It is through our various participation in these cultural events, educational workshops, and philanthropic support that we make a difference. Nationally, regionally, and individually, we strive to embody the ideals of Sigma Psi Zeta.

Colors: Red and Gold

You may visit the Sigma Psi Zeta national website at www.sigmapsizeta.org.

FB: https://www.facebook.com/NorthwesternSYZ/

Instagram: @nusigmas

Name: Significant Others
Description:
Founded in 1994, Significant Others is Northwestern’s treble voices a cappella group. Sig O is a close community of friends who love to sing and make amazing music together! We are a completely student-run organization that puts on a unique show each quarter featuring a fun theme and setlist that we arrange.

While we were initially founded as a women’s a cappella group, we have since expanded our mission statement to include female, non-binary, trans, and any other non-cis identifying individuals. We strongly value inclusivity and creating a safe space for historically marginalized gender identities.

SigO puts on three different shows during the school year: a fall show, a winter show, and a spring show. Throughout the year, we sing at various gigs on campus and throughout the Chicagoland area, including charity events, opening acts for other groups, and new student week performances. We also travel to perform with a cappella groups at other universities throughout the midwest!

For more information, check out our website and Instagram @sigonu!
Summary: Significant Others is Northwestern's premier a cappella group for treble voices, founded in 1994. We are a close community of female and non-binary folx who love to sing together! We are also avid Just Dance fans.

Name: Sikh Students Association
Description: TBA
Summary: TBA

Name: Singapore Society
Description: Singapore Society (SingSoc) is a cultural organization that celebrates the uniqueness of Singapore. SingSoc organizes many events and get-togethers for anyone interested in Singapore's rich culture and history. We welcome absolutely anyone, and you do not need to be a Singaporean to join our organization!
Summary: Singapore Society (SingSoc) is a cultural organization that celebrates the uniqueness of Singapore. SingSoc organizes many events and get-togethers for anyone interested in Singapore's rich culture and history.

Name: Sit & Spin Productions
Description: Sit & Spin Productions exists to expand the definition of theatre at Northwestern University by giving artists opportunities to explore unconventional, risk-taking works. We promote new approaches to existing material, adapted or original work, and site-specific theatre. We are dedicated to providing administrative, artistic, and production support for all aspects of our season.
Summary: Sit & Spin Productions is a theatre board at Northwestern University that produces unconventional, risk-taking, and site-specific work.

Name: Slivka Hall
ShortName: Residential College of Science and Engineering
Description:
The Science and Engineering Residential College at Slivka Hall provides a unique living and learning opportunity for undergraduates interested in science, engineering, and technology. College members take part in tutorials, firesides, and distinguished lectures on topics ranging from ethics in the lab to quantum teleportation to AIDS in America. They participate in community service projects and fundraisers, go to Chicago sports events, and organize camping and biking trips. The college sponsors an annual Thanksgiving dinner, and a barbecue is held in June to "toast" our graduating seniors.

Slivka is located on north campus just a short walk from the Technological Institute, the science and engineering library, the Henry Crown Sports Pavilion and Norris Aquatics Center, and Patten Gym.

Slivka houses 140 students in single- and double-occupancy rooms, arranged in a closed suite-style layout. Men and women live in suites clustered by gender. This building is available to all undergraduate students.
Summary: The Slivka Residential College of Science and Engineering provides a unique living and learning opportunity for undergraduates interested in science, engineering, and technology. Slivka houses 140 students in single and double rooms.

Name: Smoke and Mirrors: NU Magic
Description: Smoke and Mirrors: NU Magic is established for the purpose of gathering magicians on campus and to spread the joy of magic to students at Northwestern. The objective of the club is to host magic shows on campus and to give magicians an opportunity to improve. The club is also trying to spread the influence of magic and create a community for Northwestern students to explore magic and have fun.
Summary: Smoke and Mirrors: NU Magic is established for the purpose of gathering magicians on campus and to spread the joy of magic to students at Northwestern.

Name: Social Justice Education
Summary: Social Justice Education (SJE) creates co-curricular educational opportunities in partnership with our student community that foster self-exploration, facilitate conversations across difference and support actions that create social change on campus.

Name: Society of Asian Scientists & Engineers
Description: The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) seeks to advance Asian-heritage scientific and engineering professionals and help achieve their full potential. SASE members help create and partake in a variety of cultural and professional development activities as well as volunteering work to help the surrounding community. SASE is open to all majors, races, ethnicities, and genders, and is an organization where students can connect over an appreciation of Pan-Asian culture and support each other.
Summary: SASE prepares Asian heritage scientists, engineers & technologists for success in the global business world, celebrates diversity & provides opportunities for students to contribute to their local communities.

Name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers
Description:
SHPE History
The Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE) was founded in Los Angeles, California, in 1974 by a group of engineers employed by the city of Los Angeles. Their objective was to form a national organization of professional engineers to serve as role models in the Hispanic community.
The concept of networking was the key basis for the organization. SHPE quickly established two student chapters to begin the network that would grow to encompass the nation as well as reach countries outside the United States. Today, SHPE enjoys a strong but independent network of professional and student chapters throughout the nation.

SHPE Mission
SHPE at Northwestern University promotes the advancement of all ethnicities, majors, and backgrounds in education, employment, and society. SHPE at Northwestern University serves the Northwestern Community and surrounding schools through academic workshops, community service, and student group collaboration.

Chapter History
In the mid-1990s, SHPE was founded as a source of encouragement for the underrepresented Latinx minorities in Engineering at Northwestern. As of this year, we have grown to over 20 active members. We are currently in the process of researching and maintaining our local chapter's history, as well as establishing connection with our alumni.

Vision
SHPE is the leading social-technical organization whose primary function is to enhance and achieve the potential of Hispanics in engineering, math and science.

Strategic Focus Areas
We will fulfill our mission by increasing educational opportunities, promoting professional and personal growth, carry out our social responsibility to be involved in education, business and government issues and enhancing pride within our organization and reinforcing our reputation as a vital Hispanic organization

Statement of Values
We are brought together by heritage, social responsibility, and desire to improve the equality of all people through the use of science and technology. We value excellence in education, professional pursuits and leadership. We obtain excellence through integrity, empowerment, achievement, diversity and continuous improvement.

Connect with us:

Join our groupme, where members can be updated on upcoming events and activities:https://groupme.com/join_group/30690709/PO7uQlE8

If you wish to be added to our emailing list, please reach out to shpe@u.northwestern.edu
Summary: Our mission is to promote the development of Hispanics in engineering, science, and other technical professions to achieve educational excellence, economic opportunity and social equity.

Name: Society of Physics Students
Description: The Northwestern University Society of Physics students seeks to connect students interested in physics, astronomy, and related fields. Whether you're looking for a pre-professional organization or just a community of STEM (well, science) enthusiasts, SPS is for you! We plan public lectures, demonstrations, and events open to the entire Northwestern community, as well as informal meetings to help students and professors get to know each other. We are also expanding our outreach efforts to local elementary and high schools to encourage younger students’ interest in science.
Summary: SPS is a community for anyone interested in physics, astronomy, space science, engineering ... Whether you're seeking pre-professional experience or a community of like-minded enthusiasts, the Society of Physics Students welcomes you!

Name: Society of Professional Journalists
Summary: The Northwestern/Medill chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists promotes student journalism and provides resources for the Medill community to connect with professionals in the industry and learn important tools to improve as journalists.

Name: Society of Women Engineers
Summary: SWE\u2019s mission is to create a supportive community of women and non-binary engineers through professional and social programming. We aim to empower our members to fulfill their full potential as engineers and leaders and inspire the next generation.

Name: Software and Game Development Group
Description:
The Software and Game Development Group (SGDG) provides opportunities for current and aspiring developers, designers, artists, and more in creating apps and video games. Whether you're an experienced or inexperienced programmer, designer, artist, musician, or even someone who's interested in tech or video games, you'll have a place in SGDG.

 

Looking to make an app, but don't know how? Or maybe you're a great game programmer but a terrible game graphics artist. Fill in those missing gaps by finding other SGDG members with those skills and actually bring your idea into reality. Start your own projects with SGDG to find others to collaborate with and to get your project recognized, creating a userbase for your software.

 

Become a part of an SGDG team and compete in mainstream programming competitions and game jams, or perhaps help us host one of our own.

 

No prior experience is required to become a member of SGDG. If you're unsure whether SGDG is right for you, if you're into tech and video games, you'll probably like it here.

 

Become a member today at https://sgdgroup.org. All the latest information about SGDG will be there, too.
Summary: The Software and Game Development Group (SGDG) provides opportunities for current and aspiring developers, designers, artists, and more in creating apps and video games.

Name: Soul4Real
Description: Soul4Real is Northwestern's premiere Black a cappella student group. Founded in 2009, S4R serves to expose the Northwestern community to the fullest spectrum of historically Black musical genres including R&B, Soul, Hip-Hop and more.
Summary: Soul4Real is Northwestern's premiere Black a cappella student group. Founded in 2009, S4R serves to expose the Northwestern community to the fullest spectrum of historically Black musical genres including R&B, Soul, Hip-Hop and more.

Name: South Asia Initiative
Description: South Asia Initiative is an organization focusing on the discussion of South Asian political, economic and social issues from the perspective of different South Asian countries. We hold weekly meetings and organize university-wide guest lectures on pertinent issues. SAI also collaborates with other clubs and organizations on campus to host various events.
Summary: South Asia Initiative is an organization focusing on the discussion of South Asian political, economic and social issues from the perspective of different South Asian countries.

Name: South Asian Students Alliance
Description:
The South Asian Students Alliance (SASA) is the largest cultural student organization on campus that is dedicated to the celebration of South Asian culture. We proudly put on events that display our South Asian culture throughout the year, the largest of which is the annual SASA Show held in February. Other events include a Spring Speaker, a Garba/Raas/Bhangra, Holi, and student dialogues (among others). We dedicate time and effort to fostering a vibrant student community that engages with South Asian culture on the NU campus and in its surrounding community.

 

For any questions, comments, or concerns, please contact:

Co-Presidents Simrun Varshney and Nithya Mahakala at nusasaexec@gmail.com
Summary: The South Asian Students Alliance (SASA) is the largest cultural student organization on campus that is dedicated to the celebration of South Asian culture.

Name: Spectrum Theatre Company
Description: Spectrum aims to inspire thought and dialogue both on campus and within the larger community. Spectrum is dedicated to recognizing the spectrum of beliefs, opinions, colors, creeds, and lifestyles of all people by producing thought provoking and challenging theater. We seek to collaborate with and empower the Northwestern community through theatre. Our seasons consist of scripted plays, devised work, and public happenings centered around a relevant politically and social conscious issue.
Summary: Spectrum Theatre Company is dedicated to empowering the greater Northwestern community by raising awareness, inspiring dialogue, and affecting change through theatrical experiences based on relevant social and political issues.

Name: Speech Team
Description: Members of the speech team spend their year crafting immaculate performances for competitions around the country, all in the hopes of receiving useful feedback (and maybe a trophy or two). Revise. Memorize. Repeat. Since 1994, the Northwestern Speech Team has won five Team National Titles, 18 individual national championships, and placed in 87 national final rounds. We've also made a lot of friends along the way! With 11 different events to choose from, you are sure to find an avenue to explore your interests and develop your public speaking skills. While high school speech experience will translate, no previous forensics experience is required. The team is looking for students who are passionate about the activity, eager to learn, and ready to work.
Summary: The Speech Team offers students a venue to participate in collegiate public speaking competitions. We also host showcases and tournaments on campus, such as the Tournament of Champions in Extemporaneous Speaking.

Name: SPG Improv
Description: We're Northwestern's only Graduate Student improv troupe!
Summary: Graduate Student Improv Troupe

Name: Spirit Squads
Description:
After a great 10-2 regular season, and an exciting trip to The Outback Bowl in Tampa, FL, the Wildcats are looking forward to the 2016-17 season! With football games at Ohio State, Michigan State, Purdue, Iowa and Minnesota, great travel opportunities exist for the 2016-17 Spirit Squad!  The Northwestern Cheerleaders and Willie the Wildcat appear at all home and away football games. You could have a chance to cheer at some of the most storied stadiums in college athletics! The NU Cheerleaders and Willie the Wildcat also makes appearances at all home men’s and women’s basketball games, as well as Big Ten basketball tournaments and assorted school and alumni events throughout the year. Great opportunities abound!

The Northwestern Spirit Squad  is completely funded through the athletic department. There is no cost to participate. All uniforms, practice gear, camps, travel, etc. are paid for by the spirit fund. Some members of the team may receive a monetary grant. This will be determined after the completion of each season.
Summary: The official spirit squad of the Northwestern University Department of Athletics and Recreation.

Name: Splash
Summary: Northwestern Splash is an outreach organization that allows Chicagoland high school students to take classes taught by members of the NU community.

Name: Spoon University
Description:
Spoon is the food resource for the millennial generation.

Spoon is on a mission to make food make sense - our content is written by college students, for college students. On our site and in our magazine, you can find the simplest recipes, the most obvious hacks you can’t believe you didn’t know, and the best restaurants around campus that you haven’t found yet. For many of us, this is the first time we’re navigating our campuses or our kitchens on our own, and Spoon University is here to simplify and celebrate that.

We offer opportunities for involvement through writing, photography, videography, and marketing.  We publish editorial content daily and a yearbook-style print magazine each Winter and Spring.  Please visit our website at http://nu.spoonuniversity.com/ or email us at tessakauppila2021@u.northwestern.edu or spoonuniversitynu@gmail.com for more information.
Summary: Spoon is the food resource for the millenial generation.

Name: Sportman's Club
Description: The Sportsman's Club is an organization that aims to connect Northwestern students who share a passion for angling, hunting and other sporting activities.
Summary: The Sportsman's Club is an organization that aims to connect Northwestern students who share a passion for angling, hunting and sporting activities.

Name: Sports Analytics Group
Description: The Sports Analytics Group is a group of Northwestern undergraduates committed to strategic data analysis and outside-the-box thinking in the world of sports. Our organization serves as an outlet for Northwestern students interested in sports analytics, attracting those who are creative, have a dedicated passion for sports statistics, and use analytical thinking to solve problems. We offer our members the ability to bridge the gap between sports and data analytics by fostering the education and guidance necessary to produce content that provides valuable insight into all facets of sports (business, roster management, fantasy, in-game strategy, etc.).
Summary: The Sports Analytics Group is a group of Northwestern undergraduates committed to strategic data analysis and outside the box thinking in all facets of sports (business, roster management, fantasy, in-game strategy, etc.).

Name: SPS MSA Student Organization
Description:
Successful networking can be an essential component for entry into the sports field. Northwestern University's MSA program provides a range of networking opportunities that provide MSA students and alumni with a competitive advantage as they begin and look to advance in their careers.

  • MSA faculty and staff have access to team executives, sports agents, corporate sports consultants and a broad range of other professionals in collegiate, professional and amateur athletics administration.
  • The MSA student board offers networking events that give students inside access to Chicago-area sports operations and provide opportunities to meet with and learn from team management and executives. See below for recent events.
  • Select MSA courses feature guest speakers from the sports industry who provide their insight and guidance.
  • MSA alumni hold positions in many areas of sports. As Northwestern University alumni, MSA graduates become part of an alumni population known nationwide for excellence and achievement.
Summary: The School of Professional Studies offers a part-time Master of Arts in Sports Administration (MSA) program that focuses on the business of athletics. The MSA Student Board adds opportunities to meet and socialize with industry professionals.

Name: SPS Northwestern University Prehealth Professional
Description: .

Name: Squash Club Team
Description:
Joining the team 

Tryouts will be held in September/October. Look for the Squash Team table at the Wildcat Welcome Fair to learn more.
Students are also able to join the team at any time throughout the season.

Practice 
Practices and home matches are held at SPAC.
We practice with challenge matches(to determine the ladder for the team) and conditioning drills 2-3 times a week. The team's practice schedule is to be determined for the 2019-2020 season.

Competitions against other schools take place on weekends.

Away matches 
At least two flying trips are taken each year to compete with other schools. Last year we went to Boston and Yale. 

Local matches
Additionally, we will compete in a tournament against other schools from the Midwest and participate in an annual match with the University of Chicago. Every year, the Squash Team competes in the National Championships held in mid-February.

Club dues: ~$100/quarter.

League affiliation: College Squash Association


If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to the team's captain at seongsikkim2020@u.northwestern.edu
Summary: We are committed to providing an enjoyable and competitiion-driven experience for our members. We love the sport and enjoy getting better at playing and being better teammates.

Name: St. Baldrick's
Description: The purpose of our organization is to support the overall mission of the St. Baldrick’s Foundation by fundraising for pediatric cancer research. On campus, our primary goal each year is to organize a successful year-end fundraising event, where volunteers shave their heads to raise money. All group programs and activities throughout the year work towards this event as the central goal, as well as helping educate the community on the disease and the latest in research, and connecting interested members in relevant volunteering opportunities. In short, our goal is to help conquer childhood cancers.
