Summary: St. Baldricks fundraises in support of childhood cancer research, primarily by organizing a year-end head-shaving event to stand in solidarity with child patients.

Name: Steam Heat Dance Company
Description: Steam Heat is Northwestern's premier musical theatre dance company dedicated to preserving original musical theatre choreography and inspiring new musical theatre dance. Steam Heat was founded in 2009 by Dance major Danielle Kipnis. Today we practice and perform several dance styles such as Musical Theatre, Jazz, Jazz Funk, Tap, and Contemporary.  We perform at various events on and off campus throughout the year and have a main-stage show each spring complete with lighting, costumes, sets, props, and a live band! We have performed original pieces from Chorus Line, Sweet Charity, Lion King, and more. We also strive to further the art form by creating our own choreography and incorporating live singing into several pieces of our show.
Summary: Steam Heat is Northwestern's premier musical theatre dance company dedicated to preserving original musical theatre choreography and inspiring new theatre dance. We perform dance styles including jazz, tap, contemporary, hip-hop/urban and more!

Name: STITCH
Description: STITCH is a fashion publication at Northwestern University. Since its creation in 2006, the student-run and funded magazine has distributed four to five print issues per year to the Northwestern University student body, the Evanston community and select stores in Chicago. Founded by Joyce Lee, Matthew Alfonso, Christopher Adamson, Nate Adkisson and Kevin Burke, STITCH is now comprised of 80+ staffers from among the Northwestern University student population. Our blog, www.stitchfashion.com, is updated daily, and our latest print issue can be found at https://issuu.com/stitchfashion/docs.
Summary: STITCH is a fashion publication at Northwestern University. Our blog, www.stitchfashion.com, is updated daily, and our latest print issue can be found at https://issuu.com/stitchfashion/docs.

Name: Student Academy of Audiology
Description: The Student Academy of Audiology  is the national student organization of the American Academy of Audiology that  serves as a collective voice for students and advances the rights, interests,  and welfare of students pursuing careers in audiology. The SAA introduces  students to lifelong involvement in activities that promote and advance the  profession of audiology, and provides services, information, education,  representation and advocacy for the profession and the public we serve.
Summary: The Student Academy of Audiology is the national student organization of the American Academy of Audiology that serves as a collective voice for students and advances the rights, interests, and welfare of students pursuing careers in audiology.

Name: Student Admission Council
Description: The Student Admission Volunteers work with the Admissions Department to assist prospective students when they visit Northwestern. Volunteers can host prospective students overnight, assist with Alumni Interviews, and be a campus leader during Wildcat Days among many other opportunities. By volunteering for the SAV, you have a chance to help convince prospective students that Northwestern is the best place on earth!
Summary: The Student Admission Volunteers work with the Admissions Department to assist prospective students when they visit Northwestern.

Name: Student Affairs
Description: Student Affairs affects every Northwestern student. Nearly 30 departments make up the Division of Student Affairs, from housing to food services, career services to counseling, the student center to student org advising, and so much more. Student Affairs enriches the Northwestern experience outside of the classroom. This division engages students in activities and culture in both the campus and surrounding community. Student Affairs offers support to students in need and creates an environment that makes Northwestern students Wildcats for life.
Summary: Student Affairs affects every Northwestern student. Nearly 30 departments make up the Division of Student Affairs, from housing to food services, career services to counseling, the student center to student org advising, and so much more.

Name: Student Affairs Information Technology
Summary: Student Affairs Information Technology - IT Support and Development for the Division or Student Affairs.

Name: Student Affairs Marketing
Description:
Place your marketing request here.

The Student Affairs Marketing department is responsible for establishing the Division of Student Affairs brand as well as assisting each department within the division with developing and implementing integrated marketing communication plans.
Summary: The Student Affairs Marketing department is responsible for establishing the Division of Student Affairs brand as well as assisting each department within the division with developing and implementing integrated marketing communication plans.

Name: Student Alliance Board School of Professional Studies
Summary: The SAB is the overarching student government organization within the School of Professional Studies.

Name: Student Association for Finance Education
Description: TBA
Summary: SAFE's goal is to build a totally inclusive, non-selective organization for anybody interested in investing or working in the financial services industry, placing an emphasis on growth and education.

Name: Student Branch of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
Description:
The primary purpose of IEEE NU is to provide the means through which all students at Northwestern University may explore the EECS Department’s disciplines. It also serves the role of conveying the opinions and insights of the Department’s student body to the Department itself.


Its secondary purposes align more closely with those of the Corporation. They are primarily educational and directed toward the dissemination of knowledge pertaining to the theory and practice of electrical and computer engineering, as well as computer science. They are also professional and directed toward the development of members’ (both within IEEE NU and within the EECS Department student body) career aspirations.
Summary: IEEE NU exists to provide all students at Northwestern University with an avenue for participating in events and activities that promote the disciplines within the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.

Name: Student Consulting for Non-Profit Organizations
Summary: We are a community service organization that provides free strategic consulting services to local non-profits.

Name: Student Organization Finance Office
Description:
The Student Organization Finance Office (SOFO) serves as the banking center for all student groups recognized by Northwestern University. As such, it facilitates financial transactions and offers an independent and verifiable record of all the activity that occurs on these organizational accounts.

Student organizations are financially accountable to their members and the student body at large. Though they are not recognized as legal entities outside of Northwestern, they do, at times, “represent” the University unofficially by the programs and activities they sponsor and make available to the general Evanston public. This association with the University brings them many benefits (e.g., exempt status from Illinois sales tax) and responsibilities (e.g., adherence to documentation requirements).

SOFO is committed to providing student organizations with a financial framework that helps student treasurers maintain accurate and detailed records while allowing them and student presidents the flexibility to pursue their organizations’ stated purposes and objectives.
Summary: The Student Organization Finance Office (SOFO) serves  as the banking center for all student groups recognized by  Northwestern  University. As such, it facilitates financial transactions  and offers an  independent and verifiable record of all the

Name: Student Organizations & Activities
Description:
Students have the opportunity to participate in over 500 student organizations on campus or create one of their own. Our office provides support, advising, and training for students and their organizations. Through educational and programming opportunities we facilitate and nurture experiences in:

  • Leadership
  • Campus programming
  • Student community service
  • Social justice
  • Student organization development

We encourage students to visit us to find their passion, develop ideas, and think creatively about their student organizations.
Summary: Student Organizations & Activities seeks to engage students in involvement opportunities that build a sense of belonging and community at Northwestern University.

Name: Student Philanthropy Council
Description:
Mission

The mission of the Northwestern Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) is to educate the current undergraduate student population about philanthropy at Northwestern University and inspire a lifetime connection to the University through giving back.

About The Council

Established in 2017, the Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) provides a student voice to philanthropy programming at Northwestern. The Council is comprised of representatives from each of the current undergraduate classes. The Council meets monthly to plan, discuss, and execute Student Philanthropy education and programming opportunities.

The Council is a vital component of the Student Philanthropy program. All members have a voice in the kind of programming that the Office of Alumni Relations and Development provides current students. Members actively engage and participate in shaping the conversation around philanthropy.

Some of the programming and events the Council hosts include the Fall and Spring PhilanthroFests, I Heart Northwestern Week, and Snack Attack.
Summary: The Student Philanthropy Council (SPC) provides a student voice to philanthropy programming at Northwestern. The Council meets monthly to plan, discuss, and execute Student Philanthropy education and programming opportunities.

Name: Student Theatre Coalition
Description: The Northwestern Student Theatre Coalition, or StuCo for short, is a collective of nine student theatre groups and two dance groups, each with its own executive board and mainstage performance series. StuCo exists to provide organizational support for the common practices of the student theatre community at Northwestern, including general auditions for shows, space allocation, and acquisition and maintenance of shared equipment.
Summary: The Northwestern Student Theatre Coalition, or StuCo for short, is a collective of nine student theatre groups and two dance groups, each with its own executive board and mainstage performance series.

Name: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development
Description: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development, SEED, one of the largest, ASG recognized environmental groups on campus, promotes concern for the environment in community decisions and in daily life, through both education and action. SEED’s mission is to pioneer, teach, and model environmental stewardship so as to inspire our future leaders to act in ways that protect and sustain our planet. We seek to engage and educate the Northwestern community on environmental issues by making them relevant and relatable. In doing so, we espouse not only the challenges we face, but make clear the opportunities to improve the welfare of people and the planet together in an effort to produce a healthier, just, and sustainable world.
Summary: Students for Ecological and Environmental Development (SEED) works to affect the state of the environment and to support progressive environmental movements at Northwestern University through event programming, service, education and advocacy.

Name: Students for Justice in Palestine
Description:
SJP is a diverse group of students, faculty, staff, and community members at colleges & universities throughout the US. Our group is organized according to democratic principles in order to promote justice, human rights, liberation, and self-determination for the Palestinian People.

As an advocacy group, SJP is committed to a core set of principles to which it expects its members to adhere. SJP believes that while the Palestinian people must ultimately be able to decide their future in Palestine, certain key principles, grounded in international law, human rights, and basic standards of justice, are fundamental to a just resolution of the plight of the Palestinians. These include the full decolonization of all illegally held Palestinian lands, the end of the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip, the West Bank, and East Jerusalem. Furthermore, we believe in a just and fair resolution to the Palestinian right of return and repatriation of Palestinian refugees, as well as an end to the Israeli system of discrimination against the indigenous Palestinian population. Just as SJP condemns the discrimination underlying the policies and laws of the state of Israel, SJP rejects and condemns any form of hatred or discrimination against any religious, racial, or ethnic group. SJP is committed to overcoming anti-Semitic sentiments towards both Arabs and Jews in the community. Rooting its strength in the diversity of its membership, SJP welcomes individuals of all ethnic and religious backgrounds to join in solidarity with the struggle for justice in Palestine.
Summary: SJP is a diverse group of students, faculty, staff, and community members at universities throughout the US. Our group is organized according to democratic principles in order to promote justice, human rights, liberation and self-determination.

Name: Students for Sensible Drug Policy
Description: SSDP provides education and organizes events about issues concerning drug policy, drug education and drug use, abuse, and treatment. The purpose of SSDP is to encourage an open and honest space to discuss and ask questions about the effects of drug use and to help students recognize unhealthy and dangerous behaviors while involving youth in the process of drug education and policy reform. We mobilize and empower young people to participate in the political process, pushing for sensible policies to achieve a safer and more just future, while fighting back against counterproductive drug war policies, particularly those that directly harm students and youth.
Summary: Students for Sensible Drug Policy is an international grassroots network of students who advocate for ending the War on Drugs and educating our community about harm reduction and honest drug information.

Name: Students Promoting Education, Awareness, and Knowledge (SPEAK) for Change
Description: The mission of SPEAK for Change is to utilize activist efforts in order to challenge the normalization of sexual and interpersonal violence at Northwestern and in society at-large, as well as to foster a campus community in which survivors can thrive.
Summary: The mission of SPEAK for Change is to utilize activist efforts in order to challenge the normalization of sexual and interpersonal violence at Northwestern and in society at-large, as well as to foster a campus community in which survivors can thrive.

Name: Studio 22 Productions
Description:
Studio 22 is Northwestern University’s student-run, not-for-profit,
film production company.

In addition to making short films, Studio 22 serves the community by
providing workshops on filmmaking as well as by bringing in industry
professionals to help transition our filmmakers from the university
setting to the professional world.
Summary: Studio 22 is a student-run production company that exists to provide extracurricular filmmaking opportunities not offered in production classes. Studio 22 continually strives to promote education, ambition, and quality in Northwestern filmmakers.

Name: Sunrise Movement
Summary: TBA

Name: Supplies for Dreams
Description: Supplies for Dreams is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that provides underprivileged Chicago Public School students with critical resources and extra-curricular opportunities ranging from basic school supplies to field trips and one-on-one mentoring. The Northwestern Chapter of SFD strives to give opportunities for NU students to help SFD do this, as well as bring awareness of the issues in education that exist.
Summary: Supplies for Dreams is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that provides underprivileged Chicago Public School students with critical resources and extra-curricular opportunities ranging from basic school supplies to field trips and one-on-one mentoring.

Name: Surf Club
Summary: Surf Club hopes to build a fun-loving and supportive community of student surfers! We will strive to give access to surfing equipment to as many students as possible, regardless of skill level.

Name: Sustained Dialogue
Description: Student-led program coordinated by Social Justice Education.
Summary: Sustained Dialogue (SD) is a student-facilitated program that encourages conversation across lines of difference. Students participate in weekly 90-minute sessions throughout the quarter in which they explore issues around their social identities.

Name: Swing Left
Description:
Swing Left is a student group organizing Northwestern to help Democrats take back the Senate and the White House and end Republican gerrymandering in 2020.

We engage in direct voter contact by writing letters and making calls to Swing Left's Super States: Arizona, Colorado, Texas, Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maine, North Carolina, Georgia and Florida.
Summary: Swing Left introduces Northwestern students to the most effective voter contact opportunities to elect Democrats up and down the ballot in key states across the country.

Name: Swipe Out Hunger
Description:
Swipe Out Hunger NU is part of a national initiative focused on food insecurity on college campuses and their surrounding areas. In partnership with dining services, Swipes NU organizes "drives" that allow students to donate dining dollars by swiping their Wildcard at any of the C-stores across campus. This money is then used to aid students on campus and people in the greater Evanston community through funding soup kitchens, helping the Purple Pantry and Campus Kitchens, and providing educational opportunities for students on campus to learn more about food insecurity. 

Swipe Out Hunger NU was previously Points for a Purpose. When meal plans replaced meal points with dining dollars in 2017 Points decided to rebrand and merge with the national Swipe Out Hunger organization.
Summary: Swipe Out Hunger NU is part of a national organization that works towards ending food insecurity on college campuses through student donations of unused dining dollars, educational opportunities, and community service events.

Name: Tabletop Club
Description:
• You're invited to join our Discord! https://discord.gg/TdRKybf

 

  • For the 2021-22 year, Tabletop Club will continue to offer both virtual and hybrid activities so anyone can participate to any extent in the amazing world of tabletop roleplaying games (TTRPGs).

 

  • We hold Virtual Game Night events every two weeks! Drop by on our Discord server to play Jackbox games, Coup, and other virtual favorites. 

 

  • Our longer campaigns are great for those who would like to play an ongoing story with a consistent group of people. Anyone is welcome to run or join a campaign! Campaigns usually last a quarter, but they can be shorter or longer depending on the group. They are often a weekly commitment, but scheduling is quite flexible and will be figured out with every member of the party. If you'd like to run a campaign, don't hesitate to join our Discord and start organizing!

 

  • We also have intermittent One Shot games. These are casual, 4-ish hour long games for people with any amount of experience with TTRPGs. These games will be run in varying systems like Dungeons & Dragons, Honey Heist, Monster of the Week, and more! The one shots are a great opportunity to dip your toes in the water and learn about TTRPGs. They are also awesome for more experienced players who are looking to try out new systems, meet people interested in the hobby at NU, or get their dose of TTRPGs without needing to commit too much time!
Summary: We aim to facilitate tabletop roleplaying at NU by providing everyone the opportunity to learn, explore, and enjoy the hobby in an inclusive, friendly environment. Join our discord! https://discord.gg/TdRKybf

Name: Taiwanese American Students Association
Description:
Northwestern University's premiere student group for those passionate about Taiwan and Taiwanese culture!

Previously known as TASC, we are rebranding to TASA!

The Taiwanese American Students Association (TASA) was established in 1992, and the Associated Student Government recognized TASA as a student organization in January of 1994. Since then, TASA has grown from a group of eight members to an Associated Student Government A-status organization with members from all backgrounds, Asians and non-Asians alike.

TASA was founded to provide a forum in which Taiwanese history, culture and current events could be openly celebrated and shared among all Asian Americans and the NU community at large. Our mission is two-fold: to build community amongst students interested in Taiwan, and to provide the larger Northwestern community the chance to explore and learn about the many facets of Taiwanese culture.
Summary: A Taiwanese-American student interest group striving to promote cultural awareness through educational events like Taiwanese Night Market, Karaoke Night, Dragon Boat Festival, Celebrasia, and more.

Name: TAMID Group
Description: TAMID at Northwestern provides students the opportunity to gain exposure to the fields of consulting, investment management, venture capital, entrepreneurship, and technology innovation. Through experiences such as hands-on start-up consulting and portfolio management, our members are prepared to enter the workforce with invaluable skills. It is our belief that these skills are best adopted by studying and working together with world leading economies. Israel’s economic landscape embodies the ideal model of integrating technology with entrepreneurship. By connecting students with the Israeli economy as a case study, TAMID at Northwestern will educate and inform interested students and prepare them for their professional careers. As one of 24 national chapters, TAMID at Northwestern will continue to strengthen its diverse network of small companies, venture capitalists, business professionals, and academics that have ties to the Israeli economy, which our members can take advantage of to achieve these goals.
Summary: TAMID at Northwestern provides students the opportunity to gain exposure to the fields of consulting, investment management, venture capital, entrepreneurship and technology innovation by learning from industry leaders and consulting for Israeli startups

Name: TBD
Description:
Founded in 2015 in collaboration with the Chicago Neo-Futurists, TBD is Northwestern's premiere Neo-Futurism inspired performance group. TBD is an ensemble of students who strive to create non-illusory theatre that shares our thoughts and feelings as simply as possible so that it is more accessible to all audiences. We play ourselves without the normal conventions of theatre, telling our own truths onstage. We create an environment where the audience is as important as the people on stage, and we create a space for sharing the human experience as honestly as one can whilst performing.

Our ensemble members write and direct their own short plays, which can range in length anywhere from 1 second to 5 minutes! Our plays are wacky, serious, hilarious, political, sad, and anything in between. We perform on Northwestern's campus once per quarter in a fast paced, audience interactive showcase of new plays.
Summary: A Neo-futurism inspired performance group

Name: Team Enough NU
Description: Team Enough is the youth-led initiative of the Brady Campaign. It aims to educate and mobilize young Americans to end gun violence and hold lawmakers accountable. Team Enough believes the following: all Americans have the right to be safe from gun violence in their homes, neighborhoods, schools, and places of work and worship, and it is possible to reduce the number of deaths and injuries caused by gun violence by adopting reasonable, common sense policies. Through engaging students in advocacy work by connecting with local politicians and supporting local and national campaigns, this chapter aims to do advocacy work that will raise awareness about our nation's gun violence epidemic, depoliticize the issue of gun violence, and help lead to the ultimate goal of creating an America free from gun violence. Students can access advocacy opportunities through connecting to Team Enough, not only being able to participate in making tangible change, but learning the skills that advocacy requires.
Summary: The mission of Team Enough and its chapters is to create a safer America by ending America's gun violence epidemic. This Northwestern chapter aims to engage students in advocacy work towards raising awareness and ending the gun violence epidemic.

Name: TEDxNorthwesternU
Description:
TEDxNorthwesternU is an independently organized TEDx conference held annually at Northwestern University. The organizing team is comprised of undergraduate students representing all of Northwestern's undergraduate schools and colleges.

Every spring we host a TED conference on campus, bringing together students and speakers to discuss and share ideas. The board is broken down into three committees: Marketing, Curation, and Logistics/Finance, each with its own role in developing and planning content for the conference. 

Check out our website here, or look up any of our old TED talks on youtube!
Summary: TEDxNorthwesternU is an independently organized TEDx conference held annually at Northwestern University.  The organizing team is comprised of undergraduate students representing all of Northwestern's undergraduate schools and colleges.

Name: Tempo Tantrum
Description: Tempo Tantrum is Northwestern's newest low-voice a cappella sensation! Our mission is to bring a new and unique voice to Northwestern's thriving a cappella community and beyond.
Summary: Tempo Tantrum is Northwestern's newest low-voiced a cappella sensation!  Our mission is to bring a new and unique voice to Northwestern's thriving a cappella community and beyond.

Name: TGS Cross-Cultural
Description: Northwestern University is a community devoted to producing successful and competent leaders for the modern workplace. Producing such leaders requires that graduate students have skills of cultural competence to successfully navigate the growing diversity of our global workplace. Northwestern University has an office of multicultural affairs, which contains programs related to diversity and cultural competence, demonstrating Northwestern’s recognition of the importance of instilling cultural competence and intercultural dialogue. To this end, a graduate student cross-­\u2010cultural communication committee can strengthen and further promote skills of graduate student cultural competence through advertising and co-­\u2010hosting programming aimed specifically at creating an inclusive atmosphere where all graduate students can interact and learn how to be successful communicators.
Summary: We are student group aimed to promote cross-cultural dialogue, awareness of situations where cultural sensitivity is important, so that students from different backgrounds can have good conversations together.

Name: Thai Student Association
Description: Thai Club is an organization comprised of Thai international students, Thai Americans, and anyone interested in Thai culture. Our activities include the famous Thai Night taken place in the spring (featuring classical dance, Thai sports, entertainment, good food, and more), SEA night and various cultural and social events throughout the year. Please visit our website: http://groups.northwestern.edu/thaiclub/
Summary: Thai Club is an organization comprised of Thai international students, Thai Americans, and anyone interested in Thai culture. Our activities include the Southeast Asian Night in winter quarter and Thai Night in the spring.

Name: The .WAV Company
Description: The .WAV Company strives to foster a collaborative music community at Northwestern University. We bring music producers, music performers, artist managers, visual artists, and many other talented individuals together to produce inspiring projects and events.
Summary: A collective of producers, performers, and artists at Northwestern University.

Name: The Bix
Description:
THE BIX is Northwestern's premiere musical improv group!! With the help of our music directors, The Bix improvises scenes, songs, and more. We are a goofy bunch of improvisers who refuse to take ourselves too seriously. Throughout the year, we put on shows using short form and long form skills culminating in a fully improvised musical. 

***Not a singer? Not a problem! The Bix prides ourselves on our diversity of skills. If singing or music isn't your thing, but you love being a goofball, The Bix just might be the perfect fit!***

 

Wanna know more? https://thebiximprov.weebly.com

 

Questions? Shoot us an email at thebiximprov@gmail.com
Summary:
THE BIX is a comedy improv group at Northwestern University focused on, but not limited to, musical improvisation. 
Not a singer? Not a problem!

Name: The Blackout
Description: The Blackout, Northwestern's Late Night Show, infuses Northwestern humor and the late-night structure to create a unique show capturing the Northwestern experience in a satirical light. The crew of 100+ students write, direct, and produce filmed and live sketches, scout out and book local talent for musical and performance guests, and throw one live-show for the student body per quarter.
Summary: The Blackout is Northwestern's premiere late-night comedy show. Drawing inspiration from "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert" & "Jimmy Kimmel! Live!", The Blackout utilizes the structure of a late-night talk show and infuses it with Northwestern humor.

Name: The Campus Kitchen at Northwestern University
Description:
Campus Kitchens collects over 30,000 lbs of excess food from Northwestern dining halls that would otherwise be thrown away. We package the food into healthy meals and deliver these meals to low-income Evanston residents for free. We are conveniently based on campus in The Great Room Kitchen at 600 Haven Street.

Beyond regular operations, we also participate in on and off campus programming. In the past, we have done pumpkin carving with kids at Asian Youth Services, cooked meals for Memorial Day at Second Baptist, and helped students with their homework and St. Patrick's Day crafts at Salvation Army, taught nutrition education classes at YOU and Dawes Elementary School. On campus, we have screened documentaries, partnered with other groups to feature social justice-related speakers, co-hosted a Hunger Games competition and more. Our organization looks to expand our Evanston community-based programming as well as reach more Northwestern students.

We have volunteer shifts every day of the week - no prior experience is required! Sign up for a shift here.
Summary: CKNU collects over 30,000 lbs of excess food from NU dining halls each year that would otherwise be thrown away. We package the food into healthy meals and deliver them to low-income Evanston residents.

Name: The Collective
Description: The purpose of the Collective is to build community on campus through increased engagement with individuals who identify as Black men, regardless of their other salient identities. Knowing that the intersection of our Blackness and manhood often grant us power and privilege, we are constantly striving to acknowledge these benefits as we better understand how we, as Black men, both benefit and suffer from systems of oppression. We encourage our members to engage with this complexity and redefine black manhood in the process through self reflection, education, and group dialogue.
Summary: The Collective aims to support black men by creating a community on campus. Although The Collective\u2019s primary mission is to provide a space for black men to foster thoughtful conversation, the group is open to any student that identifies as a black male.

Name: The Daily Northwestern
Description: One of the nation's most respected college newspapers, The Daily Northwestern has won dozens of regional and national awards. In February 2012, the Illinois College Press Association awarded The Daily first place in general excellence. The Daily received 18 awards at the 2016 ICPA convention. In the last decade, The Daily has won two prestigious national awards, the Gold Crown Award and the Pacemaker, several times.
Summary: One of the nation's oldest and most respected college newspapers, The Daily Northwestern has won dozens of regional and national awards and has been publishing since 1871. Both print and online publications are produced entirely by students.

Name: The Deep End
Description:
The Deep End is a filmed show produced each quarter that exists at the intersection of comedy and journalism. Each episode takes a deep dive into a topical issue at Northwestern, which is presented in a comedic monologue delivered by a host. Comedy writers work alongside our team of journalists to craft pieces that are both funny and informative. Our Impact Committee then works to ensure that each of our episodes has a tangible impact on the Northwestern community, whether that be through fundraising or advocating for change that will help make Northwestern a better institution.

2020 Organizations Fair Zoom link here: https://northwestern.zoom.us/j/95560917619
Summary: The Deep End is a filmed show produced each quarter that exists at the intersection of comedy and journalism.

Name: The Grace Fellowship
Description:
We are a faith-based community serving Chinese-speaking students on campus. We would like to share the Christian faith with everyone and build a healthy supportive community for Northwestern students to grow academically, mentally, and spiritually. We welcome everyone regardless of their religious background. 

Location: Englehart Hall Main Lobby

Time: Every Friday 6:30pm - 9:30pm
Summary: We are a faith-based community for Chinese-speaking students on campus. Our mission is to share our Christian faith and provide a healthy supportive environment for Northwestern students to grow academically, mentally, and spiritually.

Name: The Graduate School
Summary: The mission of The Graduate School of Northwestern University is: to be a trusted, responsive, and visionary leader and partner in order to maintain and promote the highest quality master\u2019s and doctoral education.

Name: The Medical Decoder
Description:
*The MD has recently made the decision to merge with GRC Insights, an online publication focused on informative pieces about areas relevant to social impact, including global health, impact investing, and international development. If you are interested in joining, please fill out this Google Form! https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdXTLtPG4vroRiDQIdz37hCY8K29ap1-STYhdQ-YlQZ8NmzBA/viewform

The Medical Decoder is a student-produced publication run by, and designed for, those interested in the world of medicine and health care. The Medical Decoder, The MD for short, features easy to read, concise articles on topics important for aspiring physicians to know and provides a collaborative environment for aspiring physicians to share their interests, passions, and concerns about the directions medicine is heading in.
Summary: The Medical Decoder is a student-produced publication run by, and designed for, those interested in the world of medicine and health care.

Name: The Mindfulness Club
Summary: The Mindfulness Club is a group of students interested in promoting mindfulness on campus and developing a daily practice.

Name: The Panini Players
Description:
The Panini Players are a theatre ensemble who perform in the style of Commedia dell'Arte. We hold one feature performance per quarter, which includes a make-your-own panini dinner and a one-hour show. We mix lowbrow physical comedy with highbrow wit, which produces an interesting comedic dynamic.

https://vimeo.com/256685839
Summary: The Panini Players are a theatre ensemble dedicated to bringing the classical style of Commedia dell'Arte to campus. Commedia is distinctive for its use of masks,  stock characters, physical comedy and improvisation.

Name: The Set-Up
Summary: N/A

Name: The Slam Society
Description: The Slam Society is Northwestern University's open forum on performance poetry. The Slam Society seeks to provide an open and welcoming environment for poets of all levels of experience to write, perform, learn, and grow, and hopes that by holding events for amateurs and veterans alike, sponsoring trips to poetry readings in the community, and spreading the appreciation of spoken word, the poets among us can perform their original works to welcoming and supportive audiences to develop their talents.
Summary: The Slam Society seeks to provide an open and welcoming environment for poets of all levels of experience to write, perform, learn, and grow.

Name: The Studio
Description: tba
Summary: tba

Name: The Subcontinent Project
Description: The Subcontinent Project aims to foster meaningful conversations among the Northwestern and Chicagoland community by organizing events pertaining to South Asian issues including, but not limited to, democracy and human rights, gender and sexuality and nationalism, and situating these topics as a part of larger global conversations that are currently taking place.
Summary: The Subcontinent Project aims to foster meaningful conversations among the Northwestern and Chicagoland community by organizing events pertaining to South Asian issues.

Name: The Underground Lectures
Description:
The Underground Lectures is an organization whose goal is to give current NU students the platform to exchange lectures about any topic that fascinates them. From Wikipedia rabbit holes to revolutionary proposed forms of renewable energy, from obscure moments in time to the mysterious lost etymology of the word "dog," and from the history of table-setting customs to a seminar on impromptu public speaking, we make sure that no stone of knowledge is left unturned. The organization seeks to promote learning for the sake of learning, and invites listeners and speakers with equal gusto.

 

Our name was chosen because students teaching students—treating each other as mentor, mentee, and peer, simultaneously—breaks convention. We are eager to create our own network of inspired young educators at Northwestern beneath the established professorial world. More than all, this organization's mission is to allow ideas to flourish and interact, and to assist those who wish to share their ideas with others.
Summary: Welcome to The Underground Lectures, where we give current NU students the chance to exchange TED Talk-style lectures about any topic that fascinates them. If you have something to teach, then we have something to learn\u2014and vice-versa.

Name: The Undertones
Description:
Founded in 2001, the Undertones are a co-ed a cappella group that loves to travel, compete, and be goofy together. We pride ourselves on maintaining a very high level of musicianship, resulting in the group placing second at the 2018 ICCA Great Lakes Quarterfinals and receiving the “Outstanding Soloist” award. Tones have studied in every major school Northwestern University has to offer and hail from all over, creating opportunities for the group to tour nationally (The White House, NYC, Orlando, Denver) and internationally (Edinburgh, Scotland and Barcelona, Spain).  Although much of our time together is spent rehearsing, performing, and recording, the Undertones are also a close group of friends who love spending time with one another and keeping the fun and silliness alive in the work we do!

Check us out on Instagram and YouTube (@nuundertones) or on Spotify (Northwestern Undertones).
Summary: A cappella group from Northwestern University. We sing and laugh while keeping the love and silliness alive.

Name: The Waa-Mu Show
Description:
As Northwestern’s oldest theatrical tradition, The Waa-Mu Show provides undergraduates with the unparalleled opportunity to create an original musical each year. Students serve as leaders in every aspect of development from conception through production to create a show exploring themes and stories that inspire us as college students, challenge us as musical theatre artists, and engage us with our surrounding communities.

The Waa-Mu Show strives to place itself at the forefront of new musical theatre writing, continuing to push the limits of the “greatest college show in America” (Associated Press).
Summary: The Waa-Mu Show is Northwestern University's own original musical, written, performed, and presented by Northwestern students.

Name: The Women's Network
Description: The Women’s Network (TWN) was created for ambitious women looking to grow professionally while being lifted by their community. TWN offers opportunities to gain exposure to the professional world, network with high-profile speakers, and meet peers around their campus and the country. TWN meets biweekly (twice a month) and holds speaker meetings, various networking events, resume, internship and LinkedIn workshops, alumni networking receptions, and interactive activity sessions to develop relationships with fellow members. Our workshops and guest speakers help prepare you for your next steps and may open your eyes to career paths you hadn't considered. TWN prides itself on its non-competitive, inclusive, and supportive community of high-achieving and ambitious members. This organization offers exclusive internship opportunities, workshops and support to help you build your LinkedIn/resume. More personally, TWN is a great place to meet new people within Northwestern, around the country and make friends from various majors.
Summary: The Women\u2019s Network is a networking organization that celebrates ambition and connects women to fellow high-achieving, noncompetitive peers on their respective college campuses and to seasoned female professionals in various fields.

Name: Theme Park Engineering & Design
Description:
The Theme Park Engineering & Design Group (TPED) is a design club under McCormick School of Engineering. 


TPED provides theme park enthusiasts from ALL academic majors a fun multidisciplinary space to pursue their passion for themed entertainment. TPED is a platform for members to further their professional development and delve deeper into this unique field of interest by focusing on three main areas:

1. Collaborating on themed entertainment design projects and competitions.
2. Learning from and networking with professionals in the themed entertainment industry via talks, workshops, and conferences.
3. Creating opportunities to discover and hone industry-related skills.

If you're a designer, artist, engineer, musician, programmer, or literally any person who's interested in making memorable themed experiences, join us!
Summary: Theme Park Engineering & Design Group (TPED) is a multidisciplinary design club for themed entertainment enthusiasts from all backgrounds!

Name: This We Believe Northwestern
Description:
This We Believe Northwestern is based on the popular National Public Radio program, “This I Believe,” (thisibelieve.org) where regular people create and share short essays reflecting on an aspect of their personal philosophy.

Organizations throughout the country have developed their own versions of the program, and have built community and space for reflection. At Northwestern, we successfully piloted the program in the spring of 2012. Over four weeks, small groups meet over a meal to write and share their own essays in a supportive environment. It is one way we can build deeper connections with students, staff, and faculty.

This We Believe Northwestern grew out of a group of Northwestern staff working on implementing and assessing the Spirituality learning domain of the Division of Student Affairs.

If you would like to nominate a student or staff/faculty member, please contact Eric Budzynski at e-budzynski@northwestern.edu  

You may also nominate yourself(!) or inquire about more information on this fantastic program.
Summary: This We Believe Northwestern is an initiative where students, staff, and faculty come together to share a meal and create belief statements reflecting on an aspect of their personal philosophy.

Name: THUNK A Cappella
Description:
THUNK a cappella is Northwestern University's oldest co-ed a cappella group. Since their beginning on campus in 1993, THUNK performs three shows every year on campus, while also performing at numerous external gigs and workshops on campus and in the Chicago area.

\u2b07\ufe0e\u2b07\ufe0e Check out our Videos & Social Media below! \u2b07\ufe0e\u2b07\ufe0e
Summary: THUNK a cappella is Northwestern's premier co-ed a cappella group. They have been singing and wearing hot black on campus since 1993. The group is comprised of 19 members, entirely student directed. They perform on campus and in the Chicago area.

Name: TONIK Tap
Description: Founded in 2001, TONIK Tap is Northwestern University’s premier tap dance ensemble. TONIK’s members hail from all over the country and collectively study a variety of majors, but we all have one thing in common – we love to create rhythm. We perform at various Northwestern and Chicagoland events, from Rhythm Nation and Eberhard's chemistry show in the fall, to Wildcat Days and Dance Marathon in the spring. We also produce two shows a year on campus, with original choreography and video interludes. TONIK's self-choreographed repertoire has been recognized and featured as part of Dance Chicago, a city-wide dance festival in downtown Chicago. We have tapped with soccer balls, an a cappella group, eggs, on contact explosives, and have recreated classic choreography by Gene Kelly. What can we say, tap goes with everything! Email us at toniktap@gmail.com.
Summary: TONIK Tap is Northwestern's premier tap dance company. We come from all over  but we all have one thing in common -- we love to make rhythm! As a completely student-run group, we perform all over campus and Chicagoland.

Name: Track Club
Description:
The NU Track Club is a group of runners from Northwestern University in Evanston, IL. The goals of the group are to:

  •  Promote the sport of running and track and field
  •  Provide a supportive group training environment
  •  Have fun!

    The club is composed of all types of runners, from those running to stay in shape to those seeking competition. The track club is also a great way to meet new friends and we are always accepting new members.

 

For contact information and more about the team please visit our website: 

http://sites.northwestern.edu/runners/ . 

 

If you would like to join our Listserv (mailing list) and GroupMe (our main form of communication), sign up at: https://jointrack.club

 

If you have any questions or concerns, email our President, Mike!
Summary:
Go check out our main website: 
 http://sites.northwestern.edu/runners/

Name: Trading Card Game Club
Description: Helping Northwestern students find groups to play trading card games, help them develop as trading card game players, and to provide an inclusive environment in which new and seasoned players alike can play trading card games together.
Summary: Our goal is to help Northwestern students find groups to play trading card games, help them develop as trading card game players, and to provide an inclusive environment in which new and seasoned players alike can play trading card games together.

Name: Transfer Student Organization
Description: Transfer Student Organization (TSO) fosters a welcoming environment for Northwestern transfer students across all years. TSO facilitates social events every quarter which serve as a platform for transfers to meet, make friends, and access mentorship. In 2018 TSO launched the Transfer Mentorship Program–an initiative which pairs incoming transfer students with transfer mentors based on common interests. Given the self-guided mentor approach, the goal is to ease the process for new transfers. In addition, we promote inclusion and secure resources by voicing community perspectives to the Associated Student Government and university offices. All transfers are welcome to join!
Summary: As the only Northwestern group of its kind, TSO aims to cultivate a dynamic and supportive community of transfer students. We hope to overcome any challenges standing in the way of transfer integration into Northwestern, especially the incoming class.

Name: Treblemakers
Description: Treblemakers is Northwestern’s premiere East-Asian interest a cappella group and welcomes all identities. We sing everything from mainstream American pop, to jazzy Asian ballads, to mashups featuring the best of both worlds. Apart from our quarterly shows, we have year-round gigs performing at Homecoming, Christkindlemarket, CISA show, Celebrasia, and many others. Celebrating cultural exchange, we’ve had the opportunity to tour Hong Kong, Seoul, Beijing and California, as well as collaborate with other special-interest a cappella groups for shows. Throughout the year, everyone has the chance to pitch songs, arrangements, show themes and whatever tickles their fancy. When we’re not making music with our mouths, you can catch us on a road trip around the midwest, going out for a boba run, or just kicking back for a game night. While attending Zoom University, we’ll be making those matrix-styled group videos, featuring solo showcases and participating in other online shenanigans.
Summary:
Treblemakers is Northwestern\u2019s East-Asian interest a cappella group and welcomes all identities. We sing everything from mainstream American pop, to jazzy Asian ballads, to mashups featuring the best of both worlds.
Link: https://linktr.ee/Nutreble

Name: Tufaan Entertainment
Description: Tufaan Entertainment is a student-led non-profit entertainment company aiming to raise awareness of South Asian culture in the US and promote education through the arts abroad. Dance is an integral part of South Asian culture and it is a great way for South Asian youth in America to connect with their roots. Tufaan hosts esteemed teams from across the country as they compete for a national bid at the Bollywood America competition. Tufaan Entertainment is dedicated to supporting Shanti Bhavan, a K-12 school in rural India providing a world-class liberal arts education for socioeconomically disadvantaged children.
Summary: Tufan Entertainment is a student led non-profit organization that presents talented South Asian performers from across the country in an intercollegiate dance competition to raise funds for a school in India and a 2nd local beneficiary.

Name: Typhoon Dance Troupe
Description:
Typhoon Dance Troupe is a student organized dance group that highlights popular, classical, ethnic, and contemporary dances of East and Southeast Asia. Through the art of dance, we dedicate ourselves to displaying pieces of the regions' rich, diverse cultures and to promote more interest and appreciation in the community for those cultures.

Dances are open to people from any type of background, ranging from beginner to experienced, in many styles of dance, including but not limited to: Traditional Han and ethnic Dai Dance, Hip-hop and street dance, jazz dance, and kpop dance. We have weekly workshop and rehearsals and we also invite famous dancers all over the world as our "Master Class" program. We learn and practice for several performances in Northwestern-affiliated productions and off-campus events, most notably Celebrasia, the annual Chinese New Year celebration co-sponsored by CSA and TASC, which draws over 500 people annually. We also make dance videos to record our work and memorable time together. 

2021 Virtual Spring Show: Sunrise

https://youtu.be/kxTWP4Oy3YU

Examples of our dance:

"Grain in Ear" (Chinese style jazz dance ) https://youtu.be/HNUdvEhGTvA

"Juicy" (Jazz funk dance) https://youtu.be/Vwk17-sDi-I

"Red Coral" (Chinese traditional dance) https://youtu.be/BJx6T5mzhK8
Summary: Typhoon Dance Troupe is a student organized dance group that highlights popular and classical dances of East and Southeast Asia. Through work of art, we dedicate ourselves to displaying pieces of the regions' rich and diverse culture.

Name: Ukulele Club
Description:
Ukulele club is a relaxed, fun organization which welcomes students of any major and skill level. We have a ton of beginners along with more advanced players, and all are invited to jam with us! Ukulele club meets weekly, along with playing at a number of various events throughout the year, such as Cider Nights, the Lakefill Bonfire, end of the quarter performances, and more!

Ukulele club meets every Friday at 4:30 PM in Annenberg Hall. Generally, we’ll chill out and catch up with the other members of the club for 5 or 10 minutes. Announcements will be given, and then we’ll either teach the songs for the week or jam out! We also do breakout rooms based off skill level, so anyone and everyone is welcome! Lessons involve new chords, finger-picking techniques, and strum patterns. After the lesson, we will continue to jam as a whole group!
Summary: The purpose of Ukulele club is to teach people how to play ukulele, and to help people who already know how to play the ukulele improve. Additionally, our goal is to foster an accepting and welcoming environment where people can jam with friends.

Name: Undergraduate Chemistry Council
Description: The UCC welcomes students of all majors who are interested in the science of chemistry. We hold quarterly chemistry-related events including UCC Pizza Talks with fellow undergraduates giving talks about their research. We also provide community outreach events for grade school-aged children in the Evanston and Chicago area. In addition, each year the UCC helps put on campus-wide chemistry shows that attract hundreds of people, the most popular ones being the Halloween and Eberhard Beach shows, and each spring we bring a distinguished speaker to come to Northwestern and speak about their research.
Summary: The UCC welcomes students of all majors who are interested in chemistry! We put together chemistry-related events each quarter as well as campus-wide chemistry events such as the Halloween show and liquid nitrogen ice cream social!

Name: Undergraduate Economics Society
Description:
The Undergraduate Economics Society is a group for undergraduate economics majors, and others interested in economics and business.

Our mission is to increase resources for students interested in economics and business and further their academic and career goals. We strive to provide a variety of events to enrich students’ experiences at Northwestern and to continue the pursuit for excellence in the events we host and sponsor.

In the past, UES has hosted Career Workshops on topics such as Resume, Cover Letter, Recruitment, and Industry Overview. Also, UES holds multiple Speaker Events every quarter featuring renowned economists in Northwestern and Kellogg, Internship speaker panel, and Professionals.
Summary: The Undergraduate Economics Society is a group for undergraduate economics majors, and others interested in economics and business. We hold a variety of events to increase resources and to enrich students\u2019 experiences at Northwestern.

Name: Undergraduate Premedical Society
Description: The Undergraduate Premedical Society at Northwestern University (UPS) is an organization designed to provide premedical students with resources and opportunities as they plan to apply to medical school.  Please contact premednu@gmail.com if you have any questions.  For more information visit the UPS Facebook Page at www.facebook.com/NorthwesternUPS.
Summary: The Undergraduate Premedical Society at Northwestern University (UPS) is an organization designed to provide premedical students with resources and opportunities as they plan to apply to medical school.  Contact: premednu@gmail.com

Name: Undergraduate Prison Education Partnership
Description: The Undergraduate Prison Education Partnership cultivates collaboration between Evanston undergraduates and prisoners in the Northwestern Prison Education Program at Stateville Correctional Center through prison education initiatives. These initiatives include events, tutoring, workshops, and classes at Stateville CC, awareness and advocacy campaigns in Evanston, supplies drives, and fundraising events supporting prison education.
Summary: Our student group works closely with the Northwestern Prison Education Program (NPEP) to develop prison education initiatives at Stateville Correctional Center and Cook County Department of Corrections

Name: Undergraduate Psychology Association
Description: The Undergraduate Psychology Association (UPA) is a group of psychology students who are dedicated to helping all students with an interest in psychology. UPA sponsors academic, social, and community service events during the school year to help undergraduates learn more about the exciting field of psychology and to foster student-faculty relations outside the classroom.
Summary: The Undergraduate Psychology Association (UPA) is a group of psychology students who are dedicated to helping all students with an interest in psychology. UPA sponsors academic, social, and community service events during the school year to help

Name: Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association
Description: URSA is the Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association. It is made up of 10 or more student representatives in the Radio/TV/Film department. We act as the liaison between the student body and the faculty. Our role is to relay students' issues, concerns, and complaints about the curriculum to the faculty so that these problems can be solved. Our co-chairs attend monthly faculty meetings and meet with the department chairs regularly in order to ensure that the students are being heard.
Summary: URSA is the Undergraduate Radio/Television/Film Student Association. It is made up of 10 student representatives in the Radio/TV/Film department. We act as the liaison between the student body and the faculty.

Name: Undergraduate Real Estate Club
Description:
Undergraduate Real Estate Club aspires:

  •        To inspire and educate students previously unexposed to real estate to become more interested in the industry
  •        To provide those with previous knowledge in the field with a forum for expanding upon this interest
  •        To promote teamwork and commitment while also simulating the competitive environment of the industry
  •        To facilitate interaction between organization members and faculty as well as industry professionals
  •        To serve as a resource for real estate career advice and information
Summary: UREC will seek to connect interested undergraduate students to all facets of the real estate industry. Members of our club will gain exposure to the field through Chicago site visits, skill building workshops, networking events, and more.

Name: UNICEF NU
Description: UNICEF NU seeks to engage Northwestern University students in global health issues and to advocate for the rights of children and other vulnerable populations worldwide. In the past, UNICEF NU has hosted a number of events, including a speaker panel about women's health, documentary screenings about human trafficking, and a water walk to raise awareness about the need for clean water across the globe.
Summary: UNICEF NU is an organization that aims to educate, advocate and fundraise on behalf of UNICEF.

Name: United World Colleges Club
Description:
"UWC makes education a force to unite people, nations and cultures for peace and a sustainable future."

These are the guiding principles of the United World Colleges. As alumni of UWCs across the globe, we are hoping to connect all of the UWC alumni at Northwestern, as well as those in the Chicagoland area. The goal is to develop an organization that can serve social, educational and community service purposes, and involve non-alumni as well.
Summary:
"UWC makes education a force to unite people, nations and cultures for peace and a sustainable future."
People who recognize or who are interested in this mission statement are welcome to join!

Name: UNITY Charity Fashion Show
Description:
About Us:

Uniting communities through fashion and philanthropy.

UNITY Charity Fashion Show is a non-profit, student-run organization working to provide an outlet for students and those in the Greater Chicago area to use their love for fashion, style, and art for good. Each year, during Northwestern's spring quarter, UNITY hosts a fashion show featuring student performers, dancers, musicians, and artists with an audience of 200+ people. Proceeds from the show benefit a charitable organization in Chicago chosen by our own members. UNITY also hosts fundraising events throughout the year such as clothing drives, pop-up thrift shops, and model Q&As. In the past, we’ve partnered with Social Works and raised $10,000 towards their efforts for Chicago Public Schools. This year, UNITY partners with Arts of Life, which is a non-profit organization for artists with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

Any inquiries about involvement, press, or sponsorships, please contact unity.northwestern@gmail.com.
Summary: UNITY Charity Fashion Show is an annual event sponsored by diverse student groups from across campus. Together, students from all backgrounds come together for their love of fashion and raise money for a different charity every year.

Name: University Bible Fellowship
Description: UBF is a nondenominational, evangelical fellowship with one-to-one and group Bible studies, reflection sharing, Sunday worship, and conferences. One-to-one Bible studies are flexible appointments; students can determine location and time. Email for more information.
Summary: UBF is a nondenominational, evangelical fellowship with one-to-one and group Bible studies, reflection sharing, Sunday worship, and conferences. One-to-one Bible studies are flexible appointments; students can determine location and time. Email for info.

Name: University Christian Ministry
Description:
UCM is an ecumenical  and queer-affirming campus ministry at Northwestern University. We are sponsored by the United Methodist Church and the Presbyterian Church (USA). If you are looking for the Wesley Foundation or the Westminster House at Northwestern University, you have found us! All are welcome at UCM.

In normal times, we gather on Sundays at 5:00 PM for dinner and an informal worship service. Currently, we meet at 5 PM on Zoom for informal worship. We will also hold fellowship events throughout the quarter: feel free to join us at any of the events listed on this page!  https://youtu.be/l5g0JQPxz9Q
Summary: UCM is an ecumenical and queer-affirming campus ministry at Northwestern University. We are sponsored by the United Methodist Church and the Presbyterian Church (USA), but we welcome all!

Name: University Special Interest
Description: University Special Interest is a label for student organizations related to Northwestern University (i.e. The Northwestern Daily, NU Channel 1, etc.).
Summary: University Special Interest is a label for student organizations related to Northwestern University (i.e. The Northwestern Daily, NU Channel 1, etc.).

Name: Venture Capital Club
Description: The Northwestern Venture Capital Club is a student-run organization dedicated to those with an interest in learning about and/or pursuing a career in venture capital. The club is open to all undergraduate students.
Summary: TBA

Name: Vertigo Productions
Description: Vertigo is an executive student theatre board dedicated to producing new work by fellow undergraduate students.
Summary: Vertigo is an executive student theatre board that produces 6+ shows a year that are written by fellow undergraduate students.Want to learn more? Check out our website at http://www.vertigoplays.org/ or reach out to marianareyes@u.northwetsern.edu

Name: Vietnamese Student Association
Description: VSA is for everyone who has an interest in the Vietnamese culture. VSA exists in order to promote awareness of and appreciation for Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture and history within the student body as well as to form a mutual relationship between Northwestern University and the local Vietnamese community. We host a variety of social and cultural events, such as Pho Outings, Tet Night, and SEA Night, and attend different conferences with other VSAs in the area. We also do a lot of collaborated events with other VSAs, primarily at UIC, Loyola, and UIUC. You do not have to be Vietnamese to join!
Summary: VSA exists in order to promote awareness of and appreciation for Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture and history.  You do not have to be Vietnamese to join! We are actively seeking new members, and currently offer junior exec positions!

Name: WATCH
Description:
2020-21 RECRUITMENT EXPECTED TO REOPEN IN FALL - SUBMIT YOUR INTEREST TO JOIN WATCH BY FOLLOWING THIS LINK https://www.northwestern.edu/wellness/hpaw/involvement/watch/apply-to-be-a-watch-peer-health-educator.html

Wildcats Advancing Total Campus Health (WATCH) is a group of peer health educators born out of the Red Watch Band Bystander Intervention Training and operating under Health Promotion and Wellness (HPaW). We focus our efforts in line with the direction and wellness needs of our campus as identified by HPaW. With a strong focus on alcohol and other drugs, we continue to expand our outreach into other areas of health and wellness by taking a holistic approach through the Eight Dimensions of Wellness model.

Our aim is to improve the health and well-being of individuals and the Northwestern community as a whole through evidence-based, theory-driven education and outreach initiatives. We accomplish this through individual, small, and large group education and outreach efforts including but not limited to…

 

  - Interactive Educational Programs & Trainings

  - Workshops

  - Tabling

  - Awareness Campaigns

 

You can learn more from our page.
Summary: WATCH is a group of peer health educators operating under the guidance of Health Promotion and Wellness (HPaW). Our aim is to improve the health and well-being of individuals and the Northwestern community as a whole.

Name: WAVE Productions
Description:
WAVE Productions is a self-supporting, not-for-profit student theatre company which operates primarily on Northwestern University's Evanston Campus. WAVE Productions exists to share the stories of the past and present in order to open the door to a better future.

To fulfill its responsibility to the Northwestern campus and surrounding communities, WAVE sets for itself the following objectives:

  • to sustain a dynamic and progressive presence on campus by fostering traditional and experimental theatrical forms
  • to provide an environment in which students can educate themselves through the art and business of theatre
  • to create an extended family and provide a safe environment in which creativity can flourish
  • to provoke response within our communities
  • to encourage ongoing exploration and discovery through theatre
  • to create and engage a new generation of theatre artists and audiences
Summary: WAVE Productions exists to share the stories of the past and present in order to open the door to a better future. Thus, the events we do are not limited to a single form or theme - we are excited about the art our collaborators are excited about!

Name: Werewolves Club
Description:
Werewolf is basically poker, plus rationalization, minus cards and betting. During the game, each player needs to logically come up with convincing speeches and reasonable deductions within a very short period of time.


Many have found that they have become better at critical thinking and making impromptu speeches after participating. More importantly, they develop strong bonds among themselves while having great fun. This game is extremely popular among both undergraduate and graduate students (our first few trial events have attracted around 50 students each time). However, many students tend to stick to their own local groups and do not have the chance of meeting new players due to the lack of interaction between graduates and undergraduates. Also, it is very hard for them to find enough people each time. Our aim is to provide such
an opportunity to bring these excellent players together and help them meet new people, so they can share new strategies and improve their conversation and networking skills. Players of any experience level are welcome, and our members are ready and able to teach the game to any new players. We intend to host a weekly event for both undergraduates and graduates and participate in national tournaments (which are hosted sporadically). At this stage we mainly focus on Werewolves using Chinese, but ultimately we would like to include players from all of the world and introduce more strategic board games to our members.
Summary: Our organization mainly hosts \u2018The Werewolves of Millers Hollow\u2019 (\u2018Werewolves\u2019 in shorthand), which is a strategic board game involving 8 and 18 players debating.

Name: Wild Roots
Description:
Wild Roots Garden was founded at Northwestern University in the fall of 2009 through a collaboration between the One Book One Northwestern project, three undergraduate environmental student organizations (SEED, ECO, and ESW), Facilities Management, the graduate student garden, and Norris University Center.   Today, Wild Roots is managed by undergraduate students in (grateful) collaboration with Facilities Management.  Our fresh produce is harvested and donated to the chefs in our dining halls or sold to students. During the school year, we work with other environmental student groups to host fun and educational events on campus.

We are located on the south lawn of Norris University Center (outside of Norbucks).  Come visit us!
Summary: Wild Roots is a student-directed garden that grows fresh produce for the Northwestern and Evanston communities using sustainable practices.

Name: Wildcat Connection Pages
Description: Wildcat Connection is managed by representatives in Student Organizations & Activities as well as Student Affairs IT.
Summary: Wildcat Connection is the directory for student organizations, campus departments, fraternity/sorority chapters, and more.

Name: Wildcat Welcome
Description:
Be a Part of Wildcat Welcome!

Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors Can Apply to Be on the Wildcat Welcome Staff

The Office of New Student and Family Programs relies heavily on student volunteers to plan and execute Wildcat Welcome and Parents' Weekend. Freshmen, sophomores and juniors can apply for two positions within the Wildcat Welcome staff structure starting late Fall Quarter and ending mid-Winter Quarter. The positions include the Board of Directors, and Peer Advisers.

Requirements and Characteristics of Staff Members

Applicants should display exceptional communication, organizational and interpersonal skills,  a positive attitude and passion a for WW, Northwestern University and new students. If you want to be a staff member, we expect you to...

- Devote the majority of your time to Wildcat Welcome activities during the week of Wildcat Welcome

- Be motivating, spirited, and enthusiastic

- Have a positive attitude

- Demonstrate excellent communication skills

- Demonstrate exceptional interpersonal relationship skills

- Be organized, flexible, mature, and professional

- Be passionate about Wildcat Welcome, Northwestern University, and new students’ need

- Serve as a role model and mentor

- Be open-minded toward diverse cultures, ethnicities, lifestyles, and backgrounds

Duties of Wildcat Welcome Staff Members

- Attend all  trainings and meetings during Spring Quarter--an attendance policy will be in effect

- Maintain close communication with your Board liaison or freshmen over the summer for Wildcat Welcome updates, answers to questions, and concerns

- Attend One-Day Intensive Training, one day prior to the beginning of Wildcat Welcome

- Assist with new student move-in at assigned residence hall area. This includes check-in, moving boxes, conversing with parents and family members, and creating a welcoming environment

- Attendance at required assigned Wildcat Welcome events and activities

- Wildcat Welcome responsibilities associated with your particular school

- Assist with implementing the Essential NUs

- Attendance at all sessions, social activities, President’s Convocation, and various other Wildcat Welcome events

- Lead thoughtful and effective discussions after Essential NU sessions. Topics include diversity, safety, alcohol, etc.

- Answer all new students’ questions with honest and appropriate answers

- Coordinate solutions to problems, issues, or emergencies encountered during Wildcat Welcome

- Be prepared to devote the majority, if not all of your time during Wildcat Welcome to Wildcat Welcome events

- Assist with assigned Academic School’s Dean’s Convocation
Summary:
Be a Part of Wildcat Welcome!
Freshmen, Sophomores and Juniors Can Apply to Be on the Wildcat Welcome Staff!
The Office of New Student and Family Programs relies heavily on student volunteers to plan and execute Wildcat Welcome and more!

Name: Wildcats for Israel
Description: Wildcats for Israel promotes awareness of Israel on campus by engaging students and campus leaders through educational and cultural events, as well as a vast array of speakers connected to Israel. Additionally, Wildcats for Israel strives to garner support for Israel by increasing the conversation on campus and educating students. Wildcats for Israel is a non-partisan organization welcoming participants of all ethnicities, religions, and backgrounds.
Summary: Wildcats for Israel is Northwestern's pro-Israel group on campus that strives to advocate, educate and discuss all topics concerning Israel including culture, politics, and history.

Name: WildCHAT
Description: The mission of WildCHAT is to provide all Northwestern students, regardless of race, religion, ethnicity, ability, sexual orientation or gender representation, with a free, confidential peer listening service. We also aim to improve the mental health climate at Northwestern by promoting education and conversation regarding mental health issues. Peer listening is not counseling or therapy. The point of peer listening is to create a safe, confidential, non-judgmental environment where students can come to talk about anything they want. We do not provide advice or dictate what you should talk about with us. Instead, we practice a technique called "active listening." Check us out at http://wildchatnu.org
Summary: The mission of Wildchat is to provide all Northwestern students, regardless of race, religion, ethnicity, ability, sexual orientation or gender representation, with a free, confidential peer listening service.

Name: Wildlife Club
Description: The Wildlife Club's purpose is to create an inclusive community on campus comprised of future scientists, environmental activists, animal lovers, and any student who has a passion for wildlife and is concerned with the global biodiversity crisis. The Wildlife Club's goals are to be an advocate on campus for wildlife conservation through activism, to provide career-building opportunities in the field of conservation, to engage with the Northwestern, Evanston, and Chicago communities through discussions and citizen science projects, and build relationships between Northwestern and Chicago-based zoological research institutions. Long-term goals include on-campus wildlife surveys, regular club-sponsored trips to zoos, aquariums, and museums, outreach and research partnerships with these institutions, hosting professional speakers and career fairs on-campus, and petitioning the university for more wildlife-related academic opportunities.
Summary: A student organization dedicated to promoting wildlife conservation and appreciation on campus

Name: Willard Residential College
Description:
Willard Hall is on south campus and houses 290 students in single- and double-occupancy and a very limited number of triple-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women are clustered by gender on the same floor. Willard is a non-thematic Residential College and is one of the oldest RCs on campus.

 

Visit willardnu.com for more info.
Summary: Willard Residential College is on south campus and houses 290 students in single- and double-occupancy and a very limited number of triple-occupancy rooms, arranged in a traditional-style layout. Men and women are clustered by gender on the same floor.

Name: WNUR Student Radio
Description:
WNUR is Northwestern's student radio, but it's much more than just college radio. WNUR is a non-commercial, listener-supported radio station broadcasting at a frequency of 89.3 MHz FM and a power of 7200 watts. The WNUR studios are located in Louis Hall on the Northwestern University campus in Evanston, IL, and the station produces a signal that can be heard by 3 million potential listeners throughout the Chicagoland area. WNUR also streams on the Web to listeners around the world.

Through its programming, WNUR strives to provide a forum for underrepresented music and ideas. By pursuing the cultural, intellectual, and artistic aspects of radio, WNUR promotes musicians, musical genres, news, public affairs issues, and athletic events often overlooked by major media outlets. Because it is completely independent of commercial pressures, WNUR has the opportunity to provide unique and challenging programming to the Northwestern, Evanston, and Chicago communities no matter how unpopular or controversial.

Although WNUR is student-run, its roster of DJs comprises both students and members of the WNUR community. These DJs are able to share their experience, knowledge and passion with the students, creating an incredible learning community. Programming ranges from jazz to all kinds of experimental rock to house music and everything in between. We host top notch talk radio, news reporting and sports broadcasts for talkers; techies join Airplay, our long standing in-studio performance segment which has previously hosted bands like OK GO, Jeff Tweedy of Wilco and the Smashing Pumpkins. With over 60 years of tradition, some of our famous alumni include Win Butler, Stephen Colbert, Steve Albini, and Derrick Carter. Students are always welcome to visit the studio and we accept apprentices year-round (although our fall kick off event is the best time to get plugged in!). To get a taste you can always tune in right now, at www.wnur.org.
Summary: WNUR is Northwestern's student radio- but it's much more than just college radio. WNUR is a non-commercial, listener-supported radio station broadcasting at a frequency of 89.3 MHz FM and a power of 7200 watts. WNUR has broadcasted since 1950.

Name: Women in Business
