Description: Women In Business (WIB) is an open-entry organization established to provide business-minded female or non-binary identifying individuals with the background and network to support them in their professional endeavors. WIB's goal is to engage women across a wide variety of academic and professional affiliations on campus in order to catalyze the involvement of women in the Northwestern community, in the business world, and beyond.
Summary: Women in Business (WIB) is an open-entry organization established to provide business-minded female-identifying individuals with the background and network to support them in their professional endeavors.

Name: Women in Computing
Description: Founded in 2012, Women in Computing (WiC) initially sought to disrupt Northwestern University’s male-dominant computer science major by creating a space for those who identify as women. Now, WiC has become a full-fledged community for women who share an interest in technology and code, and the primary advocate for females in the computer science major. WiC hosts weekly programming tutorials, organizes lunch-and-learn tech talks with corporate and academic professionals, and volunteers to teach middle school girls the principles of computer science. One of the hallmarks of WiC membership is attending the annual Grace Hopper Celebration for Women in Computing; WiC aims to send all interested members to this conference in order to promote professional development and WiC friendships. WiC is currently headed by internal president Anna Deng (annadeng2020@u.northwestern.edu) and external president Suzy Lee (sujunglee2020@u.northwestern.edu).
Summary: WiC\u00a0fosters a community for and promotes the professional development of women who share an interest in technology. WiC offers weekly hack nights, tech talks with corporate & academic professionals, volunteering opportunities, and a mentorship program.

Name: Women In Leadership
Summary: Women In Leadership is a program that builds connections between women leaders so that women can make a difference in the professional life, personal life and community.

Name: Women in Philosophy
Description:
WiPhi is a group of women and female-identifying individuals from all levels of Northwestern's philosophy department. Undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty get together over snacks and drinks every other week. We aim to create an agenda of philosophical pursuits of common interest to its members including deepening class work, exchanging views with others on philosophical topics, and sharing common concerns about what its like to be a woman in philosophy at NU.

WiPhi is proud to host the annual Gertrude Bussey lecture, named for the first recipient of a Ph.D. in philosophy at NU in 1915, in which WiPhi invites a distinguished female philosopher from a major university to give a public lecture. 

We are open to all women who want to think about or discuss philosophical topics, no matter their nature.  Come join us for snacks, tea, and great conversation!
Summary: WiPhi is a group of women and female-identifying individuals from all levels of Northwestern academia. Undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty get together over snacks and drinks to discuss philosophy every other week.

Name: Women in Philosophy Workshop
Description: The Women in Philosophy Workshop seeks to increase the visibility and relevance of women in philosophy by showcasing their work in a supportive and inclusive environment.  We welcome any and all professional women philosophers (graduate and faculty) in the Chicagoland area to attend.
Summary: The Women in Philosophy Workshop seeks to increase the visibility and relevance of women in philosophy by showcasing their work in a supportive and inclusive environment.

Name: Women in Science and Engineering Research
Description: Are you interested in issues surrounding women in STEM? Are you a graduate woman in the sciences at Northwestern? Join our listserv (wiser@listserv.it.northwestern.edu) or like us on Facebook to hear about interesting articles, helpful events for skills & networking, and quarterly discussion socials and faculty seminars.
Summary: Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) works towards building community among graduate women in STEM, advancing women's leadership in STEM, and developing professional skills through workshops & seminars for early-career women in the sciences.

Name: Women's Center
Description:
The Northwestern University Women's Center is dedicated to fostering a campus climate that promotes equity and enriches the personal, professional and academic lives of all members of the University community, particularly women students, staff and faculty.

The Center's mission is to enhance the academic achievement, career aspiration and personal development of women at NU and to help build an environment wherein women and men can work productively together.

The Center is dedicated to building an inclusive and diverse community.

We invite you to participate in the exciting and varied programs that we offer.
Summary: The Northwestern University Women's Center is dedicated to fostering a campus climate that promotes equity and enriches the personal, professional and academic lives of all members of the University community.

Name: Women's Club Lacrosse
Description:
IMPORTANT: ACTIVITIES WILL START FALL QUARTER FOR THE 2021-2022 SCHOOL YEAR DUE TO COVID-19

NU women's club Lacrosse is a fun and competitive atmosphere. Many of the women played in high school and couldn't bear to give it up in college. Others are looking for a fun way to meet some awesome people and play a great sport.

We practice as much as possible, understanding that the quarter system and our academic schedules drive a busy NU career. This works out to practice twice a week in fall/spring and once a week in the winter. 

We play from 3-4 tournaments both at Northwestern and at other schools in the spring with other teams from the area and from schools in our league. 

Tryouts are informal and all inclusive. If you want to play, we will find a place for you. This team formed because we love the game and simply love to play.
Summary:
NU women's club Lacrosse is a fun and competitive atmosphere.  The women all played in high school and couldn't bear to give it up in college.
 
We practice about twice a week and play in 3-4 tournaments throughout the year.

Name: Women's Club Soccer
Description:
The Women’s Club soccer team is part of the Women’s Midwest Alliance Soccer Club (W-MASC) League.  We play competitively against teams in the Great Lakes region. The Fall season begins in September and runs to the end of October. The Spring season begins around April.

Games

In the Fall we typically play 10 games against teams both in Chicago and neighboring states, and our competition includes teams like Depaul, UW-Madison, Notre Dame, Michigan Tech, and Marquette. About half of our games are away and require traveling (such as to Wisconsin or Indiana). Home games are at Lakeside Field on campus. In the Spring we play fewer games, typically against teams in the Chicago-land area. 

Practices

In the fall, we will practice at least twice a week, as well as opportunities for group fitness. We stress the importance of coming to practice, so please try to arrange your class schedule around practice times. 

Dues

All members are required to pay club dues, which will be around $200. This is necessary to cover facility costs, referees, travel costs, equipment, and social events. Members are encouraged to apply for the Student Activities Scholarship Fund to alleviate the financial burden of dues.

Tryouts

As a competitive team, we take anywhere from 20-30 total girls who are committed to playing for the fall and part of the spring quarter. Although most girls have played competitively in high school, we encourage anyone who wants to play to tryout.

Tryouts:

Fall 2019 tryout dates will be held during Wildcat Welcome on Long Field: 

Friday, September 20th: 4-6pm

Monday, September 23rd: 12-2pm 

Please bring cleats, shin guards, a ball if you have one, and water.

*Monday is invite only*

 

Aside from playing soccer, the team arranges outings and gatherings in order to build a strong community for the players. If you have any questions, please contact us at nuclubsoccer@gmail.com.

 

Be sure to check out our facebook page 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Northwestern-University-Womens-Club-Soccer/514295588713766

and Instagram @nuclubsoccer
Summary: The Women's Club soccer team is part of the Women's Midwest Alliance Soccer Club (W-MASC) League.  We play competitively against teams in the Great Lakes region. The Fall season begins in September and ends at the end of October.

Name: Women's Club Volleyball
Description: The Women's Club Volleyball team is a competitive team opportunity for anyone who loves volleyball - whether you played on a high school, club, or recreational team prior to attending Northwestern, if you have a love for the game, we would love to have you! Our team has anywhere from 15-20 members depending on positions and lineups. We take a full team to every tournament. We hold tryouts at the beginning of fall quarter, which are typically scheduled during the first week of classes. Typically we travel to 2-3 tournaments per quarter. Based on team interest, scheduling and finances, our goal is to finish each season with a trip to the NCVF National Tournament in early April. We practice twice a week on campus, in addition to participating in beach games and other opportunities when they arise. We pride ourselves on being a competitive squad, so we expect our level of play to reflect that every time we pick up a volleyball – in practices, tournaments, on the beach, and elsewhere. Being a part of the Women’s Club Volleyball team is a commitment – we expect every member to attend each practice, tournament and meeting, unless academic or emergency circumstances apply. We hold our team to a high standard of play, as well as a high standard of conduct. Work hard, play hard, and have fun!
Summary: The Women's Club Volleyball team is a competitive athletic opportunity. Our team has anywhere from 15-20 members depending on positions and lineups. Typically we travel to 3 tournaments per quarter. Work hard, play hard, have fun!

Name: Women's Rugby Football Club
Description:
Since the club was founded in Spring 1999, its membership and competitiveness have continued to grow. As a member of the Chicago Area Rugby Football Union (CARFU) with six other women's collegiate teams, NU has become an annual competitor for the league title, winning the CARFU Cup in 2001 and 2002.

Beyond CARFU, the team plays college teams in the Midwest Rugby Football Union, including many Big Ten schools, as well as older women's club teams from Chicago, Milwaukee, Indianapolis, and elsewhere.  For dedicated players, there are opportunities to advance to Chicago area select, Midwest select, and USA select sides.

The club's roster fluctuates between the fall (competitive) and spring (developmental) seasons but generally hovers around 20-25 players. The team holds two practices during the week and matches on weekends throughout the fall and spring. During the off-season, players continue skill development at indoor winter practices and work on conditioning and weight training individually.

In past years, the team has traveled and competed internationally during Spring Break with the NU men's team. In 2002, the teams traveled to Barcelona, Andorra and Perpignan, and France.  In 2006, the women's team traveled to Ireland, in 2008, to Germany, and in 2010, the Bahamas.  In 2012, the team decided to stay in the Midwest and competed in the March Madness Tournament in Wayne, Nebraska, combining teams with the College of St. Benedict and St. John's Women.  Competing with 85 teams nationally, Northwestern Women held their own, winning all games in their division.  The tournament was completed with nights of camping, and a road trip full of bonding and ridiculousness.

We do not hold tryouts, so anyone who wants to join the team is able to come out to practice and play. We usually have six or seven games each season, traveling to roughly half.  For league games, travel is limited to the Chicagoland area, but we usually take one overnight trip to locations such as University of Michigan and Northern Illinois University to compete in the Tournament of Champions.  Fall practices are held at Long Field, winter practices at Trienen's Hall, and spring practices are held on Lakeside Field.  All home games are played at Long Field.
Summary: Since the club was founded in Spring 1999, its membership and competitiveness have continued to grow. As a member of the Chicago Area Rugby Football Union (CARFU) with six other women's collegiate teams, NU has become an annual competitor for the league.

Name: Women's Ultimate Frisbee
Description:
Claw is Northwestern's womxn's Ultimate frisbee team. We welcome all skill levels! We have a competitive A team and a developmental B team.

Due to COVID-19, Claw is still working out the logistics of practices for the next year. This fall, we will try our best to still maintain a close team dynamic while being socially distant. 

Trust.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dFORcnUqAjE
Summary: Claw is Northwestern's womxn's Ultimate frisbee team. We welcome all skill levels! We have a competitive A team and a developmental B team.

Name: Womxn In Economics
Description:
Womxn in Economics (WiE) is a group of undergraduate students interested in and/or pursuing a degree in economics. 

WiE seeks to encourage female-identifying members of the community to pursue their interests in economics through a variety of events and learning opportunities. Connecting womxn with similar passions, we offer valuable mentorship opportunities for members. Our programming offers insight into the many unique ways economics can be applied in academics, business, career options, and society as a whole. We aim to provide an empowering environment for womxn at Northwestern within this often male-dominated field. Our hope is that all womxn will have the resources and support they need to see that economics is for everyone!
Summary: Womxn in Economics (WiE) is a group of undergraduate students which seeks to encourage female-identifying members of the NU community to pursue their interests in economics, and to support them as they do so.

Name: Womxn in Law
Description: Womxn in Law was founded for female-identifying and non-binary students on campus who are interested in pursuing careers in legal fields. Its main purposes are to create a support system for students interested in law, provide them with the tools necessary to thrive in the field, and to address some of the most prominent issues women and gender minorities in the field often face. Womxn in Law aims to create a network of ambitious students who are passionate about their career aspirations. To join, email womxninlaw@u.northwestern.edu.
Summary: Women in Law is an organization dedicated to empowering women and non-binary individuals on campus to pursue their career goals in the legal field.

Name: World Cup at NU
Description:
• Northwestern University World Cup is the largest student-run athletic tournament on campus. It is an organization seeking to bridge cultures and bring students from all backgrounds together to play the global game of football. Fundamentally, NU World Cup believes in the unifying power of sport to bring students together. Our vision is to create a campus where all members of the Northwestern community, regardless of background, experience the passion and energy of soccer.
  • On another level, our dream for this event involves not only to recognize the diversity but also recognize that we are all from the same school and that we are one Northwestern. We want students to realize that we all come from the same place, share the same experiences, and although we come from all over the world, we are unified through Northwestern.
  • World Cup also aims to support the local Chicago community through our close partnership with Gonzo Soccer.
Summary: Northwestern University World Cup (NUWC) is Northwestern\u2019s largest student-run athletic event, bringing together over 750 students from all backgrounds through the love of the beautiful game of soccer.

Name: X-Factors
Description:
The X-Factors were formed in 2001 with the goal of infusing amazing music with the individuality and passion of a diverse group of students. Today, we are a wacky family of eighteen, who major in everything from theatre to mechanical engineering, and sing all musical styles from Aretha Franklin to Avril Lavigne! Though more than 16 years have passed since the original group was created, we still strive to create a comfortable environment, a unique sound, and memorable performances.

We perform in our own sold-out shows on-campus, but we also love giving back to the community and going on tour! In recent years, we were featured on Chicago’s WGN radio and toured around Southern California performing at high schools and nursing homes, and running workshops for middle/high school students.

The X-Factors have released five CDs and have been featured on compilation CDs. Our most recent CD, Singing For Churros (October 2014), has been recognized on the national a cappella scene. For our past and current work, we have been nominated for CARA awards, been featured on VOICES ONLY 2013 and BOCA 2013. We were also honored to receive a great review from Mike Chin of The A Cappella Blog. Our upcoming album, Singing in the Dark, will be released fall 2017.

UPCOMING EVENTS:

 

~Fall Auditions- TBA through NACCA after Wildcat Welcome :)

For more about the #FactorFam, check out:


-Website: xfactorsnu.wix.com/nuxfactors

-YouTube: www.youtube.com/xfactorsacappella

-Facebook: www.facebook.com/XFactorsNU

-Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/xfactorsnu/

-Twitter: http://twitter.com/XFactorsNU
Summary: The X-Factors are a co-ed group of singers who love having fun and singing awesome a cappella music. We've recorded six CDs and will be releasing another this year! We can't wait for our winter 2019 tour!

Name: Young Democratic Socialists of America
Description: YDSA is a hub for progressives and leftists at Northwestern. We discuss leftist politics as well as provide a space for organizing and activism on campus in order to build a progressive future.
Summary: YDSA is a hub for progressives and leftists at Northwestern. We discuss leftist politics as well as provide a space for organizing and activism on campus in order to build a progressive future.

Name: Young Life
Description: Young Life is a non-denominational Christian outreach to high school and middle school students. Young Life leadership is an opportunity for Northwestern students to serve as volunteer leaders with kids in the local area. NU students gather with students from Loyola University and adults in the community regularly for training, encouragement, and planning -- and all interested students are welcome to come see what we do! Please contact us and we'll shoot you an email with the times of our next leadership meeting!
Summary: Young Life is a non-denominational Christian outreach to high school and middle school students. Young Life leadership is an opportunity for Northwestern students to serve as volunteer leaders and grow in community together.

Name: Zen Society
Summary: Zen Club gives students the opportunity to meditate in a group environment, and talk about meditating, daily life, as well as more philosophical inquiries. Each meeting consists of a meditation, followed by tea and discussion (with a veteran Zen monk!)
